She doesn't know by herself, but when she tries to talk she always has an expression of a ghost. That's the reason she gets the nickname: Sadako (from the ring). Sawako's wish is to make friends, but that's very hard as you can see. She admires her classmate, Kazehaya-kun, who is populair and very nice to everyone, even with her.
I think Kimi Ni Todoke is such a great story.I really like the fact that the main character, Kuronuma Sawako, is a girl who isn't perfect in all ways like maincharacters in most romance animes do. I also love the fact that the drawing style in the anime is similiar to the drawing style in the manga.

Kimi ni Todoke is about friendship and love. It joins breathtaking art with original characters and plausible story development, and it really does not require of you to look the other way in order to believe the story.  
When you start watching Kimi ni Todoke you will probably think that Sawako Kuronuma is just another passive high school girl in love with the beautiful and popular dark boy from her class. But she is not. Sure, she is shy and insecure, but she also takes charge when it's needed, and she never allows for misunderstandings to develop into something worse. She is naive attimes, but she isn't stupid and ignorant.

One of the most refreshing traits of the series are definitely the male characters. They are not larger-than-life, 16-going-on-40 guys. They are as insecure and shy as the girls, and they get embarrassed, and have troubles expressing their feelings. 

I loved the fact that love is not unnaturally forced onto the characters, it doesn't just spring up all of a sudden; it develops, and we actually see why someone is in love and how this happened. 

The naivety of the story and character portrayal comes from youth and inexperience, and not from the story itself. I found this very refreshing and quite nostalgic because Kimi ni Todoke reminded me of how my friends and I have gone through some similar experiences and troubles.


All in all, Kimi ni Todoke is clever, beautiful, cute and different. I recommend watching it, and I am certain you will enjoy it at least as much as I did.

I'm new on this whole writing reviews stuff, but I find most adequate starting them with a sentence that summarizes what to be expected from the anime.
On Kimi ni Todoke's case the general idea is: a romance in which the characters have near to zero attitude.
The story in Kimi ni Todoke is really lame. The mix of romance, comedy and drama, very common in shoujos is poorly done here. The characters have unbelievable reactions in the situations they are exposed, a single smile is enough to be head over heels with someone and the whole series drags on how none of them will do absolutelynothing to try getting some development on the romance component of this show. 

The comedy is often out of place, just as a relief more than anything else. The comic expressions are amusing in the beginning of the show, but later on they feel totally unnecessary.

The drama... what drama? Some silly conflicts due to the lack of attitude or unbelievable reactions is what they call drama in this series.


The only thing I liked in this series is the art. The sceneries are beautifully portrayed, the characters design is also really nice and the whole shoujo atmosphere is satisfactorily enhanced.


It's been a week or two since I watched Kimi ni Todoke and I can't remember anything about the soundtrack. In my case, this means the soundtrack had absolutely nothing special. 


Overall, if you're a fan of romances with no development and want to waste precious time of your life, go for it!=D Go watch Nana or Honey & Clover instead...XP

When l sat down to watch kimi ni todoke, I was looking forward to a good ol fashioned lovey-dovey story, but you know what l got? a turtle race. Now heres the bad part, not only was it really slow-paced, but it was like both turtles decided to go home before getting to the finish line of this perverbial event.
I suppose now is the time that I ought to justify my remarks so I dont sound like im trolling the show. 
The story as you've probably read by now is about a girl named sawako as she wanders through her lonely life. As a sidenote, almost every anime out there has that lonely shy girl in it, but this is the first that i've seen where the show is about the shy girl, and that was quite refreshing.


In the show, she meets and falls in love with a cool-ass dude by the name of kazehaya and well it sorta seems mutual. At this point it becomes that turtle race to see who realizes it first, but you cant make a show around that right? Well, it seems they didnt need to, as in the show it also follows sawakos efforts to make friends, participate in events, and basiaclly just get a social life (which can be quite difficult, l speak from experience). 


The art in this show was somehting that I wont soon forget. It wasnt super-amazing or anything like that, but it was different. I say this because the animators could make sawako look extremely beautiful, or so scarry that my bowels just released... At first l felt like the animators just didnt care, but eventually l realized that it was probalby the most appropriate animation possible in this show. 


The characters are a little generic, as l said earlier the only thing thats really different in the character department is that the shy girl is the main character rather than the supporting role. Other than her though, you have the steriotypical nice guy, that guy who just doesnt give a shit, some girl who would wreck most guys in a brawl, a couple plotters, and the ever present crew of goofy-asses which are there to make the main characters all the more appealing.


l enjoyed the concept of the polar-opposites falling in love, and as it progressed I really got excited for them. The problem that I had is really just the less-than-stellar ending. The way I see it, if you make me sit around for a 25 episode show, you better give me a reason to come back for season two, and as it stands im not sure if they have.

Just watched the first season of Kimi Ni Todoke. Figured I should write a review about it before going into the second season, while my thoughts on it are still fresh.
Disclaimer: Mostly free of spoilers.
Plot: Kuronuma Sawako is a gentle high school student who, due to her scary appearance (resemblance to classic ghost girl) has been unable to make any friends so far. Everything changes when Kazehaya, the most popular guy in class, starts talking to her, prompting others to do the same. From there Sawako begins to understand how friendship and, eventually, romance works.
Sounds like your usual, run-of-the-mill highschool anime, right? Well, you wouldn'tbe wrong, but this is heads and shoulders above the rest of the rabble.


Despite the summary, most of emphasis is given on the friendship between Sawako, Chizu and Ayame, rather than the (very) slowly building romance with Kazehaya. In fact, the show seems intent on stressing the importance of friendship, since Sawako is completely new to the concept.


KnT actually shocked me with how much I enjoyed it. Well, not exactly. What shocked me was that I couldn't find anything in particular to point at and say 'that kind of sucked'.


In more detail:


The protagonist, Sawako (often called 'Sadako' after the ghost in 'The Ring') is genuinely likeable as a person. She is ignorant of a lot of things to do with interpersonal interactions due to her circumstances, but she is not stupid like a lot of protagonists are. She does have the always-positive attitude often encountered, but she does not take it to the annoying extremes often met. She is firm when she wants to be. She's gentle but not a pushover.

I'm generally not a fan of female protagonists. I'm generally not a fan of the 'always positive/nice' archetype. Sawako makes me question a lot of things about myself.



Similarly, the rest of the main cast (about 4 other people) are all well developed. Sawako's two friends, Chizuru and Ayame, have unique personalities, both likeable but equally distinguishable, without needlessly extra long character arcs to make them feel unique. Similarly, Kazehaya and Ryu are also like that, in that they don't instantly fall under an anime character archetype. I found it particularly impressive how the show managed to make the supporting characters feel unique seamlessly through the regular story arc instead of going into long-winded tirades/flash-backs/side-story in order to give them a personality.


Well, Chizu does get an arc to herself near the end and I admit that the transition was a little jarring, but that is about the extent of the show's sin in that regard.


I hesitate to classify this as a romcom. The show can certainly be funny. Whenever it wants to be, it succeeds, but comedy isn't the focus of it, it just occurs. Similarly, while the romantic feelings of various people are often discussed/thought on, for the majority of the show they're not the driving force or the center of attention. I'm not describing this very well, but KnT avoided going into drama territory while still technically being a romance story, basically. Slice-of-life fits it bets, perhaps, although considering the somewhat unique circumstances of Sawako I'm not sure how accurate that is.


The show's intro and closing sequence actually had songs I enjoyed, which is something I don't say often ... or at all. Music is a nonentity besides these two instances, however.


What else, what else ... oh right. The animation is pretty fucking good. I really liked the style. Well above average. The character models are very well made and movements are not wooden, though background suffers a little bit. The focus on the quality of characters themselves really impressed me.


A gripe I have is that there's wasn't any closure towards ... anything, really by the end of the season. I guess it doesn't matter that much since there's a second one, though. Still loses some points because of it.


Overall, there's not much else I can say about this. Perhaps light-hearted, certainly positive overall, watching KmT will make even a rock feel better. However, if one doesn't enjoy this kind of show, there is exactly zero reason to watch this. The biggest 'action' sequence is a slap. I think someone got shoved once, too. So, be warned.


Here's hoping the second season doesn't bomb it.


Wow this wasn't actually that short, huh.


Final rating is 8/10. Would have been a 9, but the ending felt kind of weak. Well, not exactly weak, but not fitting to be an ending episode.

The main character of this anime gave off a bit of Toradora vibes, I liked her awkwardness and how oblivious she is throughout the whole anime. It develops really well and even though the whole show may be a little slow, I didn't feel like it had any (obvious) filler episodes.
MUSIC:
Besides the opening and closing songs I didn't notices many other songs and even though it is a short intro the music I heard was really nice. I think this is one of the only anime's where I actually watched the opening and closing each episode.
CHARACTERS:
Sawako is very similar to Ryu in Toradora from theway people react to them. Though in Torardora he is completely aware and just doesn't care, in Kimi ni Todoke she is oblivious and completely innocent. This eventually leads to her making friends and getting into a typical anime high school life, although she is still quite unusual. I feel like she's a very unique character, though the rest of her friends and other people in the school are no so unique. But that doesn't really matter since it follows her and her development over the whole show is really funny to watch. 


I especially like it when her face changes and the question marks appear since she has no idea what's going on, it adds a lot of humour.


STORY:


The story is light and typical high school events, what makes the anime stand out is the main character and her affect on the high school. How rumours spread and she goes from being feared by students to being part of the class. It takes the whole 25 episodes to see a year in her life and it really feels like the year was important since each episode focuses on events that really impacted her.


ART:


The art is a bit older style but like I said the change in style when (mostly Sawako) gets confused is really funny and adds to the effect. Making her seem scary and then smiling and looking cute adds a lot of depth to the main character.

This show was frustrating because it could've been so good but the main character was so annoying.
Sawako is the most frustrating character I've ever encountered. Her voice is so breathy and plaintive,  she is constantly questioning her actions, she's a coward, and she doesn't learn from her mistakes and she is ALWAYS in the middle of some verbal miscommunication. Overall, I couldn't stand her and that's why I stopped watching in the middle of Season 2. I thought she would change and grow as a character... which she didn't really do. The characters around her grew and pushed her, but she was annoyingly stagnant.There were a few times she made me laugh, but mostly, I wanted to slap her lol.


I tried so hard to give this show a chance, watching all of season 1 and everything because the other characters are amazing. It made me even more frustrated that I was so interested in the side stories but whenever things focused on Sawako (which is most of the show, because she's the main character lol), I wanted to skip through those scenes. I liked Kazehaya a lot, but he was a saint because I could not stand Sawako and I don't know how he could.


This is such a rant against her, but I've never so strongly hated a character before so here I am leaving this review. If there is ever a dub, maybe have a voice actress who isn't so breathy and stuttering and unsure would greatly help her character.


Otherwise, the art, the music, and the characters were great. Anything that involved Sawako wasn't.

I’ll start off by saying that I believe this anime is concidered to be more than it is…  that doesn’t make it bad, but it means that it certainly isn’t a masterpiece either. Despite that, I felt nice watching it without being too hyper about it though. I can think of some other anime that deserve to be as highly scored as this and they aren’t...
In any case let’s begin with the… 
Story – 7
The story at first glance looks quite unique, with Sawako being treated as an outcast because of her scary demeanor. It starts out funny and interestingly. But after just afew episodes it begins to feel repetitive in the sense that a lot of incidents happen over and over again. Same approaches, same reactions, same outcomes. And I just happened to realize that once again there they were, lying behind the surface… the usual things that characterize any other typical shoujo anime. And since I’m not a big fan of the kind, I can’t say it was a happy sursprise. Nevertheless it had some good moments which I enjoyed and it definitely gave out a cute and innocent feeling, reminding me a little of my high school years.


Characters – 7

I wasn’t a big fan of Sawako. I liked her innocent and kind nature, but I found that it went to extremes. She was too innocent and too kind for her own good, and that felt not only annoying but also a little bit “fake”. Especially those “crying” moments were unbearable! My favorite characters where Chizuru, Ayane and Ryuu, for they felt more real. Also I almost pitied the poor guy Kazehaya who gave so many “openings” and hints to Sawako but it was like knocking on a deaf person’s door. It was nice and lovely in the first few episodes but after a while it became somewhat irritating.


Sound – 8

It’s nice and peaceful, the opening and ending themes are really beautiful to hear and watch. Especially the ending is one of my very favorites.


Art – 8

The pastel colors were what first caught my eye. They are so soft and compose some really beautiful scenes. The characters are well drawn, not top notch, but truly nice.


Enjoyment – 7

I would be lying if I said I didn’t enjoy watching this at all. It was good for my free time and it left me with a sweet feeling. I wasn’t at the edge of my seat watching it, although I caught myself being drawn to the story lots of times.


If you want something light and relaxing to watch in your free time, then this is definitely for you. It is a nice work to remind you of the years of sweet innocence back at school with your first love, how it all felt.

So,
this is how I rated it overall. You might not agree with me since this show has an 8.30 rating on MAL but this is my review so un-helpful away.
Includes, both season one and two review.
Story-6/10 (Cliche story)
Art-6/10 (tooo much chibi)
Sound-8/10 (pretty catchy, different, good)
Characterization-6/10 (started out as good and unique but ended up as irritating and un-relatable)
Enjoyment-6/10 (some moments were so retarded that they were funny )
Overall-5/10
If this world was a cotton candied, sugar coated fluff ball then this anime being categorized as *slice of life* would have been justified. 
To be honest, the only reason I started watching this was because I ama sucker for anti-social characters.\n
When I read the plot base for this anime, I thought it was quite unique.\n
An anime tackling issues about the superficial, an anime in which there is a not so pretty girl, ostracized because she looks like the character from the ring. Oh, how original!\n
However\n
Unrealistic and unrelatable: Kimi ni Todoke hardly handled this unique topic in a unique way, instead it gave the clichéd shoujo spin to it and ended the series in the most basic *girl gets guy* manner.\n
The plot is that Sawako is a teenager suffering from being labelled unapproachable. With long dark hair and pale skin, she is compared to the evil girl from the ring, due to the almost always, gloomy look in her eyes. Thus, everyone calls her Sadako.\n
The present author himself was very unpopular in High School and tries to speak for all cast outs through this series. Except that Sawako is a very exaggerated version of your average *nice person* she gushes with gratitude for anyone who is nice or civil to her, buys them presents and bakes them cookies making her  more of a Disney character who is naive, innocent and desperate to make friends than actual person.\n
Sawako is prevented from being a pathetic, pitiable character by her endless optimism and willingness to help others. She doesn't spend time feeling sorry for herself, nor have her isolation and the often cruel treatment of her classmates made her bitter. She is unfailingly generous with her time and her understanding of their school work.\n
This little note is the thing that makes Sawako so frustrating. Here, is a person who has always been labelled and misunderstood, who’s always been a castaway just because of her appearance. A person who has always been a loner and has never gotten a chance to make any friends, when things like this happen it’s natural to feel resentment, jealousy and anger.\n
However, Sawako lacks all of these natural emotions and this is what makes her a flat, one dimensional character. Not once does she break down, not once does she feel frustrated about her situation. We don’t see that side of her, nor are we aware of its existence. This marks this series as unsatisfying and incomplete as well as lacking in depth.\n
[Btw she's voiced by Mamiko Noto, big surprise! since she has made a career of doing these sweet-but-wimpy kinds of characters (Shimako in Maria Watches Over Us, Rimone in Simoun)]\n
While, Kazehaya is consistently a nice guy, aiming at Sawako only, even though the whole school is heads over heels in love with him. He chooses Sawako because she looks depressed and stands out. Since, he's the kind of guy who likes to see everyone happy and help them if they aren't.\n
Sawako thinks the same, and takes all his advances to be *just kindness* \n
At this point we see how because of this, a huge communication gap between Sawako and Kazehaya is shaped, which in the end consumes unnecessary episodes and the storyline lags continuously until the point that confessions are shouted out and wounds are healed. Except, the wounds that were inflicted on me, while I was watching this terrible series.\n
Kazehaya’s character is just as flawed as Sawako’s. For a series that’s about the high school years of a bunch of people, Sawako and Kazehaya don’t really feel like interesting characters at all. Sawako is way too pure: whenever someone tries to take advantage of her feelings (by making her jealous for example), her incredible naivety just feels incredibly unnatural and it quickly turns into a bit of a lame gimmick. Kazehaya on the other hand is just as bland as a male romantic interest. He’s just… there, with hardly any personality about him other than some guy who just keeps smiling. I mean we all want to be believe that there’s a fictional guy out there who doesn’t care about your looks and your inborn awkwardness, and loves you for who you are. Who will obviously knock off the prettiest girl and choose you, instead. Who’s not superficial; and doesn’t care about what other people think. Even though he’s the most popular boy in school, cool story bro but no. Not to mention that Kazehaya has liked Sawako for some time now, ever since school started to be precise. However, he does not communicate with her until he hears her compliment him. (Narcissistic much eh, Heaney?) \n
Meanwhile, any scene that focused on Sawako’s growth as a character was overshadowed by its romantic drivel that refused to go anywhere.\n
Another set of characters worth mentioning are Sawako’s two friends who become her best girl-pals (and her protectors), Chizuru Yoshida and Ayane Yano. Chizuru is your standard-issue aggressive female. Ayane, on the other hand, I found much more intriguing; in this first half of the season there's just one hint- in a phone call she answers- that her personal life might be rather complex. She's also pretty perceptive, and catches on to something about a character that no one else has realized just yet. Another character I really did like is Ryu, Kazehaya's buddy, a taciturn fellow who's terrible at remembering names. He and Chizuru have something going on, but she, at least, is not ready to admit they have any kind of relationship (though she apparently feels comfortable enough with him to casually invite herself and her friends up to his room, which is above the restaurant he works in.)\n
Apart from Sawako, who as I’ve said feels heavily exaggerated, the others feel real. Not terribly over the top and I think reactions and actions were all pretty ‘normal’, normal enough that it’s believable. And I think because of that sometimes you become more attached to them more than Sawako. Even when rumors about them start flying around, they are in conflict whether it’s Sawako who’s spreading them or not. Though in the real world girls tend to get revenge straight out instead of sticking around long enough to hear the other side of the story, which by the way Sawako doesn’t provide until the very end. \n
As for the bad characters, there's a coach who's the requisite Annoying Male, and then there's the chief villainess, the two-faced Ume Kurumizawa, who pretends to be friendly and cheerful while quietly manipulating things behind the scenes to suit her own purposes.\n
Kurumi, for me was one of the more realistic characters, however she too is overshadowed by Sawako’s fluff and whimsically placed aside. Kurumi is one of the prettiest girls in the school, who is also in love with Kazehaya. She sees Sawako as a rival and tries to break them apart, as forcefully as she can. \n
Sawako’s reaction to this news is so undeniably idealistic that it almost made me laugh. Sawako thinks that because Kurumi shares the same feelings for Kazehaya as she, it will enable them to become better friends and bond over it. Showing us, yet again that Sawako contains absolutely no X chromosomes.\n
Besides Sawako's personality, the art is the other major problem the series has. The backgrounds are gorgeous, but the characters often aren't. Sawako herself seems to be rendered in simplified SD form over half the time. Chizuru and Ayane are realistically done a very few times in the show, but are mostly rendered much closer to SD as well, when they aren't actually SD. But Kazehaya, Ryu, and Kurumizawa receive much more consistently realistic renderings, for some reason.\n
Also, the random light flares and bubbles appearing suddenly almost turned me into a diabetic. Not only does it give it a very kiddy feel to the show, but it also makes it very hard to read the expressions of the characters. Usually they’re used with stylistic purposes; you know, color each character with these seemingly over the top reactions. Here however, they felt more like “Okay, you can laugh now”-signs, this show just continuously tried to be subtle, while it ultimately just wasn’t.\n
Kimi ni Todeke ultimately is an anime, that is meant to make you feel good, warm and fuzzy on the inside. It’s supposed to make you feel happy and motivate you to become a better person. It revolves around the idea that no matter what, there’s always some good in everyone.\n
Except, holy fuck it isn’t. Wake up, you little shit.\n

It's a little hard for me to describe how I exactly felt about Kimi ni todoke, but I'll do my best.
When I started watching it, it was really peaceful and calm. Bad things did happen, but they got cleared up in the easiest ways. Characters got known more and more, and I liked them more and more. Sawako, Kazehaya, Ryuu, Ayane and Chizu were all very interesting,and sometimes odd, characters.
But as the story continued, it became "too" peaceful for my taste. I like a hint of action, drama, something to make me worked up! And well, Kimi ni todoke lacked that. Yes, It was real.But at some points, I was trying too hard to stay in the "real" track that it got kinda annoying! 


In general, this anime's strongest point in my opinion, were the characters. Specially the supporting ones! I Loved them all!


I apologize to all the fans, but this is how I felt :">

This is one of my favorite animes of all time. It is absolutely phenomenal from the get go. I will keep this completely SPOILER FREE for the sake of not ruining a brilliant anime. Here, I'll break it down for you:
Story:
Enriching. Inspiring. Heartbreaking. Emotional. Optimistic. Endearing. This story was so addicting and so incredibly attaching that I could not stop myself from watching episode after episode after episode. Each episode had me on the edge of my seat, rooting for Sawako, and anticipating what was going to happen next in her life and progress. I will not expand more to keep this a truly spoilerfree review but this is an absolutely beautiful story. 10/10\n
Art:\n
The art is stunning. Each character design carefully planned and constructed and the colors completely appropriate and hooking. There were no holes in the animation, no strange spots where you were like "why does this look so different from everything else", no second questions. Absolutely beautiful. The scene with Kazehaya and Sawako under the sakura tree and the road to school is one of the most beautiful anime scenes I have seen confirming my decision to score this a 10/10.\n
Sound:\n
I find myself listening to the anime soundtrack at random points of the day. Like the storyline, it is endearing and completely relevant to the story. The music truly heightens emotion at the most happy and heartwrenching moments. Stellar, absolutely stellar. 10/10\n
Character:\n
Sawako is one of the most endearing characters I have ever watched in my life. I loved her story and seeing her progress to the path of making friends, accepting who she is, and falling in love. Each character is completely individualistic and unique and given all of the personality and likeability (and screentime) to boot. Kazehaya is not our typical popular schoolboy and I truly love that different perspective. It's refreshing. Fantastic character development and fantastic timeline for that development. 10/10.\n
Enjoyment:\n
I have rewatched this anime multiple times and it still never gets old for me. Everything about it is brilliant, likeable, relatable, and realistic. It is such a fantastic watch for anyone of any age. I never got bored in the anime, never got tired of it, and never stopped watching it. I laughed out loud at some moments, jumped for joy at some, and cried at others. It is an emotional rollercoaster that you want to ride and ride again. 10/10.\n
Overall:\n
An endearing character, perfectly developed side characters, your "out of the norm" love story, beautiful art and soundtrack, and complete and utter enjoyability. This is a masterpiece of an anime that I can honestly say no bad thing about. To not watch this would be an absolutely terrible decision, truly. 10/10.

I found Kimi Ni Todoke quite "boring" and not worth to watch it. Let me explain why...
Story: 5
Well the story seemed quite fine to me. Just the normal stuff: shy, weird girl is falling in love with the cool guy. Moreover he falls in love with her too, which was quite unusual at the beginning...I was expecting a romance but what I got was just a quite ordinary story about school, friends, food, being shy blahblah... Stuff that maybe 10-13 years old girls would love to watch. I just felt old while watching this show (haha back then I was 17-18 ). The point isthat the two main characters actually do LOVE each other but what happens? NOTHING AT ALL, and I hate that! This made me just ANGRY. Episode after Episode there was no improvement at all, sure there were some sweet moments but that's all. I won't say much about that because I don't want to write a spoiler like others do..


Art: 8

The art was pretty good, I really like this kind of art in Animes. The only thing that was annoying me was the way too often use of chibis!


Sound: I didn't like the voice of the main girl Sadako, I just didn't can't explain why. The OP and the ED were not my style either so I just never really watched them..


Character: 6

The characters were all individual and fun. BUT yes there is always a BUT.. I just couldn't feel myself in their situations. I just COULDN'T cry with Sadako (the main character). For me she was rather annoying with her way of being. She was just too shy to actually say what she was thinking and of course she improved after a few Episodes but NOT REALLY MUCH! The other guy (the one she likes) should be actually quite the opposite of her but the more I was watching the Anime, the more I felt like they were both idiots that just couldn't say what they were feeling for each other! All this took us 25 Episodes and for me and maybe it was just for me, but I had the feeling that NOTHING, really NOTHING happend between the two main characters at all! Like I said before they had some sweet moments and all but for me this wasn't enough. So to say..the whole Anime they were trying to find a way to be together but at the end they..ah well . let's stop here.


Enjoyment: 6

There were some fun scenes and I highly recommend it if you want to laugh but as I said for me there was just no climax...


Overall: 5

I don't want to watch the second season and I'm tired of shows where the people are too shy, too weak and not self confident at all... I won't recommend it as a love story but maybe as a comedy after all it had some fun moments and sweet moments but that's it...

Normally, I tend to avoid shojo anime at all costs. Don't get me wrong, I'm a huge Shojo fan but too often I watch an anime that seems interesting only to wind up with the same reused plot over and over again.
Kimi ni Todoke at a first glance appears to have that all-too-familiar "unpopular girl falls for popular boy" plot. Matter of fact, that's exactly what it is. However, Kimi ni Todoke manages to take the same plot and turn it into something incredible fresh and enjoyable.
The characters are instantly likable and they are the ones that draw you into the story despite it's simplicity.Everyday occurrences are presented in such a charming way that  you can't help but simply go along with the flow of the anime, which, admittedly is slow-paced but you'll never be bothered by it.


The relationships and the character interactions never seem fake or cheesy and it has a soothing soundtrack to boot.


The animation is gorgeous even though it can sometimes be a little over-sparkly but it fits in with everything as a whole 


Even if you're sick of plots like these (and trust me, sometimes I am) Watching Kimi ni Todoke won't make you regret it ^^

While I enjoy romance anime, and while I'm new to the scene, Kimi ni Todoke really didn't hit any marks for me. I thought I would enjoy it, but after watching 13 episodes I've realised that I'm just simply waisting my continuing as it becomes incredibly frustrating to watch, as I'll go into more detail below.
The series first starts off innocent enough, with the main character being somewhat quirky and awkward. As the series progresses the viewer begins to realise that not only is she awkward, quiet, quirky, etc. She's simply socially retarded. She doesn't have basic social skills. Its like watching a five yearold try to hold a conversation. At the thirteenth episode, I really couldn't be bothered to deal with the show anymore. The situations that she gets herself into are frustrating and easily avoidable. Most of the drama that happens in this is stupid high school bullshit anyway.


Without character flaws and their journey to overcome them, how can there be character development? While Sadako or Sawako's flaws are obvious, it doesn't seem that the point of the show is to fix them. She's still socially inept, incredibly awkward, and frustrating to watch and it doesn't seem like she'll change. When a character in the show says, "Shut up, you're annoying" to the main protagonist who you spend most of the show watching and you agree with them, I think there's a big problem.


The voice actor feels very forced, as she is trying to produce a weird airy, high pitched voice. Its obvious that it's forced, and it becomes annoying.


Didn't enjoy it for the time that it had, but I guess I'm in the minority here, aren't I?

I'll try my hardest not to spoil this show. I'll also try to give you a reasonable, well debated and in depth analysis as to why this show is freaking AMAZING.
Story - 10
The story of a girl learning about the world of love and school life, one which she should've learnt a few years ago, is an underplayed plot. While not entirely unique, and not always pulled off with class, Kimi revives this concept with new breath. There's not much more to say other than it's like watching playground politics; 5 year olds learning about interaction for the first time.
Art - 10
Kimi ni Todoke andan animation and artistic paradise.

The art style, pulled directly from the manga, in no way pulls from the true characters, nor the story. One of the few shows currently airing that's not trying to sell it's self by looking good, Kimi visually portrays each character as they're initially percived, allowing the story and developments to help the viewer see them in a different manner. Be it Yano-chi's gyaru lips or Chizu's delinquent eyes or Sawakos...looking like freaking Sadako. I adore this manner of portraying characters.

The color palet of Kimi is enchanting. The playfull coloring of the op animation, to the simple, light and fluffy colors of the show and the water colored ed help the audience reconise, almost instantly, what this show is. A light hearted romance, that is what it is, and dosn't try to be anything more.


Animation - 10

I tend so see art style and animation as two different things. But that dosn't mean the animation isn't equally as stunning. Currently, in anime, animation is becoming much more advanced. A little less recently, we experienced the delight which was ToraDora. Despite being two very different styles of romance, both anime showcase beautiful animation which fully brings out the emotions of the characters. To really show you this, I would have to sit with people and go through an episode, pausing and disecting. To explain it in words as best as I can, Kimi catches those small mannerisms down to the angle at which people lean when they're just standing there, chatting.

What I love just as much is that they don't take liberties with comedy scenes, which are just as beautifully smooth and carefully animated.


Sound - 10

Not a voice actor out of place, there's nothing unatural about these seiyuus. Given briefly, the famous much loved voice actors steal abosolutly no spotlight from the main characters. Everyone does a lovely job.

I adore the OP and ED songs, which are just as light and fluffy as the show.


Character - 10

So.Damn.Good.

I wont go into depth with Kazehaya or Sawako, rather, I'd like to present Kurumi as my case.

Kururmi is the most amazing character I've seen in a while. Without being bi-polar and all over the place, Kurumi represents the amazing development characters in Kimi under go. Starting confident but alone, thinking she didn't need friends, Kurumi soon reveals herself to be unable to change her path and brakes down, saying thing's she wouldn't want. She soon, although she wont admit it, begins to fully accept someone else as equal to her, Sawako. I have a blog written on her, if you wish to read further on Kurumi and why I adore her.


Enjoyment - 10

Kimi ni Todoke just leaves you smiling. Weather it be a small skit of Sawako learning something new and being over innocent or because everyone comes out alright at the end of an arc, Kimi is hard not to enjoy. For all those who need a brake from shows which force you to rethink everything, Kimi is for you. For all those looking for a good romance, Kimi is for you. For all those who want mecha, guns, fighting and testosterone, watch it anyway.


TL;DR, I love this show, I think you will too

Let me start off by saying that i loved this show.
 It was a funny, cute, heart racing show from start to finish. Sure the story wasn't very original but it was still a fun watch. The characters in this story were outstanding. they all had something extra that i can't quite put my finger on but it draws you in along with the story.
After i watched the first two episodes i was hooked, and when i finished the show i went on to the manga which is a hundred times better than the anime. (but that is just my opinion)
The art in this animealso caught my attention. It kinda reminded me how some of the characters looked in Xxxholic. What i liked most about the art was that it is different from other anime shows. Over the years i as i started to watch more and more anime i noticed that a lot of the art had a similar aspect, but in Kimi ni todoke it felt more original.


I throughly enjoyed the music in this show. I thought they did an excellent job in the openings and endings to this anime. 


Overall this was a very fun watch. Although i wish it could have been longer. but it was funny, cute, romantic, and it just made you think how you first made friends and how close you are to them. 


I highly, highly recommend this anime to watch. If you do i guarantee you won't be disappointed.

The story starts of with Kuronuma Sawako, a young girl that is avoided by everyone due to her appearance, which is quite gloomy or scary. She supposedly can speak to ghosts / see them and if you stare into her eyes for more than 3 seconds misfortune befalls you. These are all rumors and Kuronuma is quite the opposite. She's sweet, kind, and naive. But there was one person who probably saw something in her that everyone else was too blinded by their assumptions to see, Kazehaya Shouta. The popular, handsome boy at school who everyone likes because he's kind and charismatic. But there's moreto him that meets the eye. And because of an encounter between the two, Kuronuma's life starts to change, but for better or worse?


The main theme / moral for this anime is to not judge someone by the appearance. To give someone a fair chance, you know, get to know them. And once you get to know them, you can have more things in common than you could have imagined. This lesson can be applied to real life because something like this happened to me, and I'm sure, everyone.


Moving on.


The pacing isn't very fast. Believe me, I can't recall how many time I screamed at my laptop screen saying: "Why the hell don't they get together already!" But I think the slow pacing is very good, despite my impatience. It gives you a chance to get to really know the characters - seeing them for who they are, being with them through all the obstacles they had to face & seeing their relationships grow.


Speaking of characters . . .


The characters were the best thing of Kimi ni Todoke. By far. They all have their own personalities, whether they be good or bad, you'll still love them regardless. 

For me the characters didn't just play their roles, it felt like something more; all the predicaments, emotions they felt seemed real. Trust me, the first time I watched this, I teared at at so many scenes, whether they were sad, heartwarming, happy, whatever. The voice actors were perfect for each character; main or supporting. They did a great job conveying the characters' feelings, whatever they happened to be.


The art was very good for a shojo anime. I don't really analyze anything because I don't know what I'm supposed to be looking for, but, I know what I like, and I liked this. The animation was good throughout. Oh, I also liked how the characters looked outside their school clothing - very cute and stylish.


The soundtrack was very good. The ost's suited any situation that was happening. The openings & endings fit perfectly with the series; the lyrics as well.


Overall, you should watch this and come to a conclusion yourself. Because its not like I can convey how great an anime it is through words. Whether you like it or not, its up to you, I could careless because I know how wonderful it is and that's all that matters. This is my favorite shojo anime, that I've watched so far.

After getting a recommendation to watch this anime from a few people, I planned on it. From the default picture, it just looks like a regular anime. Nothing special, right? But it is. You find out parts of yourself you've never found before in this anime. I would have never thought I would fall in love with something so simplistic as this. I'll have to say I judged a book by it's cover. Before you try to throw this anime away, watch one episode first.
Story? 10/10.
At first, Kuronuma is outsider in the school. Everyone thinks she can see ghosts and summon spirits, but she's justan ordinary girl. She means a boy named Kazehaya, and he changes her life completely. It may sound regular, but it's totally different from what you're thinking. She never smiles at all, and she's never had real friends, but it was fate that they met.


Art? 10/10.

This is one of the things that drew me away from the anime at first. I looked at the default picture and went, "Ew, this totally isn't kawaii," since it's different from what I usually watch. As the story progressed, I fell more and more in love with this type of art. I suggest that everyone give it a try. It's similar to One Piece.


Sound? 10/10.

I absolutely loved the ending song for Kimi ni Todoke. It's the best in an anime I've seen probably. The lyrics fit the song perfectly, as well as the sound. I enjoyed listening to the ending every time the anime ended. 


Character? 9/10.

The only reason this doesn't have a 10, is because I simply didn't like the misunderstandings that floated around in the story. It pissed me off quite a bit as well when Kanami did what she did, but you'll have to watch and see. Conflicts make the story grow, right?


Enjoyment? 9/10.

I really enjoyed this anime. It made me laugh, cry, smile, and fall in love with all of the characters. Anime like this deserve an award. Slice of Life is my favorite genre of anime, and things like this is why. You'll surely fall in love with this anime.


Overall? 10/10.

I'm not over exaggerating when I say this anime was on the verge of being perfect. Other people might love the conflicts and misunderstandings, but it ruined the mood for me. That being said, the heart felt parts were the best. Everyone who's watched this anime knows how it feels to be Kuronuma, and how it feels to be hurt. They also know the want to be loved and have friends. It's a great feeling when you're happy, and this is exactly the anime that gives you happiness.

To start it off, I didn’t expect Kimi Ni Todoke to be as good as it was. I’ve come across several anime of the same genre, and after a while the “Shoujo” genre feels as if it keeps repeating itself, while adding small changes into the plot. To be completely honest, I started this anime for the heck of it. This series is not that well known, or so I believe, because I’ve never heard anyone else mention it to me before nor have I seen anyone talk about it. I found it through MyAnimeList and decided to watch it considering it had a goodscore. Despite this, I kept it away for a long time ‘cause I wasn’t really interested in the story, but I am really pleased to say that Kimi Ni Todoke went beyond my expectations and provided a really pleasant watch.


The plot isn’t the usual generic narrative you find in your average Shoujo anime or manga. It isn’t a about a girl trying to win the heart of some guy who isn’t interested in her. It isn’t about a harem of girls fighting for one guy who likes the one girl we all know he’s eventually going to end up with. Of course, those types of anime are cute and all, but they lack originality. Kimi Ni Todoke on the other hand is original and cute beyond words and it feels relatable because it’s simply about a girl who’s trying to socialize with her classmates, but she can’t because there has been a rumor about her that says she is the girl from The Ring, Sadako. Her classmates are afraid of her and tend to avoid her despite her charming and pleasant attitude.


 I’m sure most of us have gone through this point in life – just trying to make friends and getting to know people around you. This aspect of the story is so beautifully developed that I couldn’t help but smile whenever the main character, Kuronuma “Sadako” didn’t know how to behave around people due to the lack of interaction she had had, or when she got into an embarrassing situation because of her shy and nervous personality! This is the aspect that appealed to me.


Nothing in Kimi No Todoke seems forced. There are no over-dramatic characters, no troubled and depressed main characters, no bat-shit crazy parents, and no traumatic past for the main character. Yet the story progress effortlessly though its humor and commendable character development.


The characters fit into the story flawlessly. Kuronuma Sawako, who is called Sadako instead due to her resemblance to the girl from the ring is an average high-schooler. Pure and simple, Sawako is really likable. This is portrayed when her two best friends realise she isn’t what the rumors depict her to be and get along with her. They eventually learn that she is actually a really sweet person, with an air of optimism about life unlike what they had previously imagined. Both the characters of Chizu and Amane add to the story as well. Despite being side characters their characters are developed wonderfully as the story progresses. Also, they add diversity the list of characters in Kimi Ni Todoke. Chizu is a tomboy and brusque while Amane is a seductive temptress. You might think that doesn’t sound like they are nice people, but trust me, they make the best pair of friends Kuronuma could have ever asked. Kazehaya, who is secretly in love with Kuronuma, helps her character develop. You wouldn’t like his character because he’s really good looking or has an edgy attitude. You’ll like him because he’s simply that likeable. He’s the guy that everyone wants to be friends with, but that doesn’t make him a prick. All in all, I loved all the characters in the anime.


As for the art, to be honest, I didn’t like it at first and it was one of the reasons I abstained from watching this anime for so long, but trust me, it’ll grow on you after a few episodes. The music wasn’t exceptional but it wasn’t entirely bad either. I never skipped the Opening and the background music was satisfying for me as well.


The only fault I that found within this anime would be its slow pace. Personally, I love anime with a really fast paced story and a lot of drama. Most slow paced anime bore me to death, but the uniqueness of Kimi Ni Todoke was what kept me on board and I’m glad I didn’t stop watching after a few episodes. Despite this minor fault, I am really looking forward to binging season 2 and I hope it doesn’t disappoint.


So, do I recommend watching it? Well, if you like this genre and are bored by the monotonous narratives of other anime from this genre, then sure go ahead and watch it! I’m pretty sure you won’t be disappointed.

General:
Just your normal romance. Not a little bit of surprise. Anime was going so slow, it's a 25 episode anime (season 1). Plot is clear, but story goes slow. Likewise everytime hurdles will come just like in every romance.
Character: 6
Characters are fine, not bad nor good. But something i found quite irritating is that the main character (male) acts like a girl, and he's like a girl inside, which I find quite irritating, like blushing & character development is fine. 
So at the end I think this is your typical romance anime where story is soo slow that you'll fed up, if you're fast paced,like for me it'll be boring to spend time on series where you'll see a boy & girl fell in love, for 25 episode. Instead of that I'll read manga\n\n
Story: 6\n
- story is good no doubt, but there are some laid-backs.\n\n
Enjoyment:- 5\n
- you'll enjoy if you've already watched all good anime & you've no place to go(as for me)\n\n
Overall: 5 \n
It's an ok, ok anime. When i saw its rating & the reviews, I thought it'll be a fantastic anime. But I was disappointed.

“Distances”
The Story... Kimi ni Todoke have an impressive yet typical storyline that revolves about a girl and a guy with unrequited feelings from each other. An essence of romance yet to be seen that is filled with cheesy, laughable, and silly moments of each character involved. It contains a storyline with precise approach of idea that is somewhat predictable yet attractive because of the mood it draws out on each episode. Concerning on being a romantic series, it also have a harmonious approach between characters that gives an additional delight. It is a kind of a love boat trip on where we sit back andenjoy tightly as we see the ups and downs, twists, and memorable scenes it has to offer. The series gives high standards for it to be watched because it didn’t focused only with one aspect which is romance rather it shown such many different emotions for us to be experienced and pleased on. Nevertheless, with its rather amazing storyline the series might give you such wonderful feedback and amusement.


Art & Animation... The series gives such bubbly, fascinating, and lively background that carries the ambiance of the story. By having a clean and detailed art, the sensation of having a romantic and comical scene becomes more appreciative and attractive as it leaves a wonderful mark. For the animation, the scenes is quite typical as its shows as sweet as possible, hilarious than ever, and being emotional than before, but even though it is quite just the same as we’ve seen from the others there are some unique qualities that this series hold which cause the series to truly shine.


Sound... It isn’t that grand as I’ve expected but it contains such breathtaking, refreshing, and tender background sounds that truly sync to the story itself. The series use a low pitch and melodic sound that increases the aura of romance, not to mention to some of the entertaining ones. OP song that gives an angelic and captivating feeling and ED song that gives an adorable and soothing tune. It is just the appropriate sound for its theme that gives the right impact to the overall series.  


Characters… All characters have contributed such major impact to the story that to be considered memorable, a variety of characters that have done a great job on each of their roles. The series have a charming and also a bit disturbing personalities to been seen depending on the roles they’ve performed. The focus might be on these pair of characters that really moves and fascinates the flow of the story being told. Kuronuma which brightens the show, while Kazehaya who complete the essence of the series. It has a scenic progression of their lives that reveals various feelings and outcome to be on one another. An additional detail is by having other characters put such great effort to make the show impressive which also increase the factor of the surroundings and its individual aspect. Regardless of the character representation that is predictable and common, they have just done it in a well manner way that is attractive enough to absorb the essence of the story which is truly amazing.


Enjoyment & Overall… It’s a romantic trip that offers a nice ambiance between the story, interaction of different characters, and laughing moments to enjoy. It’s a ride on where the flow of the story might be simple but has a promising result. It is a kind of anime where backgrounds, animation, sounds or either characters is responsible for being attractive. Being independent without these different aspects may affect the overall outcome and will become just a simple anime. All I can say is that they have managed to do something great from a simple and overly used layout.
