I absolutely loved this anime for so many reasons. It was such a delight to both watch and listen to as well. The animation was just gorgeous, each beautifully colored background painstakingly created to reflect the moods and seasons, a perfect pacing device as well. My favorites were the cherry blossoms in the spring, and the night sky full of twinkling stars, a reminder of our small place within a much larger universe. I don't normally pay attention to music during an anime, but I found the melodic piano pieces used were perfect to encompass the mix of hope, longing, fear and innocence that sooften defines our youth. 


I would say that this whole anime from both a plot and aesthetic perspective drove home this coming-of-age period, where everything is so new and exciting and scary at the same time. 

Saweko is such a great character, you can't help but root for her! I normally like take charge type A-personalities but there is just something so endearing about her earnestness and her desire to be understood that you find yourself cheering every triumph no matter how small. You have to admire her for never being afraid of trying, despite the past rejections, and hurtful experience she still is optimistic and believes that if she does her best, things will work out. Beyond the romance, this is the story of a girl who is just discovering who she is, and is just beginning to understand  the bonds of friendship and love that ties us to those around us. 



I felt the story's emphasis on these small gestures - whether a word or deed to be a powerful reminder in never underestimating the difference you can make on another person's life with such a seemingly simple act. From Kazehaya's kindness in giving Saweko a shot, to hurtful rumors and misunderstandings the ripple effects are felt during the entire series. 


I really loved the friendships formed by Saweko, the way she slowly realized what it means to make friends, and become part of a group who accepted her for her she was. Not only that but they truly cared about her happiness and did everything they could to help, while pushing her to take chances while always letting her take things at her own pace. I found Ayane to be especially wonderful, one of my favorite friend characters to date. Pin - the crazy homeroom teacher was also hilarious, I really loved the scenes he was in, they made me laugh out loud. 


The romance that develops is slow and sweet, each moment of intimacy and trust building on each other. It's nice to see two nice people circle each other, in a courtship that was based in trust and respect. To truly be seen by another, that's really the best we can all hope for. 


The one downside was at times I did grow a little impatient with the misunderstandings (CONFESS ALREADY), but at the end it was worth it. I loved watching this little group's high-school journey progress and felt an attachment to them that makes me think this is one Anime I'll be rewatching soon. 


I should note as well, that while the ending is a little unresolved, that there is a second season that ties everything up nicely, so don't be discouraged.

Okay so first off, yes this is my all time favourite.
Okay now we got that out of the way. This anime is one of the main reasons I started watching romance anime.
The story starts rather simple but it builds up really nicely. The characters are well developed, obviously Sawako and Kazehaya more than the others but it is notable that there is actual character development in the side characters, which I, find absolutely fantastic.
The art in this Anime is really well done and quite true to the manga (yeah I'm currently collecting the manga as well because I can't have enough), not a single animedoes the art as well as this one. Though there is Chihayafuru which is pretty close but gives it's own twist to it.\n
For people that don't like long and dreadful romance animes I say, please give this one another chance. And yes I must admit the anime is (as I heard someone say) a 30 episode love letter, but honestly it does it in such a nice way that you are always eager to see the next episode.\n\n
I've currently seen the series 3 times. But don't take my word for it, just go out there and watch it and the second season.

I didn't really expected that this Anime will have such an influence on me, it was such a great series, and i am really sad because it's already over. 
I wish it could have more episodes, and in the same time i don't really want it, maybe it would ruin the anime, because I think it's perfectly fine the way it is now.
Story: 10/10
Yep, I'm giving the story a complete 10, it was a masterpiece for me, not because the story was unique or because it was "awesome", it's because the story had such an great influence on me, i was totally fascinated by itand i couldn't stop myself to watch the entire series in 2 days. I was so happy, sad, depressed and full of all kind of emotions just by watching these 25 episodes. Maybe it's also because i saw myself in this anime a bit too, but i'm not really sure about that, could be.

In this Anime you see how a beautiful person should be, how a beautiful person sees the world, how a beautiful person acts and talks to other people, how a beautiful person cheerful is and how a beautiful person LOVES. This anime shows how we should be, how we should act and care about others...it shows how to LIVE and LOVE.


Characters: 10/10


Totally adorable characters, lovely ones, cheerful ones, sad ones, broken ones, and closed ones. All these characters together in one place made this anime even greater.

I loved them all.


Music: 9/10


Ah, the music was really touching, the opening was nice, the ending was awesome, and the in anime music was really beautiful. It really fits with the story


Animation: 9/10


The animation wasn't really that great like the story or the characters are, but there were some parts in the anime where you could see how beautiful they show something, and that's 

why i liked the animation really much ^^




For everyone who loves to watch a love story, watch this...u won't regret it for sure

Kimi ni todoke is a shoujo anime that is sweet and touching.
Story-  a typical shoujo with a popular male and an ordinary female protagonist, its love story is typical but rather than fast progression of its love story, it is slow and quite realistic for a budding romance. 
Art- The art is very shoujo but i like the watercolor palette used that makes it soft to look at. The character's design is simple but complements the character's personality such as sawako's shyness and kazehaya's gentle character.
Sound- The anime Op and Ed complements the anime although it is not special or breathtaking. The VA alsofits the characters.\n\n
Characters- I like all the characters in this anime because I can relate with them especially with Sawako. I also like that character's development as the series go along which especially can be seen with Sawako. \n\n\n
Overall- I enjoyed it the anime for its slow pacing and realistic build up of the relationship of the main characters but also their interactions with the supporting cast.

The premise of Kimi Ni Todoke is quite simple; The story of a girl named Sawako living deleted at his school to have the appearance like the girl from the movie "The so-called" once your name is the victim of a pun "Sadako". Sawako is a sweet and intelligent girl, always with the motto to practice at least one good deed a day, and his attempts to help people only hinders further because for a mere details it causes dread in their peers and teachers. Inside the room everyone thinks she can talk to spirits and to evoke them, which causes very funny situations. Thisis the life of Sawako, a pretty girl, intelligent practicing at least one good deed every day and is mistaken for an evocative of Satan.


Everything changes when appears Kazehaya and Sawako draws the attention of the school. Kazehaya is a perfect human being and this is the downside more pointed by those who read the manga or watch anime, but it is perfect from the point of view of Sawako, ie, is presented to us how she sees the Kazehaya. In my opinion this view has to change in the manga course not to get extremely repetitive and get seasick easily.


From all this history shows a novel surrounded by situations ranging of the funniest, the most consistent and sentimental dramas. Still relying on charismatic characters add in a lot in the work quality.


Kimi Ni Todoke is a great Shoujo anime with a beautiful art to look at and a story that will develop slowly, but improving more and holding the viewer. More than recommended.

This anime is worth the love. And I mean really, I ended up writing a review about it. It's one thing to say that I like this certain anime because of the following objective-to-subjective reasons, but it's something that is surprising for me to actually find an anime to "love" at.
STORY = 7
The story is of course, romance-esque. Shoujo-ish and all, preferrably not my cup of tea. The story itself is mild and has a basic plot, it's nowhere near as tense like Shingeki no Kyojin, not as close to laughing as the wacky Yuru Yuri, and even CLAMP's romance anime have more twists andturns than this. The story is as basic as what to do with a teaspoon: a shy, awkward, unpopular girl easily misunderstood because of her looks and introversion, with a running joke of being quite the resemblance of The Ring's Sadako, and on the other side is a "gary-stu" guy who is seemingly perfect in a lot of ways that everyone loves him, then add up a tandem of supporting characters who are not really all that dynamic yet been able to make some impact on the plot, and yet this story has worked like having that cup of tea with the right cake.

In literature, we're particularly taught of what not to write. And this anime kind of ticked all those boxes BUT despite its elements as non-applicable to real life as we know how twisted the reality of our society is, Kimi ni Todoke just handed back all things literature taught to the butler who brought the tea and cake, and simply went on with its own ingredients; a creation a mild and touching, easy-to-watch shoujo-story with feels. In reality, no guy can act like Kazehaya, and only few friends out there can be like Chi-chan and Yano-chin and Ryu as well; and if you act like Kurunama you'd probably be the bully-magnet;

and I could still go on with hampering reality from this ideal romantic story, but being ideal and mild as it is, that's what makes the storyline as captivating and even sublime.

It's just so unreal you'd wish it real. Kimi ni Todoke simply gave us a glimpse of an ideal love story as what it should be, full of laidbacks and awkward fleeting emotional heartbeat-skipping fidgets, yes, it's a love story after all.



ART = 10


When I watch anime, I'm not really particular about the art because being particular at it is like being particular at what box your mind wants to be comfortably snuggled in. But I never stay inside the box. Never.



CHARACTER = 8


Back in 2009, there was a hideous American mushy-mushy so-called love-story that gagged the entire vampire lore into a cheap, nasty vomitus.

Its proponent was the use of a silly romantic (romatic, as how its author wanted to put it, but tbh it's not romantic: it's bullshit) setting and mary-sue + gary-stu characters, where the author claimed she knows nothing about vampires among other hideous claims, but in the eyes of the mainstream, that story worked to their fandom (and this is one of the major-major reasons never to trust mainstream).

Kimi ni Todoke then, which was made in 2008, kind of used the same mary-sue + gary-stu characterization: an ideal pair, ideal setting, ideal supporting characters, ideal plot, but it's far from barfing to what it offered acidic to the stomach. Kimi ni Todoke is actually sweet, and actually right in mixture of ideal plot and character elements. It isn't acidic to you sitting in front of the screen and doesn't make you puke and roll your eyes like how Mokocchi did. You just simply cheer for Kurunama and Kazehaya with giggles and feels.

American-made vampire story has nothing on this, this is how Japanese love story makes it.



SOUND = 9


Full respect to Mamiko Noto on this one. She fully asserted and gave Kurunama Sawako the 100% life she needed. And this is one of the fewest anime where I can decipher (and yes you don't need forensics to sense that out) that even the seiyuus were having fun doing the voicing; for example, Miyuki Sawashiro is at her natural best as Yano-chin, and also is Yuuko Sanpei as Yano-chin; EVEN Aya Hirano as Kurumi-chan can't hide her natural voice on this.

As for the music, I'm not a fan of either the opening and ending songs but I don't think I can ask for anything better.



ENJOYMENT = 10


It's not that difficult to rate it at 10. I mean, I wouldn't even be writing this long if I haven't enjoyed it. There are romantic anime out there like Tsubasa Chronicles, One Week Friend, Kannazuki no Miko (okay this is shoujo-ai), Waiting in the Summer, Clannad, and the list goes on, but Kimi ni Todoke is juz special.



OVERALL = 9


I can't believe a time will come when I've watched a shoujo anime and be able to genuinely rate it at NINE. I originally wanted to rate it as EIGHT (around 7.5 if only MAL wills it), but I can't; because it feels too understated to put an 8 rating to it.

But not to worry, I'm about to watch the 2nd season so maybe, just maybe I'd fetch the 10-rating there.

Kimi ni Todoke is just brilliant. It's like how Bruce Lee quoted "Simplicity is the key to brilliance".

It's like if we're comparing (analogy) cars, the American-made vampire story is like that silly but famous DeLorean which is a very flawed car in real-life but reeks of Hollywood thanks to its fictional time-traveling alter-ego. But Kimi ni Todoke, being an awesome sublime Japanese car--this is a Lexus, the Lexus LFA. It just went on from being simple, idealistic, unrealistic little shoujo story to being a love story you can perfectly love at all thanks to its right touches, and the right delivery of characters (and the right seiyuus---but okay, that's a personal opinion) in a plot that was meant to be wrong in every literature sense. And this is what you get: a shoujo love story worth the watch (and love).


Verdict: Kimi ni Todoke is just like how Lexus was idealistic to their LFA, and it worked.

First of all, what's a good show? Well, for me a good show, anime or not, should be able to create its own structures, establish a relation of empathy with the viewer and give an important contribution for the world, as critical or acritical portrait of something. Some shows develop in the field of fantasy, but are able to create parallels with modern day life. 
   Kimi Ni Todoke is not only a good show. Is an almost perfect show. I'm not a person who gives a 10 rating easily, but I couldn't say no to this particular anime. Why?I'll tell you!


STORY:

   The best plots are, sometimes, based on conceptual nihilism, and Kimi Ni Todoke is a perfect example of that. In the tradition of the shoujo genre, this anime's action takes place in nowadays Japan, within a 10th Grade class. Sawako is a student that can't fit in the social groups that surround her, and she is most times misinterpretated and thought to have supernatural habilities. 

   The pacing, developing and inteligent cliffhangers really brought something extra to it. There's also, I think, a bit of reality distortion according to Sawako's point of view, as in the personality of Kazehaya, that could be some sort of japanese Jesus Christ. 


ART:

   The somewhat alternative styling in characters and the watercolour based cenarios are magical, and really push you deeper into the world of Kimi Ni Todoke. Also, the use of chibi and exageration of expressions, such as in Kare Kano, will help you create a relation of empathy with the characters and feel some nostalgia while watching scenes that remind you of your school days. 


SOUND:

  Both opening and ending song are excelent, not my kind of music, but the right one for Kimi Ni Todoke. The in-show music is also good, sometimes with piano or guitar versions of the OP and END songs. I pretty much enjoyed all the toons for relaxed/comical moments. 


CHARACTER:

   This is the really trump card of Kimi Ni Todoke. 

   Sawako is a perfect character at all levels. Her reactions and unability to socialize and the evolution suffered after meeting her friends, Chizu and Yano, are very reasonable and realistic. She is the anime girl you will fall in love easily. 

   Chizu and Yano are the counter-balances of Sawako, and they are responsible for her evolution as a social person.

   Actually Kazehaya is the first responsible for that, but only further will he have a more important role within Sawako's life, although he is, basicly, the object of her motivations.

   It is the realism and affectivity related to the characters that make Kimi Ni Todoke an awesome and kawaii show. 


ENJOYMENT:

   So, in conclusion, I loved Kimi Ni Todoke, and is a pleasure for me to review it and recommend it to you. 


STORY: 9

ART: 10

SOUND: 9

CHARACTER: 10

ENJOYMENT: 10

OVERALL: 10

This is the best anime romance I have ever watched. It's sweet, simple, and no ecchi. The art is very colorful, I personally love it. The characters are developed very well, and are hilarious. The only bad thing about this anime is that sometimes it is so annoying I can hardly stand it. However, these moments don't last too long. Also, both series don't have a very satisfying ending. Also, the story actually does not seem like a romance till much later.
Overall, this is an awesome show to watch, very worth it! ;-D

け に 届 け - Kimi ni Todoke is an enchanting but timid love story. The slice of life combines the typical school life of the protagonist, which is characterized by prejudice and exclusion, with a very tender love story. In order to ensure that the character portrayal and the topics addressed do not superimpose the romanticism, there are some nice side stories that compensate this with comedy.
Story: very slow but believable with a lot of depth (8/10) 
The initially closed emotional world of Kuronuma Sawako is awakened, and slightly expanded with each episode. One could criticize that the romanticism compared to the comedy sometimesseems a bit pale due to the shyness of the protagonists. I found the slow but credible emotional development as a fitting counterpart to the comedy. 


Characters: genre-typical but aptly presented (8/10) 

The cast is a well-known but successful mix of genre-typical and on the other hand, very different characters. Amusingly, protagonists have more in common than it seems at first glance.


*The description of the characters may include spoilers, so better watch the anime first.* 


Kuronuma Sawako:

Krunoma 黒沼(= black | swamp), the Kanji leave no doubt, Sawako-san is an outsider. Long, pitch-black hair, an insecure voice, a restrained nature as well a doll-like appearance make her ghostly and scary in the eyes of her classmates. If she bows her head out of shyness so that her pony covers the eye area, then that sight sends icy shivers down the spine of her classmates. The rumour mill does the rest. Completely isolated, her shy attempts to reach someone beyond this wall only make it worse. The allusion to Yamamura "Sadako" from the horror novel trilogy The Ring (リング ) by Suzuki Kôji (鈴木 光司) is not a compliment. The novels are based on Japanese mythology in the form of an Onryô (怨霊), a spirit that seeks revenge. The leitmotif of the underdog who falls in love with School-Beau is not new, but much emphasis has been placed on the development of feelings as well as the resulting difficulties and doubts that one could have as a socially shunned person. Kuronuma Sawako is a lovely, very sensitive character. Her altruistic way of acting and thinking is perceived as strange. The beauty of her personality is hardly noticed by anyone. The title Kimi ni todoke "Reaching You" hits the nail on the head. To reach someone beyond the wall of misunderstandings, superficiality and prejudices in the hope of gaining friendship and affection. Admirable, as she tries every day to clarify the misunderstandings. If the plot seems too slow or even cheesy, you should skip the anime.

Kazehaya Shouta:

He is always the center of attention and self-confident in dealing with others. Only Sawako's sensitive nature disarms his coolness. He seems clumsy, emotional and always a little jealous. He is thoroughly honest, does not hide his emotions but does not find the right words. The similarity of the protagonists in this point makes up a large part of the charm of the anime.

Yano Ayane:

She is strong-willed, smart, pretty and has the gift of gab. The rumor mill does not credit her with the best reputation, but unlike Sawako, she knows how to defend herself. She does not take everyone into her heart, but whoever finds a place there has a strong and helpful friend.

Yoshida Chizuru:

Quick-tempered, energetic, direct and super emotional. That makes her adorable and with her impulsive, lively nature she always provides for action.

Sanada Ryu:

I like his good-natured and relaxed manner. Because of its silent nature, his few words bring the interlocutors to the right idea.

Kurumizawa Ume:

Pretty, cute, popular, a real crush for boys at Kitahoro High School. But the little sweetheart is a sly old dog with a trunk full of tricks and keep an eye on a certain boy. I found her development well illustrated and in the end surprising.


*spoiler alert end*


Visuals: Drawings unusual, simple but nice and creating the right atmosphere (8/10)

Shiina Karuho's drawing style is certainly not everyone's cup of tea. However, it's the simple depiction that underlines the expression and places it in the foreground as an essential element. Very well done, because with regard to the manga, especially in the close-ups, you can see that Shiina-san has drawn beautiful and emotional pictures. The eye area of Sawako, for example, has an endearing pen stroke that makes her eyes special. I particularly liked the fact that the reduction emphasizes the intensities of the scenes. On the other hand, the skillful use of soft pastel colours and soft focus effects are friendly and cordial to the viewer. The anime adaptation has the same dreamy, friendly image design as the manga, the presentation is very reminiscent of the style of the French Impressionists and is also well comparable with watercolors. In Combination with a decent animation, the realization successfully implement the same great atmosphere and the beautiful image design of the manga is reflected in the anime. A very special and beautiful example is when Sawako-san speaks to Shouta-kun for the first time. Even if I`m not really a fan of chibi or super deforming, but in combination with the comedy and slapstick elements, it is in balance with the emotional plot.


Music: lovingly accompanying the mood, but hardly any peculiarity, except the ED (7/10)

The background music is from the instrumental formation S.E.N.S (sound, earth, nature, spirit). The Arrangements like "Aozora", "Arigatou" or "Hohoemi" have a really nice sound and provide a multifaceted acoustic pleasure that almost fondly accompanies the scenes.

The OP Kimi ni Todoke is a light, gentle J-Pop intro and is sung by Tanizawa Tomofumi. The somewhat unusual and slightly nasal-sounding voice, the cheerful music with matching lyrics, puts the audience in the right mood for the anime. The animation of the OP is tactfully appropriate, simple but very charming, the mostly female audience is addressed well, without being too cheesy and frightening the guys completely.

The ED Kataomoi is an alternative J-Pop song and is sung by Chara (Watabiki Miwa). Her voice is super shrill and oddly special, but with alternative rock songs like "Katte ni Kita" or "Tiny Tiny Tiny" (these, are not in the Anime!) she really comes across well. The animation for the ED is just cute and a great contrast to the voice. Whether you like the ED or not, is in the eye of the beholder but it's not badly done. You can say that being different is not a synonym for beauty, but I perceived it as completely unexpected and refreshingly different in a musical way.

The voice actors give the anime a huge part its appealing charm. Especially the harmony between Sawako's shy, tender voice, which is spoken by Noto Mamiko, and the gentle and soft timbre of Namikawa Daisuke, who gives Shouta his voice. The other characters have also got very good voice actors, a nice example in my eyes is Sawashiro Miyuki as voice for Yano Ayane. Her character is feminine, smart but also tough, and that is reflected well in her synchronization.


An emotional and gently narrated love story, not only recommended for fans of the Slice of Life. However, what makes this anime extraordinary is the fact that very convincing and balanced, themes such as bullying, prejudice and exclusion are presented clearly and vividly. Although the presentation is psychologically simple, it is still true. If you liked this anime, you might also be interested in "Ao Haru Ride" or "Suki-tte Ii na yo".


Thanks for reading and have fun watching.

I didn't expect this anime to be so... refreshing. And pure. 
It's vanilla, yet it didn't get boring. Sawako, the adorable protagonist, cleansed a bit my blackened heart with her innocence. Same goes with her darling love interest, Shouta. It's hard not to grow fond of the supporting characters Chizuru and Ayane, which are quite relatable to me.
This story delivered the fuzziness I search for in shoujos, without the excessive drama. There was a good balance between comedy and relationship development. My only disappointment is how it dragged on for the last few episodes without a satisfactory ending. I guess they were planning on asequel. \n\n
Despite a lack of substance in the plot, the storytelling was fantastic. I also thoroughly enjoyed the soothing watercolor backgrounds. I see myself coming back to this anime whenever I'll need a little pick me up.

Kimi Ni Todoke, I watched it a few years back but I'm updating my top 5 favorites with some reviews. (hopefully to get some people who are unsure about watching it... to actually watch it)
-NO spoilers I promise!any romance lover


-The enjoyment you get from this show really is something special, when something good happens to our main character you actually feel really good and vice versa were it bad or something. Sawako is such a easily like-able and relatable character who you get attached too.


-10/10 give this one a shot, even if the art bugs you at first I promise it will grow on you and even more so you will walk away feeling like you watched something meaningful and wonderful, that has a beautiful story being told.


-Enjoy <3

Kimi ni Todoke is a very entertaining and lively series which end each episode with either leaving a smile on your face or genuine worry for the characters. This anime is both humorous and exciting while also giving a good plot and a magnificent opening and closing songs. After watching each episode I can guarantee you will be burning with desire to get to the next episode as quickly as possible and soon begin contemplating which is more important; sleep or knowing how Sawako gets through the situation she found herself in.
In order to be able to break down the anime accordingly let's take alook at how the series genres play a role in the series plot and overall enjoyment; Slice of Life, Romance, School, Shoujo.


Slice of Life~ In regards to this genre there isn't much criticism since all in all it stays loyal to the genre. It is a story about teenagers going to school and going about their daily lives by going places with friends, letting us see inside the family life of Sawako and Ryu as well as giving us the faint details about Ayane's relationship with her college boyfriend. All in all the anime stays true to its genre.


Romance~ This genre is held well by the series main characters and their love interests such as Sawako's admiration of Shouta and Ume's feelings for Shouta. Romance is seen throughout the anime mostly between the main characters Shouta and Sawako and revolves about the two discovering their feelings for each other. In conclusion, the anime stays true to this genre also. 


School~ This genre is fitting since the main events that are important to the plot take place in the school and around the school as well as constantly referring to the school. I see no criticisms I could make towards the placement of this genre.


Shoujo~ In case some of you don't know this term is closely tied to the Japanese word meaning young woman, therefore, meaning that the target audience would be of the female gender but don't be discouraged if you are a male who wishes to watch this since the show isn't too biased toward gender. So I would say this genre is suited to an extent.


I personally believe that the series also goes hand in hand with the Comedy genre and am sad to see that it is not mentioned in the description of the anime which could have made a difference in the views and ratings of the show.


My criticism would fall in the fact that some parts of the anime are quite dull and a little irritating with the awkwardness of the main protagonist Sawako. 

The episodes are 22 minutes each so time flies while watching this show but I wouldn't recommend watching it all in one go since it does get irritating and tiring after the first 12 episodes.

The artwork of the series I believe to be very beautiful and traditional. It looks very artistic and welcoming. 

This could also be said for the opening which is around 1 minute and 4 seconds. The opening is upbeat and catchy as well as soothing. Trust me after hearing the tune and seeing the visuals you won't be able to skip through the loveliness of it all.

 But I do admit I don't personally find the storyline of the series to be worth 25 episodes and a second season I firmly believe it could have been wrapped up a lot quicker and would have been a lot more enjoyable. 

therefore the story itself earns a 6/10 which I still believe is a fair score considering.

The artwork I believe deserve 7/10 due to the visuals being magnificent, but that does not mean it deserved 10 points since some parts of the anime were too chibi for my liking and lazy at times.

the sound deserves a 6/10 for its opening and closing songs no more due to the voice acting being quite poor in some parts.

Characters deserve an 8/10 due to their charisma and their power to stand out. Especially Sawako who is considered scary looking and often related to Sadako from The Ring. Chizuru also deserves points for her tomboyish attitude and the kindness she brings to the series. none of the characters were made to be super beautiful or super special which makes them, in a way, more realistic.

Enjoyment deserves an 8/10 since the show kept me entertained and smiling throughout its duration. I am taking points off for the sheer fact that the series could have been more enjoyable with a better paste.

Overall the anime deserves the 8/10 mark and I would recommend it for people who are looking for a chill heartwarming anime that they can enjoy once and recharge themselves.

If your looking to watch a immature cringy middle school romance with a massive amount of bubbly and sparkly scenes develop in highschool, well this is the anime for you! The anime has decent aspects, if we are talking about production, the story could've been executed better to not make it seem so cliche, but apart from it being cliche it also has a lot of minor plot holes all over the place. 
The soundtrack of this anime is average, nothing outstanding about it. 
The characters of this anime are bad. No one is outstanding in terms of personality.
We have the main shy girl whodoesn't know what is friendship is and is easily manipulated by people who surround her.\n
We have the main popular possessive jealous boy who takes advantage of an inexperienced girl.\n
And we have the uninteresting side characters. \n\n
Enjoyment: I didn't enjoy this at all, it was uninteresting, everything is all over the place.\n
I honestly don't blame people for liking this, on its superficial level its "heartwarming" and if I wasn't so skeptical about everything probably it would be enjoyable. But it isn't that way, the anime has flaws everywhere so...\n\n
3/10 NOT RECOMMENDED \n

(English isn't my first language so I apologize if I make any mistake.
This is also my first review so it might not be very fair.)
A girl named Sawako starts highschool and has for objective, making friends with people of her class. But as she enters the classroom, people stare at her because of her looks ; she has very pale skin, long black hair and dark eyes, which caused people to call her "Sadako" (in reference of the movie ''The Ring"). But then of course, the perfect and most popular boy of the class, Kazehaya, is the first one to talk to her and sheis lovestruck. Kimi ni Todoke is pretty much all about that. 


Story : 6/10


A cliche and plain lovestory about the 'invisible girl'(Sawako) and the 'popular boy'(Kazehaya). I think this is one of the most plain story I've ever seen. I don't know how many times I have seen this in the shoujos. The only thing that is 'uncommon' is the appearance of Sawako and her background. 70% of the anime is Sawako and Kazehaya blushing while they are together. 30% is the plot that is struggling to move forward. This anime is awfully slow, which made me quite impatient and bored while watching it.


Art : 8/10


The art is very good. The artstyle is quite plain but it's rather pleasant to the eye. The animation is very smooth, especially in the openings and the endings. They are always very cute and interesting to watch, always depicting Sawako and Kazehaya together, or Sawako's friends. Some scenes were very beautiful and they fit the artstyle very well.


Sound : 10/10


The openings and endings were all very good. I enjoyed every single one. While the animation was amazing, the songs they chose were lovely as well. The OST wasn't particularly memorable but it fit the ambience of the scenes. This anime was very calm and cute, and I think the music played a big role in this.


Character : 5/10


I felt like Kazehaya and Sawako could have been deeper characters because their chara-design and background were interesting. They are very appealing at the beginning but then, they start to become boring because of the lack of character development. Everything became predictable because of that. 

The side characters were also awfully cliche. The athletic tall girl, the makeup guru friend, the blase quiet boy, the popular and handsome rival, the bitchy and evil rival who's an hypocrite. Not a good thing.

They have rather good chara-designs but I think they could have been a little bit more in the spotlight. They were unfortunately too invisible in this show and some of them were really underrated despite their plain personality. The character development in the side characters was really amazing and interesting.


Enjoyment : 5/10


The only things that I really enjoyed were the art and the music. I had dropped the anime for a certain period of time because I was just, too lazy to finish it. It really didn't excite me and it was just a pain to think about it. Everything was so predictable, so slow and so cheesy that it made me kind of angry. Some of the moments were really cute, while some of them were just cringy. I usually enjoy shoujos and this type of anime in general but this one was just a waste. Lots of things could have been better and improved, especially the end. It's really a shame 


Overall : 6/10


I wish I could give a lower mark to this anime but there were some really good things in this anime. If you're searching for a really sweet, cute and classic shoujo, then I recommend it to you. If that's not the case, then you should just overlook this anime.

I tried to be as objective as possible and I think this is the most fair mark I can give.

This is why some shoujos should never be turned into animes because sometimes what works well in a manga just doesn't once animated:
I first came to know Kimi ni Todoke through the live action which I loved. Bought the manga, loved it in spite of being soppy and reaching volume 27 now... starting to drag A LOT...
Anyway, Kimi ni Todoke just doesn't contain enough story to make it such a long show. 25 episodes for a couple of volumes where not much happens is just too long. While it works in the manga because ultimately, even if it's slow paced, there's just not that manyspace you want to waste on dragging things. It takes time to draw.\n\n
The live-action made the wise choice to shorten the draggiest part of the manga and make it a great slice-of-life high school drama that made it cute, without being too corny. The anime however drags the most annoying parts, and follows the manga to a tee. It feels so slow and corny that ultimately I couldn't help but cringe in front of my screen but arguably, it's faithful to the series. It's just that the animated version doesn't work at all for me.

May Contain Minor Spoilers!!!
Kimi ni Todoke is one of those shows that has such a good start, that you would never even consider it being disappointing. What starts off with an interesting premise with fun, likeable characters soon loses itself in its slow pace, strange humor, and awkward interactions. Though the show manages to stay afloat, I wouldn’t be surprised to see a few people jump ship by the end of it.
The story of Kimi ni Todoke begins with our main protagonist Kuronuma Sawako. The name “Sawako” has the unfortunate case of sounding a lot like “Sadako”, the creepy girl from The Ring. This, alongwith Sawako’s general shyness and quiet demeanor, leads all of her classmates and instructors to believe she is cursed. This is not helped by the fact that every time she tries to correct any misunderstandings, she speaks with a gravelly voice and looks like she’s about to murder everyone in her vicinity. This leads Sawako to become ostracized by the entire school until the magical day when Kazehaya Shouta, the most friendly, popular, and cutest boy in school, decides to invite Sawako to a “test of courage”-type class event.  This allows Sawako to befriend Chizu and Ayane, two girls from her class, and have a private, little moment with Kazehaya, which allows their romantic story to slowly begin.


It is here that the show begins its slow decline towards mediocrity. While the premise feels like it sets up a lot of interesting things to happen, the reality is that it’s a set-up for a few things to happen at an excruciatingly awkward pace. The first thing that the show focuses on is Sawako’s efforts to become more sociable with her class and with her two new friends. This feels like it happens almost immediately. Though Sawako herself takes almost the entire series to come out of her shell a little, she almost instantly becomes friends with her classmates through little “bribes”. Whether its cookies, class notes, or “medical attention”, Sawako’s immense kindness wins over the school almost instantly. Though not a deal-breaker, this makes the entire “The Ring” setup feel contrived and created just to give Kazehaya a reason to talk to her, because apparently he’s conveniently into girls that don’t get a lot of attention. The second thing the show focuses on is her growing infatuation with Kazehaya. Conversely, this part of the story is incredibly padded. Despite both of these characters’ obvious romantic interest for each other, not a single one of them is capable of ever pulling the trigger. Almost every interaction between these two characters involves awkward dialogue, close-ups of them blushing, and you screaming at the screen for them to just confess and kiss already! Usually this drawn out style makes these shows endearing, but the frequency of it in Kimi ni Todoke can be infuriating at times. This simplicity is expected for this type of show and isn’t inherently bad, but it is ruined by a somewhat mediocre cast of characters.


I’ve already briefly talked about Sawako, but despite generally being a really nice, sweet, and loveable character, Sawako frequently turns into an airheaded, socially awkward, bore. She will spend hours of this show’s runtime being confused by social norms and generally making poor decisions because of her failing to grasp a situation. This happens so frequently that the show even creates a specific, cutesy art-style for every occasion that Sawako starts freaking out about minor things. This also makes up for the bulk of this show’s comedy, and while it started out as a quirky thing to chuckle about, there’s simply too much of it. Kazehaya has the opposite problem of just kind of being there because he’s the main love interest. He exists simply to allow Sawako to grow and develop into a more well-rounded character, while he shows little to no growth or development. If anything, he degrades overtime from a charismatic jock to a shy, awkward mess that can barely even look Sawako in the face.


The three “friend” characters don’t fare much better. Chizuru Yoshida is introduced as the athletic type who is initially rumored to be a brute that is quick to anger and beat people up. Despite having some rough, Sawako-esque attempts at humor, Chizu is given a decent arc that results in her being one of the more developed characters in the series. Ayane Yano is introduced as the flirty, beauty-queen who is initially rumored to sleep around A LOT. While being my favorite of the friends, Ayane suffers from an “abusive boyfriend” arc that ends as quickly as it begins, and not really having much personal growth besides that. Ryuu Sanada is introduced as Kazehaya and Chizuru’s less-than-talkative friend. Ryuu suffers from very little screen time and a “secret crush” side story that doesn’t really go anywhere, but his cool and stoic nature generally makes him a treat to see. The only other character worth mentioning is Sawako’s short-lived rival Kurumi. Kurumi’s two-faced nature sets her up as a potential antagonist for the series and is responsible for one of the more interesting series of moments in the story. It, however, turns out disappointing because of how quickly it is dealt with and how little it actually accomplishes in bringing Sawako and Kazehaya together.


This mostly positive, mixed bag of characters eventually leads the story to a sweet, but severely lacking conclusion. I’m positive that the second season will do a lot to alleviate my problems with this show, but it doesn’t change the fact that season one feels lacking. Though the characters were entertaining enough to warrant me finishing this story in the near future, nothing presented thus far makes this show a must-watch series.

this is one of my first reviews, so forgive me  if it is mediocre. Kimi ni todoke is a shoujo romance anime that was lackluster in my opinion. First of all , the art is a bit different in a good way, perhaps a little bit childish, although this is a shoujo anime so its justified. 
Overall, if you are a fan of romance,you should watch this anime. if you are not that into this genre, i suggest watching other anime. Sawako´s clueless attitude might also frustrate some people so keep that in mind.
Characters: 
the main characters are Kuronuma Sawako, a girl with afrightening look , that is actually very nice, kazehaya shouta, your typical male protagonist, kind and popular, ryu, a reserved but sharp individual, chizuru , an athletic boyish girl , that is very sentimental, and ayane, a mature girl that has had her fair share of relationships.\n\n
story: \n
The story starts with a relatively good pace, with kazehaya and Sawako getting to know each other, and then it starts to slow down a lot halfway through , to the point that i start shipping more the side characters (not gonna go into names) than the main ones.\n
All in all the anime is still decent, with some funny moments.

Kimi ni Todoke is an anime which falls in the general romance category. It is exactly what you would expect.
The story is alright, it's nothing special really, but it does the job well. The characters are portrayed fairly well. One thing that bugs me though, which is a fairly common thing in romance anime, is the fact that there are constantly misunderstandings, which slow down the story and pacing by a lot.
The art doesn't help, it is really dated, but if you can slog through it, you get a story which is heartfelt and can insinuate 'feels' at the right moment.

Love Kimi ni Todoke am currently reading the manga as well, which is much further along in the plot.
Story 10/10: Endearing story about an optimistic girl and her mistaken identity and her overcoming it. Has humor, drama and a good feeling all around.
Art 9/10: The art is not drawn to my personal tastes, however throughout the series it did grow on me. I especially like the "expressive" Sawako, she's quite humorous.
Sound 10/10: Great soundtrack, always am humming the tune
Character 10/10: I love the complexities of all the characters. Each one has a certain charm that I can relate to and find sweet and endearing.
Enjoyment 10/10:I always enjoy watching this series, I know in each episode I will be touched and laugh as well, which is a sign of a great story.\n\n
Overall 10/10: Highly recommend for those who like the everyday/life/romance type of anime.

this is more of a comparison than a review, as i couldnt say all that i needed to in the recommendations. i apologize, but it's still kinda like a review!
the story is generic, as you can find many more animes with similar plots and storylines. however, the way it's told is what makes it stand out or not. i've made recommendations for this anime, comparing them to sukitte ii na yo and tonari no kaibutsu-kun as i saw many parallel and contrasting features between KNT and those two animes.
in terms of animation design, it reflected animation seen in sukitte and tonari. although in general itwas more similar to the former, but had more comical aspects to it.


the plot of KNT more likely resembled that of tonari because it was a lot more lighthearted and funny in comparison to sukitte. the plot in all three animes however, follow a similar storyline. none of the male and female leads get their romantic relationship rolling until towards the end. all three animes had female leads confused and questioning their feelings toward the male leads.


the animes had similar character set ups. outcast females that gain friends through being open with the male leads. all females had a small group of girlfriends with the addition of close male friends from the male side.


overall, i find these animes enjoyable to watch, despite potential repetitive aspects. KNT is a good mix of both sukitte and tonari, i would say its more funny than either of them though. 


what strikes me as different about this anime though, is that there's a second season. i havent watched it yet but plan on doing so soon. i think a second season will allow for the romantic relationship to develop further than these typical animes. with sukitte and tonari, the series ends just has the leads are confronting their feelings. so im interested to see how far KNT will take that.

Kimi ni Todoke is the kind of show that's surprisingly good in spite of itself. It's so unbelievably cute you'd think everyone but the shoujo fans would steer clear of it. Yet it's rather appealing. My fourteen year old sister who usually dislikes too cute stuff (she disliked Lovely Complex, please) loved this show. It's because Kimi ni Todoke feels...fresh, and its characters are all likable, especially Kuronuma Sawako. She's so good and honest you'll like her even if she's dense and "oh my gosh what is this i'm feeling" -y kind of girl.  Another thing I love about this anime is...the pace.The romanticpace between the main couple, I mean. It's very slooooooow...but you get to appreciate their conversations and you feel like they are really getting to know each other and falling in love beautifully. Watching them hesitantly walk the way to romance is much more delightful, then, say, "I just met you and this is crazy but I'm gonna kiss you and two episodes later we're renting a hotel room maybe" kind of anime. I HATE that kind of anime. \n
Although Kimi ni Todoke is great, it's still high school romance, though. If you don't like that kind of thing this show probably won't change your mind, though for those who like the genre, this is a true gem.

Kimi ni Todoke maybe one of the best Slice of life anime I have come across till now. For people who enjoy slow developing stories, this series definitely must to be on your list of animes to watch.
Story begins with Kuronuma Sawako, who is mistook by everyone in her school as a spooky girl who can bring misfortune. A fateful encounter with Kazehaya Shota- the most popular student from her school, however, changes all that slowly. She begins to slowly open up more to others in her class. The most important change in her life is the beginning of her friendship with Ayane Yano andChizuru Yoshida. Lots of fun and happy moments follow in the course of the story which Sawako enjoys with both of them. Attitude of her classmates towards her slowly starts changing and they now accept her more than they did before. A sweet development of ever increasing feelings between Kazehaya and Sawako through out the story follows.


An overview:

1) The scenes in the series are really well crafted and are a complete delight to watch. Though Sawako is portrayed as a somewhat spooky girl she is probably the most optimistic amongst any of her classmates. Her flustering on the smallest of the things that a normal student wouldn't even bother, really add to many hilarious moments in the episodes.


2) Her friendship with Ayane and Chizuru has been developed very carefully and is very believable.


3) Developement of romantic feelings between Kazehaya and Sawako are really really cute and innocent.


4) Lots of hilarious moments since Chizuru is absolutely dense when it comes to understanding many emotions.


4) Chizuru's story unfolded at a later part of the show is really touching in many ways.


5) Character development is strong and meticulously followed throughout the show.


6) Dialogues are very well written and have a lot of depth if listened to carefully.


7) Music is soothing though maybe there was some scope for improvement.


8) Animation really good.


9) Encode is excellent.


Note: This is specifically for all girls: If you think that a guy shown blushing is absolutely kawaii then you have a treat in this show. Cause Kazehaya blushes a lot in this show which I personally founfd absolutely adorable :))

The main character of the story is Kuronuma Sawako, you follow her through her high school days. She is in no way normal, from the beginning its quite humorous and you do feel pity for her because of her morbid appearance she gives off and most people think something horrid will happen if you make eye contact for a certain amount of time.
Kuronuma is in love with Kazehaya a boy who has helped her overcome her boundaries of being an outcast, he also happens to be the most popular kid in the school. 
But the purpose of the anime in my opinion is somewhat abecoming of age story, with help from new found friends this girl will go through struggles of being in love, making and trying to make friends happy, being taken advantage of, and most importantly growing out of her shell to be more outgoing and lovable as a character.\n\n
With the help of her friends the sweet pure hearted Kuronuma Sawako should bring us on a journey we will enjoy.

Kimi Ni Todoke is definitely one of my favorites of this season and perhaps of all the animes i've seen. And if you're into romance/everyday life storys, then this one's definitely for you! 
It's basically about a girl name Sawako and something about her scares off some people so they keep a distant from her. She just never had friends but then one day, she meets a boy name Kazehaya, who's very outgoing and friendly and popular. She looks up to him and her life slowly changes after meeting him. 
Story:
Even though i haven't finished the series yet, I know it gets 9 out of10. The story wouldn't be considered brilliant or a real masterpiece, but it has a very good calmness to it and the story is enjoyable to watch. There are a few conflicts here and there, but throughout the series, it keeps good consistency and gets me interested as more the series goes on. I must say this series seems to go really really slow for me. But I don't blame the producers since the manga story isn't that long and they've got 24 episodes to fill. ANYWHOS, it's a cute love story and has alot of funny scenes.


Art: 

I love love this style of art. It's very pretty and cute at the same time. The OP and ED animation are fantastic and very relaxing for me o.o 

I can't really explain how the animation is, but it's great. 


Sound: 

I can't wait to get the OST when it comes out (or did it already come out hm..). The BGM are blended so well with certain scenes and they did a grreat job at it. I would say most of them are relaxing and very cute. 


Character: 

Man, all the characters are great in this series, even the 'bad' characters. You just can't help but feel for them and in the end, like them as well. Knowing that Kimi Ni Todoke is all about romance and slice of life, I definitely didn't expect a really evil character that wants to kill people, and that's pretty obvious. 


Overall, I really enjoyed it so far and I know I'll still enjoy watching it until the last episode of the series. It's one of those shows when you can watch it on a relaxing sunday afternoon and what not. And yes, there are a couple sad scenes, espcially when watching what Sawako has to deal with, but in the end, it leaves you with a good feeling and i dont know if i should say this, but it makes me sort of happier? Anyway, try it. 


c:

This is an amateur review. Romance, slice of life, a little bit of laughs. Almost done with first season, YOU'VE BEEN WARNED!! Kimi ni Todoke 
Ok, I'd like to start with what I've seen so far. Most people are crazy about this anime, and I see why. Great characters and it's pretty modern. As for me, I don't feel like I would watch this for two days non-stop like I do for a lot of romantic anime an such. It's like sweet girl likes sweet boy and romance sprouts between the two. The girl, Sadako(Sawako), is a young girl who is sweet and shy andmost people don't approach her since she looks a bit like Sawako from "The Ring". \n
On her way to school one day, a boy named, Shota, wasn't afraid to approach her and asked her for directions since he was new to the school. She begins to develop feelings for him and, like I said, romance starts to sprout. Things start to turn around after their encounter and she makes friends and opens up a bit.\n
It's a pretty simple anime. From what I've seen there are no inappropriate parts for young viewers. To be honest, it's not exciting really. It's like "Nice girl meets nice guy, and BOOM, stuff happens." It's a cute anime, but a bit cliché. I recommend it to anyone who is first starting romance anime. \n
I did this on my phone so I'm sorry for any typos.

Quite to be honest, I can call this anime as a 'shoujo-manga' genres, since this anime was adapted from a manga 'Kimi Ni Todoke' alas 'From Me To You'. I found some -no. a LOT of scenes which are compatible to be called as a shoujo-manga. The story was also good, only at the beginning, it was a bit fast. I also won't deny that I can guess some parts easily, and well... I wouldn't deny that I was quite shy while watching some scenes, especially the last episode.
My only complains are about the songs and the background effects, which were quite disturbing me severaltimes, especially the effects. As a shoujo-manga reader, I absolutely noticed that lots of manga, especially shoujo, have always put an effect like a bubble etc, and I've never really paid attention for that, since it's for an ornament for having a good yet making the background to be a bit 'crowded', but it's quite annoying if they put this into anime too, since anime was colourful, meanwhile manga wasn't.\n
Overall, this was good, and it made me amused as the main character, that 'Sunako' made me laugh several times because of her stupidity, and I love how they portrait the characters and the relationship between each others. But the most important thing is, this anime kinda reminded me of my life during high school, since it's one of the most precious memories that I've ever had.

I'll keep this short.  The anime follows the manga almost mirrored perfect.  And I like that.  But I won't comment on much, except that which I want.
This anime has fantastic music and sound.  The Intro Theme is beautiful, and the ending theme is great.  
That is the only real comment I want to share in this review, because things regarding the story can be found in the manga.

I'm not one to write a review or give harsh criticism but I can't sit by on this one. Now let me make this clear before I start ranting, just because I don't like this anime does not  mean that you won't. Now I have never had an anime frustrate me to this point. Let me say a couple of good things first. The art isn't so bad it can be beautiful at times, the music isn't so bad either it would always portray the mood. But that's it, the main character made me want to scream at times. No one and I meanno one is that slow, before I watched it I read a description and thought. Wow this character reminds me of myself when I was in high school. But man it was far from the truth. She is so dim that it's overwhelming, I get being isolated makes it harder to understand others when you do open up. But come on she was almost like a new born baby. And the crying I have never seen so many tears in my life, I didn't think it would ever end. There was so many opportunities to make this into a very good anime but sadly all it was about for the most part is girl unpopular, boy very popular, become friends, developed deeper feelings for each other. That's the first couple of episodes then it's just all about the drama. Characters development seemed lacking and the story just dragged on and I really had to force myself into finishing it. \n
 But again this is my opinion nothing more and it seems many people like it. So don't be turned off on watching it just because of my feelings for it. You may enjoy it as well.

Well First of all, spoilers ahead so if you don't want them, then don't read this.
*sigh* Kimi Ni Todoke. I had high expectations from you but you have let me down massively.
First of all, this anime should be called "Goukai" (Goukai = miunderstanding) instead. 
The story is average. A girl is way too shy and gloomy looking to the point of complete regard of her existence, and a popular guy who likes her as the story progresses. I was fine with that, actually Sawako's character also made me happy to the extent of crying to say how pure someone can be.
That is all there isto it. Every single time she meets someone, there is a misunderstanding and she is way too shy to even approach them, let alone takes two Goku-like buffers to draw up the courage to actually admit it to someone.


I understand the protagonist is shy and avoided by everyone but that does not mean that the character would not have the common sense to understand something ONE BLUNTLY SAYS TO HER FACE - THAT IS THE AMOUNT OF RIDICULE THAT HAPPENS WITH HER.


The cherry on top of the cake it takes 1.5 years of the anime cycle or two seasons worth for her to understand what everyone is blatantly saying to her face. Bravo Sawako, you're denser than the periodic element.


The characters are average, an awkward/outgoing protagonist duo, and supportive friends on each side. Hence, to summarize:


- Mediocre Characters

- Increasingly Frustrating episodes

- Art style was rather refreshing

- Too many f-ing misunderstandings


That is all.

*Short Review*
I consider this show to be brilliantly done in the era we live in now. There is nothing sexual or vulgar about this show. The best way to describe this show was an innocent romance, and for that reason alone it could be one of my favorites. It's a very pretty anime with a great sound track.
It is slow at parts and very frustrating when their misunderstandings get out of hand, but i think the story in all is worth getting though that.
9/10

So, I'm going to be pretty blunt here, and it's not a review at all, more of a PSA to anyone who wants to watch this series.
The first season of Kimi ni Todoke is a complete waste of time, unless that's your initial motivation for watching the show in the first place. The first season moves at such an horrifically slow pace it's a wonder that I actually got through it all. My motivation for doing so was the linguring hope that: "This will be the episode where something happens! I know it is!".... Well, that moment never came..
Though the artistry, the CGI and characterdevelopment is pretty solid, it just isn't enough to justify a higher mark than what I've given it (3/10). The thing that is consistent throughout both series is the realism of the characters, they certainly reminded me of people whom I used to be affiliated with at school.


With that said... I highly recommend the 2nd season of this show, it was such a refreshing change of pace. And although many people seemed to sneer at the introduction of a the new character [Kento], I found that it actually kept things interesting and although initially you may not take to him too favourable, I think he was pretty vital in keeping a casual, fun atmosphere to each episode. With Ryu and Pin supporting.


There are plenty of flash-backs in the second-season that link back to the important moments of the first, that there's no reason to watch the first 25 episodes. You will not be missing out of the plot development... Simply because... Well, there wasn't any. 


But ye, go watch the second season, it's good fun and pretty fucking cute, you'll be content with the ending I assure you, but there is certainly a possibility for a continuing season where we can see where the characters develop in the future. After 35 episodes leading up to the climax, I think we're owed a season that shows how their decision manifests for better or for worse.

I just want to say that the star of this show is Ryu, that guy made it pretty etertaining throughout the series, he provided solid comic-relief when it was needed, but he wasn't just a one-dimensional character, he's somebody that I think everybody knew at their high-school. So of course it's fun to reminisce about the good ol' days of high-school.


Sorry for the shitty, monotonous post. Just don't want people waste their time with watching this season, so go watch the second!

Well, when I heard that this was going to be an anime, I basically started jumping up and down and hunted the crucial first episode down. 16 episodes later, I haven't been disappointed yet. 
The STORY is unlike any others that I've read, but the 
ART is truly magnificent. the pure watercolors and steadfast designs are breathtaking. It's basically like the animators took the color illustrations from the manga and animated them. 
SOUND: (i guess what they mean is seiyu and music) The opening theme (Kimi Ni Todoke) is such a pretty song, i find myself singing it in the shower. All of the seiyuare very talented and the voices are just like the ones in my head as i read the manga. Ending theme by Chara was lovely at first, but as the series progressed, i found myself getting bored from it.\n
CHARACTER: this is what attracted me in the first place when i started reading the manga. Kazehaya is friendly and refreshing, Sawako is lovable and adorably innocent, Chizu-chan is hilarious, and Ryu+Pin just add to the bundle.\n
ENJOYMENT: I'm pretty sure you can guess from the content of the review how much i utterly enjoyed this.

I am so in love with this anime and it's characters. First of all I want to thank Karuho Shiina for giving us this manga/anime... Arigatou :D You made me fall in love with Kazehaya and Kuronuma so much that I can't get them out of my head. They are placed inside my heart and not leaving. I am so glad I chose to watch this though... everything about it left me so happy and Kazehaya has so many cute moments... one of my favourite moments is the end of season 2, but you won't get a spoiler out of me. I would recommend thisto absolutely EVERYONE who loves cute and feel-good animes. Seriously, you won't find much better than this. The pure and honest love Kazehaya and Kuronuma share is inspirational :D \n
This anime has reached my favourite, officially! Kazehaya hits number 1 in my catagory of favourite anime guys... mainly because of his freshness, cheerfulness and outright cuteness lol! He's awesome. Kuronuma reaches number 1 in my catagory for favourite anime girls... because of her cuteness, always trying her best and she's so beautiful. There are so many funny moments in this anime too... really, you will not be disappointed! Give it a watch!!! RECOMMENDED 10 STARS!!!

One word fits this series perfectly; Endearing. 
To start with, I was very hesitant towards watching this anime. "Another high school romance" is what went through my mind. There is nothing particularly original about Kimi Ni Todoke but I couldn't help it; I had to keep watching.
The main character is shy, an outcast, and overall just a lonely soul. We can all agree that we have been in that position many times, which is what made me like Sawako instantly. Kazehaya is the one who starts motivating her along with Yano and Chizuru. Throughout the whole series you can't help but want to cheer forher as she slowly breaks out from her shell. \n\n
Overall, this anime is worth a watch. The intro and outro songs fit the anime perfectly and sets the mood. I'm a guy and I loved it, so hopefully others will too.

The Story is really good, it is mainly a Slice of Life, romance, and shoujo anime. The story develops at a really good pace and it's not as deep as a phycological thriller it still tells a nice story that is fairly deep considering how you view it. The story rarely if ever got boring for me as it held be tight as I went through all the episodes wanting to see what happened next. The story is also unique with other shoujo anime and doesn't have many clichés and unlike some other shoujo anime isn't this soap opera like anime that can break outdown at times rather it's much better. You might be thinking, well I'm a guy and shoujo anime and manga is for girls, well I too am a guy and I rather like shoujo anime and manga and romances, and I also like actions so you know. This is also one of the best romance animes that I've seen and I love romance anime. It really does a good job with the story though of course it being a Slice of Life anime some may think at times that it goes really slow, I really didn't think that when I was watching it.


The characters are a place where this shines, it has wonderful and unquie characters especially Sawako and I condsider her one of my favorite anime characters as she just loveable and wonderful. As she cries we too tear up not always because it was sad but because it was beutiful and joyus. As she laughs we too find our selves laughing. Other characters in the series are good as well and I really enjoyed them like Shouta, Chizuru, Ayane, and Ryuu. Character development is wonderful and great, we really get to see how these characters grow and develop throughout the anime. It also doesn't focus on developing just one or two characters but rather several characters to a good degree and by the end you can really see how far these characters have come. Not only that but the story doesn't focus on just one love tale or just focus heavily on one character that we don't get to see a lot of the others, we really get to see into the other characters and they are really included. Because of all of the development and the time that we spend with them they really grow on you and you really like them and want them to succeed and they become amazing.


The music is wonderful, I found the opening and ending themes to be great and awesome though they are only like 1 minute long compared to the normal 1 minute and thirty seconds however they are still great songs and are rememberable. They might not be the absolute best I've seen they are really good. It doesn't stop there the soundtrack in the anime also melds well and I can hardly remember hearing the same music over and over again to the point where it's overused. Though the soundtrack isn't as memberable as the opening and ending it did it's job well and I think that if I heard it in a playlist it would also be good. Maybe not where you have to have the CD of the sound track but nice to hear once in awhile.


The animation was good, it was nice and sweet and really well done. The characters where really well draw and the animation style was unquie and well done. That being said there were still some flaws, like I remember where when viewing a character from the side and a little diagnal and I think in a couple other view points as well we could only see one eye and the other side was kind of shaded in. It was enough for me to take notice, there are a couple of times where things like this happened but it doesn't greatly detract from the overall experience of the animation or the anime. The anime is not dubbed to my knowledge and I watched it subbed and the voice acting was pretty well done, I really don't have any complaints about it.


The ending, well there is a second season which only has 12 episodes, the first season has 25. So the ending of the first season was good, alight because there was a second season which I quickly jumped to. It's regretable that the second season though only has 12, I would like to see a third but who knows if that will happen. Though to comment on the second season's ending it was a little rushed but still good.


Overall it was a wonderful anime that I really enjoyed. I'm sure that if you like Slice of Life anime or Romance or even shoujo then you will like this anime, if you only ever watched mecha and action then maybe you will like it. It could be that nice refreshing anime that you watch. I urge you to check it out, maybe it give it a episode or just the opening, and if you don't like anime or never tried it then this could be your chance.

It was a time that had not seen such a friendly female character as Sawako. The anime is very good, the story is good, the characters has charisma, and the plot is never forced, even the moments of humor.
A story of love, discovery and friendship, which is so simple and charming as well.

I am actually a little surprised that I liked this series as much as I did.   When I first started this series, I thought it would be a solid series, but nothing noteworthy.  The story is nice though typical for the high-school romance genre.  However, I think what won me over are the characters and the art.  The characters are amusing, well-developed, and fit nicely within the series.  The main character Sawako is especially likable, having a level of innocence that is very endearing, plus her voice fits the character very well.  The art not only fits theshow very nicely, but it also matches each scene.  Throughout the series, the art style changes from a more realistic style to a much simpler version during some of the more comedic moments.  These changes help enhance the feelings and emotions that each scene attempts to portray, which I think made the show even more enjoyable than it would have been otherwise.  It's a good thing that there's a second season, as I would like to see how the various romances continue to develop.\n\n
Kimi ni Todoke is a very heartwarming series, sure to appease fans of high-school romance.  It does have some chick-flick moments that may cause some to roll their eyes, yet they didn't deter my ability to enjoy the show.  With great art, characters, and even nice opening and ending sequences, Kimi ni Todoke is a 9/10 (Outstanding) for me.

I am a horror and psychological OTAKU but I also love watching action and adventure type of stories. Love stories are not really my type or at least it is the last in my lists of what I would want to watch or read. Most probably for the obvious facts that love stories have the strong tendencies of being so cheesy or too dramatic which is what I hate the most. Well, at least that’s what I’ve always believed to be the case but after watching this series I couldn’t be so damn wrong. 
ABOUT THE STORY
This beautiful story was about a very shy andweird girl in high school, Sawako, who was so outcast because of her resemblance to “SADAKO” of the famous movie “RING”. As the story went by it was revealed that she was simply so shy and awkward around people and almost everything for her was new so she’s really had a hard time making friends. And this was also about a popular guy who she was looking up to and aiming to be like someday and without even realizing that the guy love her so much. The series revolved around her transformation, making important friends and most importantly, it showed how Sawako and Kazehaya fell in love with each other.


What I really love about the story was its simplicity and despite that, the author still managed to make it as beautiful and amazing like those famous stories with a heavy main plot. This series proved that love stories doesn’t have to be too dramatic with characters sleeping around and end up hurting each other or people dying and making the lead character broken or worst having a half-assed resolve because you can’t choose among so many girls like those HAREM-type of stories. This series was just about a girl who genuinely wanted to make friends and realizing how sweet it was to fall in love for the first time. There were no over to top scenes or cheesy dialogues. The characters’ thoughts and dialogues were genuinely honest and innocent as if it was the feelings from a real person which was one of the strongest points of the series. Nowadays, most series put so much drama to the scenes and dialogues that make it over exaggerated which is not what real people would do or say in real life. The series showed more of the realistic side of life. Every romantic moment is expressed in details and almost magical. Even from simple romantic gestures, little sweet talks and even cute jealousies of both main leads, the romance is expressed genuinely. It is not too much or too dramatic. It is made as simple as possible and yet the impact is no doubt so huge which make the story so amazing despite the simplicity.  This is the definition of what a true love story should be, without any malice or people going insane, without a very serious heavy main plot. It was just a pure and innocent love story like our first love or for some what our first love should have been. The story reminds us how wonderful truly it is to fall in love.


ABOUT THE CHARACTERS

Almost all the characters were so likeable whether the supporting characters or even the third parties. Both Sawako’s and Kazehaya’s friends were such nice people and would always support them behind the scenes. I also love Pin, his not only hilarious but he can also be reliable in important times. 


ABOUT KAZEHAYA AND SAWAKO

Of course, the two main protagonists were the strongest characters among all of them. Sawako was the shy and very awkward type of person and Kazehaya was the popular and friendliest among the campus. I really love Sawako for being so innocent. She would be troubled for every little thing around her and would always assume that she might be bother to others. I would always thought of wishing to protect her innocence as so she won’t be dirtied by the harsh reality of the world. What I really love about her was despite her shyness and insecurities; she worked hard just to be accepted by everyone. One thing that not only me but lots of her closes friends admire about her. And did I mention she was absolutely hilarious! She and Pin were the main source of comic relief in the series. But of course, let’s not forget the very gorgeous Kazehaya who despite being very popular was still level-headed. Unlike your typical popular guys who sleeps around and as if they are collecting girls they can go out with, Kazehaya was also innocent about love and didn’t even had the courage to confess to the girl of his dreams. He would even be innocently and cutely be awkward towards Sawako despite being famous. I also admire that his not the type of guy who would believe anything others would say and would just believe it if it was straight from the person himself. I strongly believed that’s one of many reasons why he loved Sawako for being so honest and straightforward. He was also so damn cute whenever he would get jealous or shy when his admiring Sawako. What was really hilarious was the very obvious fact that both of them didn’t even realized that they felt the same feelings for each other and all they had to do was be honest with each other and just say what they truly felt. They didn’t even notice that each other’s gesture towards the other was in fact a hint of love. They were such a cute and too dense couple. They are two of the best characters in my hundred lists of best characters.


ABOUT THE ANIMATION and SOUND

The animation was superb. Every scene was beautifully made especially the effects in important scenes where the characters showed their strongest emotions or said their super cool lines. The characters were amazingly made; see how beautiful Sawako and Kazehaya are as well as the other characters. It was almost like a sin how the author made such gorgeous looking characters. And to add it up, the soundtracks were captivating. It was like the music made the series a lot more magnificent. Like a cherry on top of a cake. 


It’s been a long review! Well, it is one of the bests after all so we should express all the pent up ideas and comments.


If you want to remember your sweet first love then you can definitely relate to this series and if it’s not that sweet then you would definitely wish to have this kind of love story when you were younger. With the best story, cool lines, amazing characters, captivating animation and music, this series is definitely one you cannot miss. Find out why love has been the most important and the sweetest feeling in the world since ancient time.

Take your average well-intentioned but misunderstood girl and place her in a friendship with one of the most popular boys in class, and what do we have? Despite the general cliched feeling the anime originally gives off, Kimi ni Todoke is actually quite a pleasant but at times exceptionally frustrating anime with, yeah, a couple of cliches but quite an emotional feeling and absorbing cast, especially when it comes to the supporting cast.
