Our protagonist is naive but generally a wholehearted person, which at times proves irritating due to the problems her lack of self esteem and ability to misunderstand everything cause. Despite this, thesupporting cast makes up for it more than enough, while providing comedic relief and all-round humor to the anime, and the supporting cast quite honestly push the anime that little bit further.


We follow Sawako (mistakenly nicknamed Sadako) as she originally sets out to befriend her classmates and attempts to follow Shota's (her eventual love interest) example of being a 'popular, refreshing person.' Eventually, she goes on to try to pursue a relationship with Shota. Despite the general simplicity of the plot, there are an endless amount of interferences and misunderstandings between the two, which causes this anime to be really, really frustrating to the point of me cringing whenever they attempt to talk to each other.     


The art, particularly the background art, had a very soft feeling, as though the characters were in a watercolour painting, which gave the anime a very delicate beautiful feeling, especially combined with the fragile soundtrack and the scene of the anime. I will admit everything was pieced together beautifully, the music, the art and the characters fitted together like a jigsaw, the animation was fluid and the voice acting was quite good.


In the end, despite how angry i can get at the characters, I've already watched this anime twice and will again someday. It's quite a precious thing to watch and you will grow quite attached to it - felling quite satisfied with the ending, but a little sad to see it go.

Such an adorable anime.  I couldn't keep away from it even for a moment. Even when I went to sleep I was excited to wake up the next day to watch more of it.
I suppose it's also because I could relate to the main female character.  I was really shy in school and I had rumors about me and people who harassed me.  I never really had friends or a "prince charming" like boyfriend, but it felt nice to be able to relate to a character so much.  I'm so happy the anime was so much like the manga, so eventhough the anime is over, I can continue on with the manga as if I'm still watching the anime.

Social isolation, like many afflictions dealing with the mind, is a cruel mistress. It robs you of precious moments before they can even form, even as you take a perverse sense of comfort in its cycle of self-harm. You fail to reach out to others, convince yourself that you deserved to fail, and then fully expect to continue to fail. Without the tools to change your behavior, in fact, you won't even realize the overlying problem at all, because this *is* your normality, having felt this way for so, so long.
As an outsider looking in, this can be a frustrating process to watch. Why doesn'tour female protagonist, Sawako, just simply state what she thinks in order to avoid confusion? Why is she so critical of herself; unable to accept her true worth as a beautiful, intelligent, kind young woman? Why doesn't she give Kazehaya the damn chocolates? Just *headpalm* give him the damn *backshove* chocolates! What's stopping you? He's right there!


And that last scenario is in the *second* season. Because this takes time to resolve, I understand the criticism that is often levelled toward "Kimi No Todoke" - which translates to "From Me to You" - that there are episodes where "nothing" happens. This is because what may be a huge step forward developmentally for Sawako may very well be an everyday, mundane event to you or me. It can take the form of a single sentence that is no longer left unsaid, a piece of advice that is truly taken to heart, or the revelation that maybe she is capable of being loved. It may be slow, but there is definite progress, and it's heartwarming to see. 


Compare this with Tomoko, the main character in "WataMote." Although it's a comedy and not a romance, it serves as a perfect example of a character who not only suffers from her own crippling social problems but always seems to find herself back at square one. Although you find yourself laughing at the situations she gets into, it is often very hard to watch her fruitless struggles if you have any empathy for her at all. Even though WataMote tries to end on a somewhat hopeful note, Tomoko's future is far from clear, and that is because through the entire season she lacks the one key ingredient that Sawako has in spades: a support system.


Enter Shouta Kazehaya and friends. I have heard Kazehaya described as a "Gary Stu" and as with other opinions about this show that I feel are misplaced, I can understand why. On the outside he appears to be the perfect guy: attractive, outgoing, kind, popular, and sure of himself. Those first four traits are undeniable, but that last one is put into doubt more and more as the show progresses. Shouta doesn't always say the right thing, or give the right impression, or understand every situation - and it leads to many confusing situations for him and Sawako both. The beauty of it all is, despite first appearances, that Shouta needs her just as much as Sawako needs him. And it's everyone that needs to come to this realization, not just Shouta but Sawako as well, along with their classmates, and you too, the viewer.


Along the way you get to meet a handful of side characters who are fleshed-out nicely and make a major contribution in moving the story along. As in life, some are quick to be friends with Sawako, and some aren't. Many of them start out as straight-up antagonists, but just as we learn new things about Sawako and Shouta along the way, there is much to appreciate about the ones who throw a wrench into the works, even deliberately. No one here is one-dimensionally cruel just for cruelty's sake. And again in a true reflection of how life actually works, many important lessons can be learned from those who are most critical of you.


It must be noted that "Kimi ni Todoke" makes all its points without beating your head over it. It avoids overusing symbolism, constantly repeating character exposition, and characters going into tearful hysterics every few minutes that afflict other titles such as "Your Lie in April." Also unlike "Your Lie in April," there's not this sense of impending doom that settles over the entire proceeding. Even during the setbacks, "Kimi ni Todoke" remains positive which makes for a comfortable watching experience.


From a technical standpoint, Production I.G. did a fine job of incorporating the original character designs from the manga source material. The animation quality is good, and actually improves slightly as the season progresses. The soundtrack is quite good too, especially the opening and ending vocal tracks of which instrumental versions find themselves woven into the episodes on occasion. The voice performances, as is to be expected nowadays, is top-notch with well-established talent taking up the roles of main characters and side characters alike.


In summary, if you are one to appreciate a good romance story, then I cannot recommend "Kimi ni Todoke" enough. If I have any criticism of it at all, it lies in the fact that for now we only have the two seasons to watch these characters grow and flourish. I am hopeful that since the manga is still going as I write this, we may get to see them again on the small screen for a third season, or maybe even the big screen as a one-hour movie that double features with something else. Sawako and Kouta deserve that much.

This series had a huge impact on me when I watched it for the first time about six years ago. I thought it was a true masterpiece, and I still think it is. I could go on for a long time listing everything that I love about this anime, but there is already so much been said about that so I don’t even know what else I can add to that. The story, the characters, music, art… Everything is just top notch. It’s an amazing fairytale and a classic romcom right there.
But…
Recently I re-watched the first season, for the first time in many years. Andnow that I have become older, smarter and wiser I started to see things in Kimi ni Todoke a bit differently. As I was re-watching the first season, I started to notice certain issues and interpret things in a different way. It’s like I’m watching it through a prism of time and all the knowledge that I have accumulated in the past years.  So instead of praising this anime I would rather focus on those issues and look at some things more in detail. Just remember that I’m NOT saying that this anime is bad, as a product of entertainment, I just want to share some of my observations and interpretations. You can do whatever you want with that information.


So there I go:


When I was watching it for the first time, I was around the age of 18, just about to finish high school. And like I said earlier, looking back at it, I realize how much this anime impacted me. Not only emotionally, but it also influenced me in how I developed further as a person for a long time, how I behaved to other people and generally speaking… It had a huge influence on my perception of reality. The most important point that I am trying to make is that “fairytales” like Kimi ni Todoke (or any romcom for that matter) can really f*** up people’s minds. 


Kimi ni Todoke is a highly distorted representation of reality where people are actually being kind to each other, where “being weak” is being encouraged and idealized, where people love and help each other unconditionally, where everyone is basically being “happy together” in one dumb clusterfuck. Kimi ni Todoke is the embodiment of “wishful thinking”. Everything described above are in my opinion the worst things to promote and teach to children/young people. Yea… You might say something like “It’s just a fairytale bro, aren’t all fairytales supposed to feed people’s wishful thinking and be unrealistic?”. Yea, maybe. But the problem is that animes like Kimi ni Todoke can set highly unrealistic expectation from the environment, which can result in disappointment in life and people, depression and other psychological problems. 


Kids/Young people who are not educated and who don’t have a fully developed brain yet, unable to think rationally and strategically, might really think that all the events and behavior presented in Kimi ni Todoke is legit. The worst thing is that most kids who watch that show don’t even question the behavior and motives of the characters, and most kids automatically assume that people behave like that in real life too.  In the reality, teenagers don’t try to include anti-social, weak and dumb kids… Or ANY kid who deviates from being “normal”. No they don’t shower them with warmth and love. Most people are very egocentric. Any person who’s been through an average high school knows that the reality is actually different from what is being presented in Kimi ni Todoke.


Main character Sawako’s behavior is just text book autism. She doesn’t understand why people act in a certain way, she doesn’t understand the motives behind other people’s behavior… I could go on for a long time summing up all the symptoms, but you can go see it for yourself, it’s all right there. Just take the opening scene for example, where Sawako is overhearing a conversation in the toilets, like the first 2-3 minutes of the first episode. She is alone, people are gossiping about her, nobody is taking her serious and people are literally running away from here. I think the opening scene of the first episode actually shows the reality the way it is for Sawako… It’s cold, grey and lonely. But because you are only getting it shown for such a short period of time, and because it contrasts so much with the rest of the series where everything is colorful and fluffy, you simply don’t get enough time for your consciousness to register what’s going on. I simply don’t have enough space and time to debunk every scene, but you can just go watch it yourself. 


“For some reason, I always find people apologizing to me”. 

“I’m sorry for not living up to your expectations, but I can’t see ghosts.”... 

“For some reason, people are always afraid of me. I just try to be friendly”.


Nuff said…

I'm a girl of law and justice, so my rating of 6/10 is based on calculations from other aspects. I hate a message in this anime that almost made me give it a lower score; Hail justice! Shall we dive in to the review?
Story 3/10 :
Let me get this straight : there is absolutely no story.
We follow the daily lives of the characters by seasons and that's it. A shy/introvert girl who tries to socialize after an interaction with a boy. And here comes what turned me off the most-the message. (WAIT FOR YOUR PRINCE CHARMING TO SAVE YOU, GIRLS. YOU WILL SEE HAPPINESS AFTERHIM. YOU WILL CHANGE FOR THE BETTER. TRY TO BE PRETTY FOR HIM)

Seriously? Flash news: there's no such a thing as prince charming, and no one will change you for the better but yourself. Change FOR YOURSELF and be pretty FOR YOURSELF cause others really don't care and you will feel disappointment if you keep on looking for validation.


Art 6/10 :

What can I say? I have watched high-quality animation anime so this was so mediocre next to them, add to that the use of "fast sketches/chibi version" too much and even in serious times, which was cheap but acceptable.


Sound 8/10:

I loved the opening so much. The very few OSTs were soothing.


Character 6/10:

Sawako, baby girl,  "naivety" can only take so much for what you're doing. I study maths as a main subject and I detected an absence of logic. Yes, I know you grew up with no friends, I know. But how do you explain this : 

Kurumi : I hate you. Sawako : Kurumi was my bff and she loved me and I loved her wow fRIENDSHIP !

Kazehaya, boy, don't you have any PROBLEMS? SERIOUSLY THE GUY WAS SMILING EVERYTIME and beside the fact that he's "loved by everyone" and he has a small brother, WE LITERALLY KNEW NOTHING ABOUT HIM.

Ryu and his childhood friends were explored more than the main characters and developed so much.

Mediocre cast.


Enjoyment 7/10 :

I enjoyed some of the sweet/funny moments in this anime. But it wasn't enough to make me watch the 2nd season. I will close my chapter with this anime here, no more suffering for me YAY :(


Overall 6/10 :

If you have PLENTY of free time, go ahead and watch this at your own risk. Beware of the slow pace, it will feel like a chore sometimes.

This anime is really a simple concept of a high school romance, but what made me love this anime is the characters, they really outdone it. I got really hooked in with the first couple of episodes in, it was an easy and thought out concept that you know what to expect. Even though the was alot of progression through the whole season with the main characters, the screen time with side characters is really what shined to me and how they did it. Overall this anime is a beauty to watch, one of the best romance anime, I've seen so far for sure. Fora guy like me that's heavily in to shounen and action this anime was really enjoyable.

It isn't anything ground-breaking. She's shy, she thinks too much, he likes her, he's popular and everything she is not. 
It has, however, details that make this anime stand out from others. It's in the little things.
If you are shy and awkward (like me lmao), You.Will.Relate. I've come across a fair share of shy, main characters, but this was the most relatable by far. Also, Sawako scaring the hell out of her classmates creates lots of funny situations, so that's a bonus. Oh, and her best friends and their relationships, that's good too. 
Very prone to cliffhangers, which will keep you on the edge ofyour seat wanting more.\n\n
tl;dr It was very enjoyable to watch. Simple, but enjoyable. Slow build-up, which is not always ideal, but you can put up with it because it's So Enjoyable!! It filled my heart with good things and I Want To Adopt Every Character.\n\n

Oh, goodness, I can't believe I actually found a 100% realistic romance anime. 
I'm just gonna jump into why this anime is one that everyone should watch. For one thing, it isn't just a romance. I've been noticing this a lot lately, but many romance anime do this thing where EVERY plot point revolves around the main romance story. I hate it. Kimi ni Todoke actually managed to break that barrier. At its core, it's your standard "popular boy meets shy girl" plot, but once you delve deeper into it, it really becomes a story about friendship, and that's why it's so good. 
The charactersthemselves are what makes this anime great, in my opinion. They're all written in ways that makes them seem authentic and likable. That, in turn, supplements the story (which is also amazing, just to be clear). It's hard to explain, but I just loved watching this dynamic of girls having girls' backs and classmates that welcomed one another despite their differences and a girl learning what it means to care for people. It all comes together really nicely through this anime.\n\n
The only thing I didn't really fall in love with was the art style, and obviously, that's just personal preference. It did grow on me, but I'm not the biggest fan of the more 2-D, simplistic style. That being said, there's still some pretty shots in this anime. \n\n
I can confidently say that if you want a good romance, school, or slice of life anime, this is where you need to be. It goes above and beyond almost every other anime in the genre that I've seen. It's heartwarming, it made me cry almost every episode, and it made me happy. So, I'm really looking forward to what's next.

Chicken Noodle Soup for the Soul: Anime Edition
Just like any medium, anime can elicit a wide range of emotions and thought-provoking ideas about any number of serious subjects. But the thing is, sometimes you just want to sit back and watch something that makes you feel good. 
Kimi ni Todoke (season 1) is simply one of the most heartwarming anime I’ve come across. Even during my second time through the series, each episode rarely failed to make me feel all warm and fuzzy inside, and sometimes even moved me to tears. And yes, as you can see on my MAL profile, I’m a guy. 
Sohow did Kimi ni Todoke pull this off? Well, first and foremost, characters. They’re a delight, and will be getting the lion’s share of the attention. Let’s start with the main character, Sawako, the awkward but sweet social outcast. It’s nearly criminal just how likeable she is, to the point of someone being that nice is almost unrealistic. Plenty of “loner” main characters end up being portrayed as quite bitter and disillusioned, but that could not be farther from the truth for her. Despite so many reasons not to (I mean almost everyone calls her “Sadako” after girl from The Ring), she not only treats everyone well, but almost always puts others first. Yes, her social skills are severely lacking, but given her history, it didn’t seem too implausible, and more importantly, she did make strides in that area throughout the first season. How? Well, I’m glad you asked.


Enter Kazehaya, the main love interest and most popular boy in school. And I know those of you that have seen enough shoujo must be thinking “I’ve seen this story before”, and you wouldn’t be entirely wrong. But I’ll say this, as a guy that watches plenty of shoujo, the male love interests tend to be sort of hit-or-miss for me; but I legitimately came to like Kazehaya. Unlike similar characters, people didn’t like him because he looked like a model, was the star of the basketball/football/soccer team, or his parents were loaded; they were drawn to him simply because he was a genuinely good person. Despite all their differences, him and Sawako had that in common. Oh, and like her, he displayed his fair share of awkwardness in their budding relationship. Actually though, Sawako did not look at him in a romantic sense to begin with. He was just someone she admired and wanted to emulate. It happened gradually, but she did sort of begin to emulate him. She got more friends, started socializing, and even fell in love for the first time.


Speaking of those new friends, there were 3 more members of the main cast. Chizu, the tomboy with a bit of a fragile heart. Ayane, the decidedly more feminine-looking but also much less emotional of the two girls. Then there’s Ryu, the strong and (very) silent type. I won’t go as deep with these three, but needless to say, like the main 2, they are all very likeable and add something of value to the show. Sawako’s new-found friendship with Chizu and Ayane was the basis for some of the more heartwarming moments in the anime.


Now it’s time to briefly touch on some of the other aspects of the show, starting with the story. Like I said, the “unpopular girl meets popular boy” thing has been done a lot in shoujo. But I feel like it was presented in a realistic manner that did not come off as another pandering “self-insert MC X dream girl/guy love interest wish fulfillment” romance anime. Also, watching Sawako grow as a person and her world sort of opening up was a real joy to watch.


The animation was solid, although don’t expect to be blown away. The character models were pretty realistic for the genre, but each had their charm. IMO the chibi scenes worked great for the comedy aspects of the show. I can never get enough chibi Sawako. Warning, there’s a lot of those sudden shoujo bubbly, flowery backgrounds. Hope that’s not a deal-breaker for anyone.


The sound was spectacular across the board. I loved every seiyuu’s performance, but if I had to pick my favorite, it would probably be Yuuko Sanpei as Chizu. She really made that particular character come to life. As far the OPs/EDs, they’re all good, but the OP1 is the stand-out for me. The sweet and gentle melody captured the feel of the show so well.


I thoroughly enjoyed season 1 of Kimi ni Todoke. Yes, the plot was somewhat generic and the romantic element moved slowly, but everything about the show was just so darn endearing. It’s a 9.5/10 in my book, and if I wasn’t so stingy giving out 10s (less than 3% as of writing this), I would probably round up to 10. Please watch this series if you can withstand a little bit of cheesiness. It’s a real gem.

This is my first review, but I've watched a bunch of shoujo anime and yeah.  If you've read any other reviews on KimiTo, you probably think very positively already, and you should be!
[8]Story:  The only reasons why I gave KimiTo an 8 and not a 10, is because of the simplicity of the story itself and some moments that lack originality.  But if you do plan to watch KimiTo, then be prepared for a VERY slow pacing.  In my view, the slow pacing in this anime was very well executed and it made KimiTo stand out over the other rom/coms.I thought each and every moment between the main characters was fairly important, and it made the storyline have greater purpose.  The best thing I love about the story though, is the fact that KimiTo focuses more on romance rather than comedy.  The comedy is just a good relief factor to ease the tension, and I've got to say the comedy in KimiTo is priceless.


[9]Art:  The basic animation in KimiTo is well made and easy to look at.  The reason why I bumped the score up to a 9 is because of the picture moments.  I don't know how to clearly explain it unless you've seen it, but each time you see one of these scenes it amazes you.


[10]Sound:  Voice actors and actresses are amazing.  Sawako's voice actress was meant to play her, and all the other voice actors and actresses do very well at their part as well.  I especially liked Kurumi's voice.  The opening and closing themes are AMAZING!  The opening theme was named Kimi Ni Todoke, so it fits perfectly with a soothing rythem.  The ending theme was a female role, and well, you've got to hear it.


[9]Character:  Almost a perfect 10, but the reason why I gave a 9 is because the other main characters weren't fully developed, so I would have prefered to have more development toward the main guy and girl.  Also, Joe is annoying sometimes! XD But the main guy and girl characters are very well developed, except for the fact that we don't have the guy's thoughts explained well enough.  Nevertheless, still a solid 9.


[10]Enjoyment:  Every single freaking episode, I wanted to keep going to the next.  Every moment I savored, and this has got to be one of the most enjoyable animes I've ever watched.


[10]Overall:  Despite the 8 for Story, and 9's for Art and Character, this was one of the best animes I have ever watched in my life.  Gladly, there is a second season to finish off the series.  I do hope that there will even be a 3rd season though @_@.


So yeah, I'd reccommend this anime to any of the shoujo fans out there.  (:

What a cute and wholesome love story.  Sawako is a quiet and shy girl who keeps to herself.  She ends up talking with and falling for a boy named Shota.  She has never had friends so she doesn't understand the normal social rules.  She is herself and that's why the story is so beautiful.  A beautiful relationship forms from this two as well as Sawako and two other girls which help her.  I truly enjoyed this story because of that wholesome feel.  You typically don't get that out of an anime, and this anime really broke free ofthat label.  The only thing I didn't like were some of the episodes were a little slow and left you with terrible cliff hangers.  When you don't have the full season out to watch it's nerve wracking to wait until the next week to see what finally happens or if their romance will finally blossom.  It's definitely a love story that you won't forget.

I think if everyone in the world would sit down and watch this Anime and walk away knowing how simple it can be to change the life of someone this world and it's inhabitants would be better off. It takes one person to start a chain reaction that affects not just one person but many. Amazing is the only word I can use to describe this and that doesn't seem to adequate. I could go on and on about this show but I think the only thing that matters is you sit down and WATCH this show.

This anime made me cry and laugh all the time. The story line was amazing, it showed the character development and everything ran smoothly. Nothing was too rushed or too slow, everything happened at a really nice pace. This anime is nice for those who enjoy reading/watching high school romances. Kimi Ni Todoke had me screaming at my computer screen and drowning in a pool of feels. It really captures how two people fall in love and the troubles that come a long with it.
Once I started watching, I couldn't stop. The characters and the simple story line had me hooked and reeled in. Iimmediately fell in love with the characters (with the exception of a few...) and how this anime really highlights friendship as an important part of life.

This is only the second time i have watched a show that had me literally laughing and smiling and feeling in every single episode. Kimi ni Todoke managed to pull ahead as my favorite Rom/Com through its awesome characters, and the wonderful development that went with them. 
A heart warming story of friendship and love blossoming hit home with me. Seeing the growth of an individual who finds unexpected friendships in even more unexpected kinds of people shows you just how amazing we can be as human beings. We can put aside our differences and be a part of others lives in ways you wouldnever expect. 


Seeing a shy, and gloomy looking girl become friends with a tom boy, a makeup wearing pretty girl with an attitude, and a the most popular guy in school certainly puts ones mind to wondering how that could even happen. However, this show manages to show that progression in such a natural, and heart warming way, that i never found myself questioning that. 


Itazura na Kiss must now step aside and let Kimi ni Todoke take it's place as my favorite Rom/Com

Story: 10\10
I love how the plot and story is simple. It follows the life of a school girl, Sawako, who is shy and misunderstood. Despite her scary looks, she has a really pure heart and she's very innocent and pure. The pace is very slow, but in no way is it dull. The girl is going through changes, so naturally, to change, it takes you time. changing can't just happen with the blink of an eye, and this is why I loved this anime so much. The pace was perfect to make me understand every part of the story.
And can I add how much Iloved the fact that it wasn't cliche in any way? Abuse and violence wasn't romanticized and the main character didn't get harassed by the guy of her dream and then called him "BAKA\HENTAI"!!!. I can say that this was a first for me in anime. And the time where there were bullies, they were teasing a certain character, and the bullies were considered pathetic and they were the ones who were losers.

Art: 7\10

I thought the art was good. It wasn't the best, but it certainly was good and well drawn. Something that annoyed me a little is that I wasn't able to know if some characters were goodlooking or not since they were all drawn in an appealing way. Other than that, the art was cute and the eyes weren't exaggerated, which is something that I found beautiful.


Sound: 10\10


I loved the opening theme and ending theme so much! They really set the mood and the lyrics were quiet good. The opening theme will always touch my heart. As for the voice actors, they were very good in conveying the emotions of the characters, and I didn't find any of them to be annoying haha. There was no "overly cute anime voice" that made you think one of the characters was 4 years old. I really liked the voices.


Character: 10\10

Oh man, I don't know where to start! Each character has its own personality and all the characters have their flaws and imperfections.

Kazehaya, the main guy, isn't this typical anime guy. He is not a hot perverted who falls head over heels for the girl and teases her a lot and plays with her emotions. Nor does he sexually harass her. He is in fact as shy as she is! He blushes and he has many flaws that we later find out as we get deeper in the story.

The beautiful thing about those characters is that they are realistic and there was no exaggeration in their personalities. They all have their flaws and imperfections. Even the bad guys aren't 100% bad. Also, we were able to see a reason for the actions of all the character; (they did this when that happened which means they have this trait, and their personality is like that).


Enjoyment: 10\10

As I said, in no way was the story dull, and there was always something happening, from a quirky, funny thing that somebody did, to a line or an action that a character said or did which will break your heart and makes your stomach hurt.


Overall: 10\10

This is a masterpiece. I have never ever seen anything like that. It was in all means beautiful.


I say there should be season 3, since the story is not over yet. If you ever end with the anime, I say you continue with the manga because more things happen that make you understand the characters even more and love them even harder.

The manga is as beautiful as the anime, and the anime was pretty faithful to the manga except for the last episode of season 2, which was a bit different. If you don't want to miss anything, just read the chapter of the final episode.



Anyway, this is one of the best things I have ever seen and I will always love this anime\manga.

A short review about Kimi ni Todoke. No spoilers are present (as it should be).
I haven't watched many episodes, but I was eager to write a review this anime.
Story:
Well, it can embarrassingly emotional and juvenile, but also sweet. So if that's up your alley, then this is perfect. There is not much action, but rather talking instead.
Regarding genre, it would be most likely be categorized as Comedy, Romance, and Slice of Life.
So this anime is suitable if you feel like watching something a bit slower paced. 8/10.
Art:
Well, the art is normal. Sometimes the characters make weird faces, usually cute/adorable or weird/creepy (but not a "scary"creepy) ones. There may be a lot of background sparkles. Just so you know. So many sparkles... and flowers. 8/10.\n\n
Sound:\n
The BGM music has a lot of slow piano playing, with lots of sentiment and flourishes. But this is very soothing and pleasant. There can also be light strumming on a string instrument, guitar, or percussion (e.g. chime, xylophone), or lightly synthesized music. The opening and ending theme songs are both pleasant. Great! 9/10.\n\n
Character:\n
The main heroine can be a bit frustrating to watch, but if you will bear with her, she can be quite endearing and a satisfying leading character. The other characters are quite funny, but display a broad variety of emotions. But I like how these characters are not one dimensional. 8/10.\n\n
Enjoyment:\n
I'm enjoying this. If you like romantic comedies... well, this *is* a romantic comedy. So expect the things that romantic comedies have. I don't think I have giggled and blushed simultaneously so much in such a short time... 10/10.\n\n
Overall:\n
I'm rating this 9/10 overall because I enjoy the story and the characters. The music works great with the art and the feeling of the show, and all these are making it quite enjoyable. Watch this if you enjoy a bit of drama, teenagers in love, and all that!\n\n
Quick Summary:\n
- It's a romantic comedy, so expect as such. Ah, young love and love triangles... \n
- It's actually quite funny. (I like the Japanese version with subtitles most. Good job voice actors!)\n
- If you don't like the first few episodes, well... this anime might not be for you. But if you like a good laugh from all the situational comedy, then stick around!\n\n
I hope you enjoy! ^_^

With a sweet story and endearing characters, this was a good anime. So why did I give it a seven?
I enjoyed the story. It was filled with feel-good moments, the occasional cliché and lots of blushing. It did get repetive after a while, but I finished it, and I'm glad I did. Unfortunately, the main flaw lies in Sawako. 
I liked the characters. Kazehaya was kind from the start, which was a nice break from the usual tsundere love interests.
 I especially liked Ryuu, though I do have a tendency to favor quieter characters. Sadly, i just didn't see what I wanted to see fromSawako. Though she did grow, there were flaws. But in the end, she wasn't a bad character, I just wish we would've seen a little more out of her.




The artwork was truly lovely. I can't really describe it in a way that would do it justice, but believe me, even if you hate everything else about this series, you'll love the art.




To conclude, I enjoyed this anime. It had a sort of calm feeling about it.


The romance was cute and innocent, and though it was slow, I didn't mind. So, even if this isn't your cup of tea, watch an episode or two. You never know. Maybe it'll be your new favorite.

Kimi ni todoke was a refreshing change of setting for me, especially after watching the Kara no Kyoukai series. I had actually watched the first few episodes of this anime a few months ago, but had dropped it because I was getting tired of it. I had thought that it was boring and kind of repetitive.
I was wrong. I'm glad that I gave it another chance.
This anime started out unassuming and looked like any other shoujo anime that I'd seen before, but there were several characteristics that stood out from the rest. Our main character, Sawako, is an extremely shy girl that is trying herbest to change her life for the better. She is a lonely girl, with only one childhood "friend" from her middle school. Sawako is then put into a classroom with completely new faces all around. But there is one face that she recognizes and admires, Kazehaya.\n
Unlike other animes, the relationship isn't actually determined from the very start, but grows as the two main characters get to know each other better. We see why Kazehaya is so popular and why Sawako falls in love with him. For this reason, I like how this anime respects its viewers and not throw them into a relationship that feels forced. \n
No, no. As Sawako continues on her quest to make new friends and do what all other ordinary girls do, Sawako grows into a beautiful character that most viewers can't help but fall in love with. To make an analogy, she is like a blank sheet of paper at the start at the series. By the end of it, all of her friends and experiences draw rainbows, stars, hearts, and love onto the canvas. The environment that she is shown to grow up in really brings her personality to life. The one thing I couldn't help but think about was that what kind of loneliness and suffering she went through before the start of the series. It kind of makes me sad, seeing as she was so isolated from others that she never had a chance to grow until the start of the series. \n
I've just been going on and on about Sawako so lets move on to Kazehaya. Kazehaya is a good person. I really like that about him. He is nice, looks out for others, and gets along with people easily. But underneath that outgoing face he puts up, he's just as shy as Sawako. They both are so similar to each other and yet so different. \n
Chizu and Yano I actually thought that they were going to rip Sawako apart at the beginning, but I'm glad that they turned out to be caring friends. I'm actually surprised at the amount of depth they went into Chizu. But I would have wanted to know more about Yano as a person. \n
The characters in this anime are the story; their interactions, stories, and reactions to situations is what makes it so cute. You can't help but cheer on Sawako and all the other characters when they run into trouble. It's a realistic anime and lovable at the same time. \n
Art: The art was okayish. I didn't really enjoy it as much, but its to be expected when watching one of the older animes. Sometimes Kazehaya's smile is so wide I think that it might snap in half. It bothered me a few times, but I got used to it as the series progressed. \n
Sound: I actually enjoyed the sound quite a bit. The opening was one of my favorite songs. The soundtrack during the anime was quite fitting and nice, with its sweet and mellow tones flowing as the characters went on with their days. I didn't really like the ed though. The tone of the singer didn't agree with my ears.\n
Enjoyment: I enjoyed this anime very much. It had some slow pacing that would probably make some of my friends freak out, but I actually enjoyed it. It's characters are ones that are not only realistic, but also are easy to fall in love with because they're human. They have flaws like all the rest of us but their strengths more than makes up for that. I liked this anime.\n
Overall: This anime is not one to skip out on if you are into romance and slice of life animes. Watch it or read it. It doesn't feel forced and you'll keep on wanting to press the next episode button.

Kimi ni Todoke is a classical shojo. The story is the usual: a girl who is avoided by everyone, suddenly meet a boy who slightly fit her amidst people.
As far as the art, the drawings are simple but effective, not the best I've ever seen, but still good drawings. 
The dubbers are very good, as well as the OST ( Tamizawa Tomofumi's openings are great ). 
The characters are very interesting, the main is a very shy girl and her shyness is  almost the reason of all the funny moments of the anime. Other funny characters are Pin, Ryu and Chizu. 
Concluding, this animealternates funny and tragical moments, the story is simple, even so it will probably touch you.

When i haven't started to watch this anime i thought that it will be an anime like Itazura na Kiss, Lovely Complex ect... 
I like kind of stories what are about a girl and her hardship with friends, school, love or an absence of a family member. 
As i was wathcing more and more episodes i had to realize that this story is different from the other animes what i have ever seen from this genre. 
I have never given genre like love, shoujo, comedy romance worse point than 9 but now i did it. 
At first i very liked the characters in the endthis love turned into hatred because of their hesitation. I got bored myself on the last few episodes. I hoped that my expection will be happened in the end...\n\n
I think the grafic could have been better for an anime what was made in 2009-2010.\n\n
All in all i gave 8/10 because most of the scenes were very interesting and caught my attention.

"I don't know how I handled loneliness. I can't remember how I dealt. All of that has escaped me. Without a trace."
[Plot]
Communication relies on a message from one human to another being interpreted correctly. Sawako Kuronama—a beautiful, selfless, misunderstood girl—enters high school with the same middle school social status she was given: a ghost. Not an invisible ghost, but a scary living, walking one. Her abnormal facial expressions and difficulty socializing landed her a spot as an outcast. She's exceptionally friendly and attempts to say hello to everyone she meets, but her initial—slightly funny—facial expressions cause them to flee away. That is, until the catalystknown as Shouta Kazehaya enters Sawako's life. He single handedly gives her the "ability" to destroy her comfort zone and widen her world. Don't be mistaken though, he is not the all-powerful male protagonist who manages to alone save her. Sawako's best friends Ayane Yano and Chizuru Yoshida are precious gems who stay by her side regardless of situation, helping her grow.


[Characters]

Love. Platonic, Romantic, Unrequited. Love. This is a romance anime, love is expected. What I did not expect was how well platonic love was portrayed. The protagonists and their supporting friends are genuinely good people. It is not easy to create such realistic relatable characters. 


For starters, Sawako is truly selfless. Not in an annoying, pathetic way; she is not a burden. She always attempts to create a clear line of communication, probably because she knows how it misunderstandings can be so cruel. Aesthetically, she is relatively pretty with long, black hair and bangs that suite her face. She is still new to social interaction, so sometimes she takes messages too literally, but in the end if it's important, she will find out through her own will. Sawako doesn't attract attention by means of pity or sympathy, she draws in people one they take the opportunity to know her. As she begins to become closer to her newfound friends, her character rapidly develops. 


Shouta Kazehaya, every girl's love interest, falls for Sawako. However, the romance is not immediate—in fact it's awfully slow paced to be frank—but it's not boring either. The success of a romance anime heavily relies on the male protagonist too, and Kazehaya exceeds expectations. As a handsome, outgoing boy with a killer smile; he has girls fawning over him. His cute, polite personality and kind heart earn him a popular position in school. As an active member of the community, he his generally liked by everyone and receives little-to-no hate. He's almost equally as flustered as Sawako during their encounters, a "refreshing" factor. Unlike many other stereotypical male protagonist, he blushes, and get's embarrassed too. Shockingly, as much as Sawako looks up to Kazehaya, he is equally as memorized by her as she is by him. 

Not only does the male protagonist surpass my expectations, Sawako's new found friends Ayane and Chizuru are remarkably impressive. 


Ayane, a beautiful adult-like classmate of Sawako's, is exceptionally mature and intelligent. She wears plenty of makeup, has full lips and a great figure, and could easily be dismissed as a "popular" pretty girl, but instead she opts for the "badass" look. Her perceptive abilities are impressive and she's an awfully considerate person. Being slightly more mature, Ayune dates plenty of older people and has the most "experience" out of the group. She has no issues socializing and more often than many others thinks before she speaks. 


Chizuru—a tall, strong, and athletic girl—is probably the most friendly and second most emotional of the bunch. She's very expressive, not in a rude way but in a funny way. The best way to describe her thought process most of the time would be "simple". She isn't stupid or any of the sorts, but she's nowhere near as observant as Ayane. 


Both Chizuru and Ayane were best friends in middle school, and Sawako managed to fit into the group perfectly. They value Sawako's friendship and help her expand her horizons. Initially, they were a little freaked out by Sawako, but once they were able to get to interact with her, they immediately accepted her. Realizing that Sawako was actually friendly and tremendously kind-hearted, the two considered her a good friend. They are extremely reliable friends and worthy of Sawako's admiration.The pair—especially Ayane—often assists Sawako with her relationship with Kazehaya. In fact, if it weren't for Ayane I doubt Sawako would have the courage to even reach out to Kazehaya. 


Ryu Sanada is the fifth link to the group of five. He's a quiet, observant, baseball playing boy. If he's not likeable then he's certainly not dislikeable. He provides great advice and blunt answers. . Ryu also is willing to listen to any of friend's problems.  He's considered a part of the group and is invited to all activities involving the friends. Not to mention the fact that his room is most-often the area most used to host the parties/get-togethers. 


Her parents are really supportive and kind.


[Features]

There are plenty comical moments that caused me to burst out laughing. Sawako's facial expressions, and sometimes simple misunderstandings are hilarious. The art is pretty, and switches at times to a more cartoonish style, especially when facial expressions are made. Characters are well designed, the main ones are all aesthetically pleasing. 


The OP and ED are pleasant, good lyrics and an enjoyable voice. Character voices are great and fitting. 


To me, the best most notable aspect of this anime would be not the romance, but the bonds between the characters. Sawakos' development is outstanding. Her two friends Ayane and Chizuru don't feel uncomfortable at all around the "awkward" Sawako, and Sawako isn't an introvert, she's just new to socializing. 


The romance itself is quite slow, but certainly does develop over time. Kazehaya seems to be slightly more confident than Sawako, but not confident enough to bluntly confront her. Sawako misses a couple of hidden messages, being the slightly oblivious girl she is. The two are a great couple, if the pacing of the romance were a little quicker the anime would have soared. 


If you have any interest in the Romance or Shoujo genre, then I highly suggest watching this anime. Though don't come in for the Romance, think of it as a nice sprinkle on a Slice of Life anime. 


Thanks for reading!

Have you ever felt like you where right next to the characters watching relationships develop? This is what this anime had me feel like.(NOTE:My opinion may be quite biased because I'm just a sucker for shoujo anime.) I felt like i was a part of the story, and that i have yet to experience until now.
Story-10- You may think this is just your average anime, nothing special about it,thats what i thought at first, but then it is so much more.The story is about a girl name Sawako. She looks creepy (Something like the girl from "the ring".) People call her sadako because they thinkthat name fits her. She is nice and kind but she is kind of an outcast, who doesn't really want to be one. One summer day she meets Kazehaya, a kind guy who is lost trying to find the school.(Turns out he is Mr.Lively, almost the complete opposite of Sawako.) He then helps her get friends and fit in more during the year;what goes on next are love triangles, misunderstandings, and alot more.(NOTE:You may think ending is incomplete but there is a second season to answer all of the questions left unanswered.)



Art-10- At first you may think "The art is not all that good", but as the series progresses you will understand why the art is the way it is. It complements the story and characters. IMO i don't think the voices and story could be the same without the art as the way it is. 9.5 out of 10.


Sound-10- The voices are superb. They fit the characters perfectly. (There aren't any voices that don't fit the characters.) The opening and ending songs are good too. Soft melodies with a catchy beats. Also in some part during the show soft music complements certain thing, and was good too.


Character-10- I don't want to spoil the plot and the good characters, but i have to say the characters complement each other nicely and if one was removed the story would not have been what it was.


Enjoyment-10- This anime kept me on my toes,and i liked that. I was engulfed in it and did not want to stop watching it (ended up watching it straight through). If you are a shoujo anime fan than this is definitely a must watch. Also if not this anime could make you a fan.

This anime will pull at your emotions with one moment you are laughing and then the next something serious happens, and then you are clinging to the edges of your seat waiting to watch the next episode. 
This anime will make you gnaw at your fingernails as you imagine what it would be like in the shoes of the main characters! 
It has amazing plots, and its characters are cute and the art is amazing. I love its opening songs, and it's unique in the sense that the main character is a lonely, friendless girl who is too considerate and kind, but very very shy.This anime not only centres around romance, but friendship love as well, and how important it is. It follows the steps to achieving amazing friends with amazing character developments, and how a loner, shy girl finds friends and eventually the guy she likes. \n
I really loved this anime, and it's on my top list for romance anime along with Lovely Complex, and I really recommend you to watch it! You will be crying by the end of the series, and find yourself rooting for the characters every step of the way! It's not so deeply engrossed in romance of girlfriend and boyfriend that it becomes sort of annoying, but it deals with friendship problems, bullies, and even your friend's boyfriend/girlfriend messes. \n
Watch it!

Kimi ni Todoke starts off with REALLY high potential, then ends up dying midway and just feels like some sort of comedy, slice of life, drama, chibi character series.
The romance in this series is SO dried out, and starts off fresh but just keeps going on with no progression at all.
Story: 4/10
Starts off very nice with the fun aspect of the main character Sawako being a creepy girl who no one likes. This is funny the first 2 episodes, but then just progresses on and you just sit there thinking WHY? 
Art: 5/10
I enjoyed this art, even though the character designs were simple they werepretty, i would give 9/10 for character art. However, the amount of times the art is drawn as chibi weirdo characters and bubble backgrounds is just plain annoying and ugly. Even in serious moments ALL the characters are chibi (weird) and you are going to sit there thinking the anime didn't have a big enough budget.\n\n
Sound : 7/10\n
Good, nothing extraordinary\n\n
Character: 4/10\n
This is the main problem in the series. The main character has mental problems I'm sure of it. She keeps crying over NOTHING, she has NO back bone, and she doesn't even speak to people. Yeah i get she's supposed to be nice but she's a pushover, and barely talks to her friends... She's also extremely shy to the point of being scared to tell her parents she wants to go to a party etc.\n
Her two main friends, Ayane, the cliche pretty girl with loads of boyfriends and Chizuru, the dumb airhead tomboy, are plain boring, nice though nothing special.\n
The main guy Kazehaya is nice, but popular for no specific reason other than he is nice?? yeah alright, all girls at the school apparently like him and spread rumours like children to get him, when he's nothing special but a nice person... Also his love for Sawako comes out of nowhere...\n\n
Enjoyment: 6/10\n
If you look past the flaws it's quite funny and relaxing. It's a good anime to watch if you're bored and have nothing else to do, and want a little pure romance (even though the lack of romance is quite comical)\n\n
Overall: 6/10\n
The romance is quite bad and is just two people liking each other for the hell of it. This show is more like a slice of life/drama than a romance (don't expect any kisses, holding hands nothing). But it is SOOOO unrealistic. When watching this you're just gonna cringe because it's just plain weird.\n
It's an alright anime, just not something i would ever give more than a 6.\n
TBH I'm very surprised about all the 10/10 reviews and ratings.. Was nowhere near that.

*NO SPOILER REVIEW*
Before you watch "you've got the wrong idea" THE anime, you have to ask yourself...
Do you crave awkwardness between characters? 
Do you like cringing when a character does something stupid? 
Would you enjoy watching two characters struggle to form even somewhat of a relationship?
Well I enjoy these being the romcom type of guy I am but, this.. THIS.. was just too painful.
STORY: 6
It's the classic cookie cutter romance anime. It doesn't mean that it's bad, it's just nothing special. Although the Chizu story line did peak my interest, the rest of the story just couldn't make up for it. The struggle toform even the slightest of a bond was mostly what put me off, considering the length of the series.

Awkwardness between characters can really add to a RomCom anime, it's just when nearly every scene is worthy of a filthy frank award, it's too much.


ART: 9

The art is very aesthetically pleasing and very well done. There is no drop in quality throughout the entire series.

Everyone is adorable and I feel the need to protect them OK.


SOUND: 8

There is nothing special about the sound, although the opening for season 1 did boost the rating as I am biased for a good OP. (to me at least)


CHARACTER: 8

Some characters are much more well-made than others. Sawako being such a creative character that i'm not completely sure how they made such a bland, uninteresting and generic male counterpart. The supporting cast is also well designed, even the characters that barely speak are interesting in their own way.


ENJOYMENT: 7

Although I did mostly talk about the negativity in the anime, I can't lie that I did enjoy it. Even as much as this anime made me want to drop it, it still got me to watch it all the way through to the end- and that's saying something I guess. But for real, it's still worth a watch (like every anime ever lol) it may seem generic and silly but at the end of the day it'll warm your heart.

And that's pretty much what you want out of a RomCom, to feel fuzzy and happy I guess.


OVERALL: 7

Kimi Ni Todoke is a cute story, although cluttered with poor choices and characters (mind you, not THAT many) it still left me satisfied.

I would recommend it to any RomCom enthusiast but other than that, watch some My Little Monster or something beforehand.

I don't usually watch romances. The constant slow pans of lovers looking at each other, the blushes as they quickly look away, the gasps as they say each other names, etc; I just find it all too hilarious and tedious to get into the show.
Now you would think based on my score Kimi ni Todoke must've done away with these tropes. You would be wrong. Kimi ni Todoke has enough blushes, slow pans, and gasps to last me a decade. Not to mention enough inner monologuing to make me feel I was reading a novel. Oh, did I forget to mention the classic misunderstanding trope,where characters refuse to communicate with each other for more than 5 seconds and therefore it takes a couple of episodes for conflicts to be resolved? Cause it has that too.


So why the hell do I like this show? It's simple really. It's because of the characters.


While this show may classify as a romance, I see this more as a story of friendship. Sawako may be the sweetest MC I have ever watched. I can't help but like her. Her pure-hearted way of tackling things made me want to root for her, and that pure-heartedness is mirrored in her friend Chizuru, a brash loudmouth that couldn't act more differently than Sawako yet be more similar at the same time. Then there's Ayane, who's more experienced and perceptive, with such a mischievous personality that she can't help herself from teasing her friends. The two males of the friend group are just as likable. Kazehaya, Sawako's love interest, is a popular guy with a kind heart but naive and shy enough that he isn't as confident as he appears to be. Ryu, Kazehaya's best friend, is aloof and disinterested but still willing to help out his friends in his own way. The interactions and relationship between these 5 friends are what made me enjoy the show so much. They're genuine people, and it's nice to watch them.


Kimi ni Todoke is a romance, and a slow-paced one at that. Sawako and Kazehaya sure like taking their time getting with each other. But despite that, I rarely felt bored. The cast of characters is just so damn heartwarming that I had a stupid smile on my face nearly every episode. If you wanna watch something that lets you relax and feel good inside, this is it.

A fairly short review on Kimi Ni Todoke. 
Don't get me wrong, I liked the show, but I just can't rate it more than a 7. For me the show didn't click completely and I'll tell you why. 
The story is fantastic, I have to give the creators credit for this. They put us in a realistic situation with circumstances we could relate to. The show felt like it really was happening and I have to say this is one extremely good storyline. 
The art is a slight downside for me, at some points the art was a bit pale for me lacked color anddepth. Blending for me was off but maybe that's because it's kind of old. So I had to rate the art a 7 as it lacks a bit of cleanliness. \n\n
The dubbing quality was decent but I have to say that the acting was quite well done. But sound effects and music for me were off and didn't click the circumstances together for me. \n\n
The characters were an absolute joy to watch, they were realistic and incredibly relatable. There were a few moments where I was cringing slightly, but that's just because of the MC's voice. Otherwise the characters have thorough back stories and the roads they take are quite intriguing to witness. \n\n
I enjoyed the show quite immensely but then why am I rating it a 7? It lacked in the visual aspects and there was a certain lack of depth to the story. And I'll tell you why. Read the manga.

This anime is wholesome overall, and the characters are loveable as well as detailed. The art is beautiful and flawless. I can only give sound an 8 since it became repetitive after 8 or 9 episodes, and most of the tracks inside the movie is a cover of either OP or ED. I would give this anime a 10 without a doubt, but it is so slow that it gets bored. It isnt exagurate to say that half of the anime is either Sawako or Kazehaya getting flustered at each other, which stands for why my enjoyment is only 7. Even for a Romance genreaddict such as myself, this anime is still way too slow for my taste.

Short and sweet review. Do you know what to expect from romance anime and are tired of people pointing out the "genre stereotypes" and then judging the anime around that? Just want to know if you should watch it? I got you covered
SO many people who watch romance anime use this one as their measuring stick. I can understand why. But it just wasn't that magnificent for me.
The main issue with this one is the pacing and then the blatantly obvious turn the show takes to draw out the story to unnecessary lengths.
If the show had been condensed into a 13 episode season, or even23-26 episodes, it would have benefited. The female MC was very interesting at first. The extreme level of her awkwardness and level of outcast was fun to watch. But after two seasons of moving at a snail's pace with the MC's relationship, it gets EXCRUCIATING. After watching several other romance anime's where, at least EVENTUALLY, the MC's actually show some real love towards each other AND are able to express it without some issue causing misunderstandings, this one is hard to give a great review.\n\n
HIGHLIGHTS: Music got stuck in my head, is fun for the first ~13 episodes\n\n
DISAPPOINTMENTS: Not much progress, loses its way after first season, SLOWER THAN A SNAIL MOVING THROUGH MOLASSES with regards to the MC's relationship, MISUNDERSTANDINGSSSSSSSssss

The manga is SO much better. The first time around, I had just read Kimi Ni Todoke, and I was just really looking for more Sawakaze. But the second time around I found it very slow and without much character development. The issue is the pace for me. With the manga, so much is happening with the other characters the pace didn't bother me as much. But the anime obviously didn't have as much time so it was cut short for the sake of making "convenient" season 1 & 2 finales. The final version is being published in English in December, so if you likedthe first season for the story, but not the pace, I'd read the manga.

Edited: Got the right quote and a better look at the visuals and plot.
"I'm sorry, Sadako! Don't say you'll be all right by yourself. Don't you get it? We love being around you! Don't you see?... We've been friends all along, Sadako."
I think that, in order to appreciate this show, you have to see it from the eyes of the heroine, Sawako "Sadako" Kuronuma (evidently you need to watch The Ring in order to appreciate the nickname, but there are long-haired yokai in Japanese folklore, so that works for me). Socially awkward, a bit airheaded, not really understanding why people freak out around her, andwith a heart of pure gold. Let her draw you in, and laugh at the teens not understanding who she is, and at her innocent attempts to learn how to communicate.


This is a romantic comedy, but because the early chapters of the manga emphasized comedy over romance, the actual story proceeds at a bit of a slow pace. I think this was a good choice, since it allows us to get to know not just Sawako, but also Shouta, Chizuru, Ryu, and Ayame. Series 1 is faithful to the original, and the dramatic (melodramatic, even) moments are emotionally powerful because of the strength of the manga. Two such scenes stand out: one where Sawako resigns herself to being alone, until Shouta asks "Hey, can someone trade me a seat next to her?" The other is when Sawako is bullied by other girls, and Chizuru and Ayame walk right in to save the day. When this show gets dramatic, it cranks it up to 11, so have some tissues handy.


The premise of a girl, of whom everyone had such a terrible first impression, that she's written off as "creepy" and avoided like she's radioactive or something, is more than a little ridiculous, but it is a comedy. At the same time, when the supporting characters realize just what a genuinely good girl she is, they start to change. Shouta starts inviting her along and offers to sit with her, and Chizuru and Ayame not only take a liking to her, but smile at her innocence and truly become angry when she's mistreated, effectively becoming her best friends.


I guess if there's a weakness in the show, it's the character of Shouta (but only a little). I generally don't find "flawless" characters believable, even if he says "I'm not as good as you think". But I guess his big weakness is Sawako herself, so I can live with that. The casting, from Mamiko Noto's Sawako to Aya Hirano's Kurumi is spot on.


Visually, the show is pretty good, often using cute SD characters during funny or relaxed moments. The fingers distracted me a bit-- to me they were so long and skinny, they almost looked like chopsticks. (I'm actually struggling to remember the visuals and story, as this is a show I need to re-watch. I DO remember, however, that Sawako's smile is a heart-melting moment in the show. Shouta, you lucky bastard.) OK, now that I'm re-watching it... it looks like the post-production added in a noisy coloration through Photoshop or a similar editor. I might be mistaken, but the original may have used "noisy" tones to make the backgrounds and scenery look more real, and this is the animators' way of replicating that effect.


The opening theme song is a good love song, featuring Sawako in various cute situations. But Kimi ni Todoke is a song that I probably won't import-- the reason is, the "short" version is probably an early arrangement with just standard band instruments plus piano. The finished arrangement adds a number of instruments (at least a flute and synth set to sawtooth) that in my opinion diluted the great vocals. The end credits theme is cloyingly sweet, which means that I probably skipped over it often. Most of the soundtrack is fairly simply composed and arranged, staying out of the way for the most part and lifting up the more dramatic scenes.

Kimi ni Todoke screams average. The anime lacked character development and the plot moves much too slow. The characters were flat and didn't have much substance to them. I could say I enjoyed the art as it had a soft texture to it, but it didn't really stand out compared to other animes. The soundtrack was suitable but not memorable whatsoever. To be honest, I couldn't even make it through the first season because of how boring it was. Each move was predictable and not very suspenseful. I'm not saying the anime was *bad*, it was just so typical and the plot was a bitoverrused: unpopular, quiet yet innocent and kind girl with a popular and athletic, yet super friendly boy. They also have a small crew of friends who have their own problems with crushes and so forth. If you're into this type of innocent anime, then I recommend Kimi ni Todoke, but if not, there are much better animes out there.


To begin, characters. They were just so stereotypical and predictable. Also a little annoying. For example, Sawako, the protagonist. Her voice was super annoying in my opinion. High-pitched, breathy, and constantly stuttering over her words. Her innocent and naive personality became much too forced and unfortunately did not allow her character to develop much. She did make a lot of friends, which I guess some would consider development, but she didn't mature based on how many episodes I watched, if that makes sense. She also didn't bare any flaws, besides owning a bit of social anxiety. For example, she cooks for her friends, she is loyal, she is kind, even to people that dislike her, and so on. The reason she did not really develop as a character, I believe, is because the anime created a lovable and cute girl bubble around her.


Next is Kazehaya. Like Sawako, he is almost flawless and super likeable. Of course, they fall for each other, because who could've seen that coming, am I right? His personality is so two-dimensional. Sure, he's friendly and sociable but that's about it. Nothing very special. Oh, and he's good-looking, like of course he is. 


I was okay with the other main (side?) characters. The anime unfortunately forced too many confusing and badly executed issues onto them in an effort to make the anime not completely Sawako and Kazehaya centered.


Overall, average anime with poor development. There are definitely better animes out there so I suggest not to waste your time watching Kimi ni Todoke. Literally.

If you were to read the summary of Kimi ni Todoke, you'd never watch this hidden gem of romantic anime. The story is in many ways derivative and typical of shoujo romantic stories, with an innocent, straightforward, lonely girl falling in love with the popular guy in class.
Yet the story hides a special charm that grows on you the more you watch and this draws you into the world as you watch the characters grow and struggle.
The real highlights are the artwork and music which really convey the emotions and carry the viewer along. Those 2 elements is what helps lift this story and allowsus to really feel for the characters.


I had no problem with the pacing of the story which I found entirely appropriate. It allowed us enough time to get to know the characters. All the cast performed brilliantly with the seiyuu voicing sawako particularly outstanding as she had a lot of work voicing her thoughts. In many ways this story is perfect for anime because many of the comedic elements and emotion cannot be conveyed in any other medium.


Obviously the main weakness is that at the end of season 1, there is no resolution whatsoever and hence I was very lucky to come along knowing that there is a season 2 to complete the story. However, I am also aware that the manga is still ongoing.


Overall, this is an extremely easy to watch romantic comedy style anime with  charming characters, beautiful art and a heartfelt soundtrack. Highly recommended for those who enjoy such anime. Please read my review of season 2 for my overall view. Thanks!

This series starts off strong and then kind of peters off and gets bogged down. The initial character building is great - there's tons of warm and fuzzy moments as Sawako gets her first glimpse of friendship and begins to grow closer to Kazehaya...but it doesn't advance much further.
The arcs feel long and drawn out, and the typical shoujo Slice of Life High School Romance trope of miscommunication causing heaps of drama is present in its entirety, and long overstays its welcome.
However, Kimi ni Todoke makes a good effort in presenting their characters as likable, unique individuals whom you begin to care for. Which makesit even worse when you see characters you enjoy experiencing the same problems and never speaking their mind.

I will make all of my reviews shorter. I, personally, don't like reading tons of paragraph.
The story is simple and light. I like how it shifts from serious to comedy. If you are the type of person who easily bores I suggest not to drop it because the story is a slow pace. The art is very good and funny. The background in the anime is also good. I think the seiyuu is fine. I like how Kuronuma Sawako develops. Somehow, I'm kind not convince how her character is being scary just because of how her name is alike in the horror movie. I thinksome of the non anime fans would also like this. I would recommend to watch the second season.

A very fun and enjoying story to watch. 
This was a interesting story. From the art to the characters. There was very little that bugged me. 
The art is very nice and pleasing. Especially for something from 8 years ago. The scenes with the goofy animation are pretty great and the character designs are good. 
The character designs are all good. I just felt that Sawako's character design could be better. I thought that if she had her hair in a Ponytail or a bun she would look better. Later on when she does have her hair up she does look very good. She isstill pretty anyway's. I just think it would have been better if her hair was up for most of the show. In the end with her makeover she looks so nice and looks better.


Some things that i kind of found weir were : 

1. In the earlier episodes i found it weird how the entire class starts surrounding and praising  the MC kind of out of the blue.

2. The show kind of drops her being thought of as a spooky person. 


~~Spoilers~~ 

I kind of wish we got more of the romance.


Such as Ryuu and Chizuru becoming a couple. 


There are a couple people that fit really well together. Such as 

RyuuxChizuru 

SawakoxKazehaya

Kind of seems there is a thing with Ayane and  Pin going on. 


There are characters kind of forgotten such as kurumi. She had a couple episodes. Even though most seemed annoyed with her i actually liked her. I kind of like how after she fully realizes she wont get with the guy she stops acting all cute. 


Over all a good show.

I couldn't help to be bored while being interested in the show. I don't mind how long the anime is, as long as I see development and advancement then I wouldn't mind it. However, this show takes forever to conclude any side-story. I would say that it takes up to about 5 episodes to conclude one story; it should have been at least 3 episodes because it took quite awhile and a waste of time.
It was a waste of time to watch some parts of each episode because it chooses to be repitative. You heard this statement before, you've seen this flashback 4 times already,you don't need to do long pauses every second, so can we just move on from it and call it a memory to remember while watching this? No. They have to keep reminding you over and over how every character feels, and it doesn't seem necessary.


I wasn't interested in the characters, rather, I was more interested in the side stories and the main story. All the characters seemed bland and noncompetitive, they were just generic characters.  Even though the stories took awhile to conclude, it's partially what helped it to be watchable.


What also kept me going was the art style. I loved the art. Sometimes it felt great to watch while seeing the characters interact, but you'll catch that some scenes look like they were showing off their art. I am not interested in a art contest; I want to watch a show with great quality. 


I give this anime a 6/10, by the way, it was a boring romantic story.

I know I'm a bit late in seeing this anime, since it's been out for 6 years now. But I think that it is truly timeless. It's story line was breathtakingly beautiful and for me, is a worthy comparison to Clannad, the all time feels jerker of romance slice of life anime, though of course they feature different plots. I loved every part of it, and I was only able to because Sawako the female protagonist is the most sincere and humble character I have ever witnessed. She may not be as capable as others, but she tries. She tries so hard that you canfeel sympathy for her every time, but nonetheless, even if you don't, I think you will end up rooting for her till the very end. It might be a romance anime, but it explores many different types of love one can feel: familial, friendship, self love and romantic love.


Story: 10/10 One day, I found myself seeking a romance anime that would touch my heart and make me feel some type of way. And after finishing this anime, I have no regrets! I'm so glad this was the anime I settled on because from the first episode, it had my tears rolling. I usually don't cry for anime, but this one hit something in me. The entire plot plays out in such a delicate manner, where all the feels come genuinely from each character's personality type and their innocent interactions with others. This anime is kind of dragged out to 25 episodes, and I was hesitant at first if it would even be necessary to watch all 25. But after I finished this, I went straight into the second season because I just could not stop. It was addictive for me, and I would definitely watch it again. It's rated PG-13, but concepts are very simplistic and other than one or two episodes where they use a bit of offensive language, I think this anime is fairly innocent. However, perhaps the concepts of love and reasoning may be difficult for those under 13 to understand.


Characters: 10/10 I think that a huge reason why this anime was able to speak to me was because of how well each character was able to convey their emotions, their thoughts and feelings. Now I do not mean that they are 100% on every aspect, but I think it was definitely above average. The core reason why I would rate this 10/10 for the characters is because of their ability to grow. There are anime with female leads who fail to do the simplest of tasks, but then there's Sawako, a girl who truly finds it hard to understand things most of us would see as normal, but because of her humility, and her honesty, the viewer is almost able to sympathize with the reasoning behind her actions. Every time she accomplishes even the smallest of acknowledgement, one just can't help but be happy for her. She is a main character that may not always be capable but she is definitely one I could never hate because she displays qualities of the purest of heart. The male lead, Shouta, is someone who one can identify as the most popular boy in school, one sought after by a bunch of girls, one who is athletic as well as smart. Sure he sounds typical at first, but he is so much more than that. He is not full of himself, there are things he cannot do, feelings he doesn't know how to express. He is kind but he is not kind just to be kind, and he is able to see others for who they truly are. They developed his character to be able to display qualities of what it's like to be human. Instead of simply leaving him as "the perfect person", they were able to incorporate the concept that he makes mistakes too, and that's what is most lovely about it. The idea that characters are able to be who they are, imperfect, but still they receive love, and compassion. The idea that the main girl may not be the most beautiful girl in school, nor is she popular. The idea that people can be loved for their personality, even if they are not a perfect person is what is refreshing. And the way all this love is conveyed through a very "clean" story lacking in all things ecchi is what amazes me the most and I am happy that this is one of the few anime out there that doesn't need sexual components to have viewers. The other characters are just as lovely in their own right, and do share some background story to them as well, although not as much. But all the characters stick to who they are and have a firm ground on the person they see themselves as versus what they are really like, giving their character depth.


Art: 7/10 This anime's art style is not bad, and must have been good for when it first was released. However, I am watching this in 2016 where graphics have been pretty stellar. Regardless however, the art style did not bug me that much. Everything was proportional because they chose to keep the art and backgrounds rather simple. If the viewer does decide to watch the second season, I'd say the art improves but not dramatically. 


Sound: 7/10 It is what it is, and their voice actors suffice. I like the main guy's voice but other that that nothing bad stands out but there's nothing that was amazing either. The opening and closing are pleasant to hear but they do not stick in my mind very much. The second season has a better opening and closing, but that is just my opinion. 


Enjoyment: 9/10 I loved it. Definitely worth pulling an all nighter for. I'm someone who does not like skipping episodes because I want every single detail but I can imagine that someone might not be interested in watching all 25 episodes. There's a lot of parts that build up into something that pushes character growth but once finishing you might feel like wow all this was only to get this far. To each their own, but this anime was very pleasant for me. Maybe it did not hit home as hard as Clannad and Toradora did, but it is definitely one to remember for a very long time.

'Kimi ni todoke' isn't your typical shojo anime.The protagonist, Sawako, is seen as a chick-from-horror.
