Her classmates are afraid of looking at her and there are gossips that you'll get cursed if you do it for longer than 3 seconds. She's the shy and, because of it, lonely type of girl, but when she meets Kazehaya, she tries to change a bit. She's not used to having friends and the process of her developing friendships is one of the most well depicted. This anime is an emotional one, but, thankfully, it has its funny moments, too. The thing that can be annoying is the progressof Sawako and Kazehaya's relationship, but it's the kind of anime that doesn't focus on lovey-dovey things, but they aren't bad, either. The style is a bit like the K-on!'s. Music. Personally, I liked the opening and the ending. The first one is a little melancholic and fits the ambience of this production. If you survive the first episodes, you'll get sucked in and watch it with interest to the very end.

I'd like to say first off that I didn't want to watch Kimi ni Todoke when I first read about it.
From the synopsis, I thought the anime would be shallow, and that it would revolve completely around Sawako's attempt at proving she was nothing like the character from The Ring, and that she would use Kazehaya expressly for that purpose.
I have never been so wrong!
The story was sweet and innocent and cute, and very heart-warming. I found Sawako's character very unique - she's not headstrong and assertive like most other anime leads, and I think that's why I liked her so much. Yes, the storyis based on how she is feared by her classmates, but I found that that fact merely added tot he story instead of completely swallowing it. It's because of this fear that Sawako grows, and that she can grow closer to Kazehaya. 


Story: 9

Like I said above, the story was sweet and innocent. The pacing was really slow, but I kind of enjoyed it - it felt more realistic. Seriously, let's be honest - how often do romances bloom in the space of a couple days?? It can happen, but rarely. Although I enjoyed the sweetness, I admit that sometimes the problems that arose frustrated me. Nine times out of ten, the problems that surfaced were from some sort of misunderstanding, and sometimes I found myself thinking "seriously?? Just say what you meant!" However, it was a minor annoyance, because the problems do add to the anime. Also, the ending was satisfactory - I finished this anime with a smile on my face, not a frown.


Art: 9

I loved the art!! It was so airy and romantic and beautiful. I think this anime has one of the best artwork I've seen. However, I feel like the characters weren't as well drawn as the backgrounds. Sometimes their artwork was superb, like during really pivotal points, but most of the time it was just okay. The comedic artwork was perfect though - some of the portrayals of Sawako's face get me every time.


Soundtrack: 9 

The opening theme for season one was my favourite! I always watched through it, because I loved it - it matched the anime perfectly. I didn't really like the opening theme for the second season though. They should have kept the one from the first season.


Character: 10

The character development in this anime was fantastic. It was paced like the anime - slow but believable. And it wasn't super noticeable development either. You'd stop and realize that so-and-so really grew from the beginning, or something similar. And the way the characters revolved around each other was awesome as well - everyone was unique and likeable. I even liked the "bad" character! 


Enjoyment/ Overall: 10

I love love love love this anime. Like, with all my heart. It had everything I liked! And the romance that developed in this anime was so beautiful. I found myself looking forward to the next episode every time I finished an episode.

Don't wait to watch this anime! I was very reluctant to watch this anime, putting it off for about a year or so. I finally got bored enough to watch it. Once I watched the first episode I was instantly hooked, watching every moment I had time!
This anime isn't your typical comedy and romance between a girl and a guy. Usually it's the smart, beautiful girl who gains the attention from the popular boy, but in this, it's exactly the opposite. The most popular guy in the school ends up falling for a girl who is socially awkward and is cursed by her looks, beingdescribed as a character from a horror movie! She is often misunderstood to the point of people resenting being near her! I was very moved and drawm emotionally by this anime going through the tough times as well as the moments of laughter!

This series intrigued me when "Sadako" from "The Ring" was mentioned in the synopsis, nope, I wasn't exactly expecting this to be a horror/thriller kinda Anime considering the art/poster/images I've seen of Kimi ni Todoke. A lot of positive stuff in here I enjoyed every single episode and the opening and ending theme of this series is absolutely catchy, can't stop repeating "Kimi ni Todoke" on my MP3 player ;)\n\n
If you're a sucker for a good love story or maybe would like something refreshing (and a bit of frustration) then Kimi ni Todoke is recommended... While you're at it give "Lovely Complex" a go as well.

When I read reviews of this anime I thought it would be a change of pace from the typical shoujo genre. However as I began watching this anime I realized the reviews I read exaggerated this anime. The story is about a girl named Sawako, but people call her Sadako after the scary character from "The Ring." She is feared by her classmates, yet is clueless about the reason. Then she meets her savior, Kazehaya who is a nice guy. From there the story is slow paced as the two feelings grow. In some aspects the story is different from others as it does not have unnecessary misunderstanding and unrealistic situations. The realness from the anime match the setting of high school. Yet there is one thing it has that is not typical yet is disappointing and it was the ending. It didn't end bad, but it felt flat, so maybe more fun stuff will happen next season.However the anime still holds typical shoujo elements mainly in the characters. 


Never had I watch a shoujo anime where the characters looked mostly normal. The water based color softens and sweeten the anime helping tell it's cute story. You get used to the art and the fact the the main character is not a bishie which I love. Normal guys are not that sexy and I feel it draws away from the story and characters. If I knew more about art I would describe it more, but one thing I can describe is the camera angles. From the close ups, to the wide shots none of the video seems unnecessary and it all fits the anime. 


The theme songs both fit the mood of the anime as the opening is sweet, yet a little edgy and the ending softens the episode. The voice acting is nice and normal just like the characters. In the beginning Sawako soft voice bothered me until I got to know her character and realized it was the voice actor transmitting the character perfectly.


The male lead, Kakehaya, is more typical shoujo then some would admit. While he is not cold or rich he is athletic and smart. People assume he is not just because he does not play baseball anymore, but once an athlete always an athlete. Also like a lot of male leads the guy is popular with his peers both guys and girls, and the girls can be creepy. The female lead Sawako is not dumb in school and has her creepy ways, but she is too is like a lot of female leads. She is naive, kind hearted, and easily loved. The cock blocker in the season was t Kurimi and while she didn't do daring moves on Kakekaya like many cock blockers she still had that jealous behavior. Besides some typical shoujo personality traits the characters are lovable and you find yourself thinking how cute they could be. Still the sidekicks Chizu and Ayane stole the show as they brought the aspect of different type of friends. They are not the type of friends you would expect Sawako to be friends with which makes it more believable. Throughout the story characters like Sawako grow while some stay neutral like Kakehaya. 


I enjoyed this anime overall and I can't wait for the second season. I would recommend this anime to someone looking for a mostly drama free story with plenty of sweet scenes. I wouldn't recommend this to someone who likes heavy drama because this anime is too sweet for you. This anime is unique in it's on little way and if you decide to watch it well enjoy :)

this is the best ever i have seen ..i have seen over more than 400 animes(most of them are love animes) this anime ignited something some kind of feeling inside my heart....i think everyone feel the same way....there is no love anime good and realistic as this one..........hats off...kimi ni todoke....one more thing...this anime is loved by japanese people itself and got several awards and made into live action movie....only a reputed famous anime will be made into live action movie ...that is kimi ni todoke~

This is my very first review. Long story short, this is my favorite anime, let me explain.
The storyline is very interesting, in episode one, you get to learn about this character, called, Sawako, she's very shy. She meets some friends later on and you get to really understand her.
This story is very heart-warming and you will never forget it, it leaves you with a sort of syrupy feeling after you finish the series. Trust me, this anime is worth watching.

This review won't be as thorough as others so I hope it would be short but sweet.
Story: 
The first few episodes start out very nicely. You see the problems surrounding the main characters and you, the audience, can relate to Sawako with her issues. This anime is definitely a romantic anime as almost everything is encircled around love. Will they confess to each other? Will they be alone together? Will they see each other again? And so on and so forth. But the love build up is wayyyy tooo slow. If you're okay with an extremely slow paced love relationship then I suggest this handsdown. 


Art: Nice art, although not the best I've seen.


Sound: Loved the opening and closing music. It's gonna be my jam for a while. 


Character: This is where I get frustrated. It's okay that the secondary characters are a bit iffy and unrealistic but it simply frustrates me to see Sawako so oblivious to everything. I won't spoil it for you guys but seriously, she needs to open up her eyes and the reality around her. She doesn't need to apologize for EVERYTHING she's done and hasn't done. She needs to wake up and see what her relationships and her feelings actually mean, of course, in the end she does, but how can her oblivion drag on to almost 25 episodes! And yes, most of the issues are caused by her oblivion, so I guess without her oblivion, there would be no show to watch.


Enjoyment:


I did thoroughly enjoyed it, if you don't count the parts where I wanted to tear Sawako to pieces because of her unrealistic oblivion towards relationships and love. 


Overall: 


You saw the name everywhere and everyone's recommending you to watch it. If you're a total romance and shoujo sucker then I definitely recommend!

I often find it hard to compare animes that I have determined to be among my favorites with other shows I have liked less because those that fit into that category tend to have something striking about them, like a particularly interesting plot, particularly interesting casts, or some other feature that just jumps out at me. Because of that, I only ever want to say is something along the lined of "Well this shows characters were awesome" or "this shows story rocked" but I can never say exactly what part of the story rocked or why the characters were awesome. In this case, I cansay exactly what makes it stand out.\n\n
The thing that makes Kimi Ni Todoke stand out is its pacing. Kimi ni is a lot like other shoujo animes in many ways. The main characters are styled much like most shoujo characters, the story, although not the most common plot, has been seen before and will surely be seen again, and the music doesn't stand out in any significant way in my mind. What makes this show stand out above the rest is the smooth story progression. Where many shoujo stories seem to come in little chunks of plot broken up by episodes with little story value beyond character development, Kimi ni devotes every episode to story progression, and that combined with it's well executed take on a classic story, interesting art (the many different art styles used in this will stick in your mind in for weeks after watching this show ;), and lovable characters will have you laughing and crying all the way to the end.

Kimi Ni Todoke is one of the most optimistic and beautiful shows that I’ve ever seen. Watching it again only made it clearer how much other shows simply do not compare. The story’s about a teenage girl named Sawako Kuronuma who, because of her scary-looking appearance, is doomed to be an outsider. But one day she meets a boy, Shota Kazehaya. And it’s thanks to this boy, and the spark that he provides in her life, that she is able to muster up the courage to try and make changes to her life. The show is then less about the love story, and more aboutSawako’s growing world, growing self-confidence, growing capacity to interact with the people around her, and how this manifests itself throughout the show (relationships, friendships, her self-esteem, and even the way she’s drawn). Sawako’s personality is ultimately what gives the show its unique aesthetic and worldview.


Sawako has remained alone throughout most of her school years. There are constant rumors and misunderstandings about her. Some say she’s cursed, some day she does black magic; all anyone can agree on is that she’s kind of creepy. It doesn’t help that any time Sawako tries to force a smile, it looks like she’s just killed her husband and drowned her children – it’s scary. But Sawako remains a bastion of positivity and optimism. She always helps out, volunteers, and does things for others, never expecting anything in return. She notices how Kazehaya always seems to be around people, talking, laughing, the center of attention; she admires that. Soon enough, he’s making an effort to include her in the dynamic of the rest of the class (going so far as to sit next to her when everyone else refuses to).


It’s because of this initial effort from Kazehaya that Sawako starts making more chances. She puts herself out there, hoping for the best. Soon enough she makes two friends, Yano and Chizu. But, even still, her self-confidence and her knowledge about these matters is so poor that she isn’t even sure that she qualifies as being a friend to them. Part of Sawako’s problem is that she’s become so accustomed to being alone that she doesn’t even recognize the importance of her own feelings. She knows of things, but has never experienced them. This is why she doesn’t even know if she qualifies as being a friend, or later why she doesn’t even understand that her feelings for Kazehaya are romantic (a shoujo standby, but given psychological depth here).


As Sawako begins to make friends, the central conflict becomes internal. It is no longer about her classmates or friends accepting her, but rather about Sawako thinking enough of herself to see herself as an equal to her peers. Most of the time she believes that she should put her wants and desires on hold to let other people get what they want. That’s why she volunteers or all the jobs that people don’t want at school – she’s completely selfless in an almost self-denigrating way. She casts herself down in order to bring up others – in order for her to aspire to become like them. Part of the growth o Sawako’s character is finding out the ways in which all the people she admires and wants to be like are all flawed in their own ways.


Even after acknowledging her feelings of love and friendship and seeing what she’s on equal ground with everyone else, she still has moments when she reduces herself again. I’d like to discuss Sawako’s “chibi” moments. I’m aware of the long history of these in anime; however, in Kimi ni Todoke, they serve an explicit thematic purpose. Sawako’s “chibi” moments are an expression of her current standing within the situation. If she feels awed by a situation or if she can’t understand it, she’ll go into that mode; her height is changed, her facial features become simplified, etc. She makes herself sub-human, even; unable to comprehend the situation she finds herself in. This is because she assumes she’s not equipped or on the same level as the people around her. It’s an issue of self-esteem. But these situations become fewer and farther in between. Part of the show’s strength is seeing Sawako rise to meet the challenge in situations that are important (notice that she does not go “chibi” in these confrontations).


There’s a formal elegance to the construction of Kimi ni Todoke that still baffles me. It is a balance that seems perfectly realized. It always seems to know exactly when to leave our mundane world behind and replace it with colors, sparkles, floral patterns – it taps into Sawako’s psyche even, and the animation is derived from her emotion. How else does one explain the pinks, the greens, the effervescence, the transcendence, the almost utopian ever-optimistic sensibility that seemingly is able to only come from being able to intensely identify with this teenage girl’s feelings?


Kimi ni Todoke believes in a world where people are good and darkness is there only to allow for opportunities to grow; it is a thoroughly uplifting vision. Through Sawako, we experience the world not as it is, but how it should be.


Note: I should mention that this write-up focuses more on the first season than anything else. The first season concerns itself more with the growth of Sawako’s inner strength and confidence, and the tentative steps she takes to have a life that she can be happy with. The second season, on the other hand, tries to resolve the romance between Kazehaya and her. As such, it’s beyond the scope of what I was focusing on in this essay. However, the second series is quite worthwhile, just necessarily different.

Though I've been known to harp on watchability, stretched out plot, unnecessary recaps, and stupid love stories, I have to say, with Kimi ni Todoke, I really didn't mind. 
It's one of the slowest things I've ever watched, plot-wise, but it has a very delicate and nostalgic feel to it that makes you want to tune in more. I'm really fond of the theme tune; it's very feel-good, and though there is a lot of repetition, I really found I didn't care. I just let myself be absorbed, sat back, and enjoyed. 
At the end, I did have a RAEGFEST since I felt cheated ofmy happy ending with a kiss/confessions of love, but then a friend pointed out to me that the second season has just begun airing in Japan this January. Thank goodness it's being continued because, JEEZ! I'm looking forward to it, but for only being 25 episodes, it took me days to get through because it really is quite a slow burn.

STORY: Well, basically Kimi Ni Todoke shows you that no one should judge a book by its cover and that sometimes people who seem weird or unfriendly turn out to  be kind and warm-hearted, afterwards.
Honestly, I cried in the middle of the 2nd episode. And for me, it's really hard to cry about something I would watch. I really can relate to Sawako's story even though I'm not like her when it comes to personality.
Even so, I know the feeling of people making false assumptions about you without even knowing the real "you".
Despite the fact that the story progress seems kinda slow and therearen't many lovey-dovey scenes, Kimi Ni Todoke is an anime that will make you cry, laugh and smile for sure.


Art: I find the art very appealing. Mostly because it emphasizes the characters' feelings and  in the end makes it look much more realistic than the common cutesy shoujo art you see every day.


Sound: This is to me the best feature in the whole anime. Throughout the series, you will recognize a collection of 22 original soundtracks including the opening by Tomofumi Tanizawa (awesome singer btw).

It just makes me feel relaxed with a warm feeling inside my heart. (cheesy but true) Whenever I hear them I feel like I want to daydream forever.


Character: From the synopsis  you realize the main character, Sawako, has a very unique personality. But she's not the only one. The supporting cast also have their particular characteristics which once again sets a different concept of what you would usually see in this genre.


Enjoyment: Kimi Ni Todoke creates a great combination of a unique plot with very amusing characters, an awesome sound compilation and beautiful, simplistic art. If you are looking for something  other than the typical romance/shoujo anime this is for you.

Kimi ni Todoke is an Anime that, while it is aimed at female teenagers, I personally loved and enjoyed all the way through. If there is a Shojo anime that guys can enjoy, this is one of them. 
Story: 9/10
The story revolves around a shy, but friendly girl named Sawako who tends to be socially awkward because of her resemblance to Sadako from "The Ring" series, giving off a creepy vibe to everyone around her. This all changes when the most popular boy of the class, named Kazehaya, starts to talk to her. The anime then continues on how Sawako becomes friends with many peopleand becomes popular among everyone at school, as well as how her feelings towards Kazehaya develop throughout the series. 


Art: 10/10

The art style is one of the greatest I have seen up to now, and I can go on and on about how pleasing the art style is. The character proportions are very well done, although the heights are a bit off for my tastes. One thing I did love of the art style is the way the characters look during different scenes. An example would be that a silly, chibi-like version of the character would be placed during a silly or funny scene, while a more adult-like or beautiful/handsome version of a character would come up on a romantic or serious scene. There are many things that can be discussed about each of the characters art style, but it's one that I will surely remember for a long time. 


Sound: 10/10

The OP and ED are very heartwarming and nice, not to mention they set the tone of the show. The songs that are played in different scenes fit well based on the situation. An example would be a silly, fast, upbeat song would play during the silly scenes. The voice acting was very nice and the VAs fit the characters very well. 


Character: 9/10

The characters are very well done, probably one of my favorite characters in all of Anime. Sawako is the shy, but sweet female protagonist who tries to make friends but is pretty socially awkward and takes a while to do so. Kazehaya is the male protagonist who's known to be the most popular guy of the class because of his kindness to others and his good nature, all while showing interest towards Sawako. Ayane and Chizuru are Sawako's best friends, where Ayane is mature and calm, while Chizuru is tomboyish and emotional. Ryu is a close friend of Kazehaya and the childhood friend of Chizuru, known to be very quiet but knows when to give support to those in need. Pin is the homeroom teacher of the group and he tends to pick on Kazehaya, since he knows him from Kazehaya's baseball days, and likes to joke around a lot, but he shows a serious and helping side when the students need it. Kurumi is a girl that has known Kazehaya since middle school and she seems like a sweet and caring girl, but there is more to her (Which is something you have to see). 


Enjoyment: 10/10

I really enjoyed the series, seeing how Sawako develops as a character throughout the series, starting out as a shy girl that no one talked with to a girl who was well known and friends with everyone. I enjoyed the silly scenes with the music that played in said scenes, and I enjoyed the scenes that were romantic or important. I also enjoyed the characters and their interactions with each other, with each of them having a unique personality. 


Overall: 10/10

This anime is one that really made me happy and feel good, especially for how the show went along. This show is bound to make you root for Sawako and Kazehaya to get together, and it's easily a couple in anime that you would enjoy. Whether you're a person who loves romance animes or someone who enjoys slices of life, or someone who likes feel good animes, this is one that anyone can enjoy. The pace may not be for everyone, but I assure you that if you just roll along with it, it'll come out to be a series you would enjoy. This is one I highly recommend to anyone that watches anime, whether you're new to anime or a veteran in watching anime.

(Spoiler free)
SUMMARY
Kimi no Todake is a good slice-of-life high school romance. Featuring Sawako - a very shy, and socially withdrawn girl finally making friends and dealing with social interactions. You can forgive some minor irritations, due to the supporting cast of Ayane and Chizou moving things along nicely. It's a shame the second series falters after this good start - although things are wrapped up nicely. See my other review of Season 2.
OVERVIEW
Sawako Kunomura doesn't have many friends in high school. Made fun of, and feared, by her schoolmates for resembling the girl from the Ring series, she also has the nickname Sadako - nothelp by her unintended creepy smile and awkwardness. Things change one day though, when the most popular guy in school, Kazehuya, befriends her and she starts coming out of her shell. After soon becoming friends with Ayane Yona and Chizou Yoshida - she starts developing a social circle and all the drama that entails.


REVIEW

One thing becomes very apparent - Sawako does take everything far too literally. Her social anxieties and inability to read other people's emotions and intentions clearly is unusual - it seems she aligns with traits of someone on the autistic spectrum. When sarcastically told by other characters to become a ghost or do something - she will go ahead quite naively and carry it out quite literally.


Even when Sawako is facing other students with an ill intent towards her, Sawako's naive in her understanding of the situation. Sawako's excessive internal monologues can grate after a while - constantly thinking she's in the wrong, but thankfully things move on in an episode or two, with her realising she is a well liked person. By the end of the series Sawako has become more socially adept.


The male lead Kazehuya is a likeable but unremarkable guy, and only serves to provide moments of pleasantness and light relief. It's a shame as his function in the series is somewhat mute, given Ayane and Chizou great characterisations helping Sawako.


The best part of the show was easily, Ayane and Chizou - while initially introduced to give an impression of delinquent students they soon reveal themselves to be some of the kindest characters and Sawako's closest friends. There's a heart-warming scene in episode 4 which cements Sawako, Ayane and Chizou friendship.


The friendship between Ayane/Chizou/Sawako is the stand-out feature of series, and it overshadows the love interest between Sawako and Kazehuya - and even Sawako's own personal development. Regardless of the situation Sawako is facing, Ayane and Chizou are always on hand to make sure she will get by - this is incredibly refreshing, where in other romantic anime the supporting characters are just walls the protagonists can bounce their heads off - instead Ayane & Chizou are actively taking action to help. Situations where you would expect Ayane and Chizou to be mad at Sawako, are actually resolved through talking openly and honestly - without allowing the trope of a series of unfortunate misunderstandings develop (even though it seems this will be case early on in the series). The series makes you feel like everyone should have a friend like Ayane.


At times it feels as if the series is getting to a dull routine – and the introduction of Pin, a wise cracking chauvinistic supply teacher is a welcome addition – if only to alleviate Sawako's insecure rumblings.


The most disappointing thing part of the series was just how much animation and art styles vary – switching between ultra-cute and a more grounded art style. I get that the studio is trying to convey the endearing qualities of the characters but at times its too much. On occasions it is great in effect, but it happens so often it just too jarring – and it's a noticeable off putting point.


As is typical, there are some of misunderstandings that need to be cleared up - however what is a pleasant piece of fresh air is that none drag on too long, leading to a quick resolution of issues, and moving through relationship and character development in a brisk manner. With the exception of a couple of episodes that drag-on, the pacing is fair. Special note should be given to episodes 4, 10, 14 and 18 which are great moments for the season.


Overall, this is an OK romantic anime – leading into (a disappointing) final and complete Season 2.

Hello.
This will be my review about "Kimi ni Todoke", which I consider a really really great anime. 
On one hand, I struggled to actually make out a rating, as I wasn't sure to give it a 9 or a 10, and as a conclusion, I would give it a 9.60 which is rounded to 10. however, if I need to round a number I always choose the lower, as it actually reached that rating for me. 
As a first real rating topic, I take the storyline, which I consider one of the weaker points of the anime*, I feel like something is missing at fewparts (like the storyline to be less predictable, even though it is meant to be something like this). Although I especially liked how it went on. And the fact that besides romance you can actually laugh gets this anime an extra point. 


* Being a story maniac, it is awfully hard to give me a story that will get 10/10, so I will give my rating of 9.


Second for every anime is the art, which left me breathless. The design of the characters is something fabulous, also the special effects are used in a perfect balance with the story in the right moments which actually empowered the excitement. That was simply something I had to give 10 points.


Thirdly I need to mention that the sound is completely fine, the intro and outro fit the anime, also most of the sounds are placed at the right point, one or two little errors I felt, and even those might not be noticeable in most cases. So, all in all, I would give it 10/10.


The fourth point is the characters, some of which without the art do not give back what the story needs them for, however, the art corrects it sometimes and as the story goes on they become forgettable moments, although the main characters will remain for quite some time. For that lack of strength, I decided, however, to give it a 9.


Fifth point and last is the enjoyment which I can say that was the hardest to put a rating on. I was between 9 and 10, and I can actually say that the filler episode made me feel even more uncomfortable at a point, despite this I decided to give it a 10 because it was some time ago when I laughed so freely like on this anime and waited so much to see what's next. 


So in overall as I already said it's 48/5, which is exactly 9.6. But the anime itself is not a 10 for me, as it never really reached 10, not even for a moment, however, it was always close to it, so it's a superior and proud 9. 

Being so, I recommend watching it if you like romance animes with a cute sense of humor.

This is the very first romance anime I watched and I never regret to watch it and never get bored on re-watching it over again.
As I began to watch the first episode, I feel like 'well, okay' with this anime. But as I finish the first episode, I knew that this anime is going to be good and as I continue watching, the story become more beautiful and cute.
I love how the story not only telling about teenagers drama romance (although it centers in romance), but also some lessons in life and how a person could change if they tried to.
The art is not badand really cute at some scenes. The characters are unique and completes each other.\n\n
The sound are really great. Especially the opening and ending songs. Those are very good and I love hearing it over and over.\n\n

This anime visited a lot of tropes. By and large, it played straight the ones I love, and subverted the ones that usually aren't to my liking, catching me flatfooted more than once. Whereas many romcoms play with the old "will they, won't they" (spoiler alert: they usually will), this one didn't really leave any doubts by episode 3 that they definitely will.
Asking the if question above, it's often hard to write a story about. You can answer it yes or no and that's that. Kimi ni todoke didn't ask the if question, but more of the when and how and where question. You candefinitely write stories about those. Add into that that the main couple are not the be all, end all of this work, but instead we also get a well characterized supporting cast, and it definitely stands out from the usual blend.


All in all a very enjoyable anime, likely one of the very best in its genre, a genre which doesn't exactly lend itself to providing outstanding work, so a 8/10 overall is probably the best score a pure romcom is ever gonna reach. Kimi ni todoke definitely earns that mark.


I also liked the art style, and it seems to me it will age well.

This is my favorite anime. Ever. It was also my first ever anime so I might be biased but I really think it is incredible. I WON'T HAVE ANY SPOILERS in this review so you can read on safely, I'll skip the synopsis seeing as you can find many, and get right to what I love about this anime:
What I loved about it most is that it taught me things about life.
In this anime we look at the tough world of high school through the ultimately innocent eyes of Sawako. Though she doesn't really have any friends she is eternally optimistic, honest and.... extremely dense.The fact that she is dense, though, is actually what makes her so great at figuring out complicated issues of friendship, popularity and love. When you know nothing about life and making friends you have to start from zero and learn the basics first. We sometimes forget the basics getting too caught up in unwritten social rules and insecurities. Her solution to a lot of things that bother everyone is being honest, believing in people and not giving up. Everyone can clear up a misunderstanding. It gives you courage to see her go through life, it makes you want to be a good person. 


The best stories are the ones that make you want to be better yourself, that help you deal with everyday life and that help you become who you are or want to be, this is one of those stories.  Why are you still reading this, go watch it!! 


I see you're still reading this so I'll get into the other aspects of the anime. 

The anime is very slow paced with relatively little emotional pay offs and big moments. Personally it never bothered me for a minute, though, it made it more realistic and made the character development more meaningful. I think the way the anime works is very character driven, the story never seems to just serve the plot and choices and realizations are given enough time not to feel rushed. The story is actually quite typical shoujo but it still feels very different from a lot of other shoujo I've watched now and it is perfect in it's execution. The lack of regular emotional pay offs and big drama might bother you if you are already used to the shoujo genre (I wasn't) but I'd say give it a few episodes if you still think it's too uneventful then this might not be the anime for you. 


I really liked the art, has a bit of a pastel watercolory vibe, perfectly capturing the innocence and it's got the funny chibi versions of characters to show the extra emotions (and just to be funny). I also like the way the people are drawn not too unrealistically and that there's no trace of the weird obsession with boobs you seem to find in other animes. The backgrounds were also beautiful.

The music is not incredibly complicated, mostly simple piano, but perfect for the atmosphere. Both season one and season two have got great theme songs, too! The voice actors seemed perfect for their characters to me, but I did watch the anime first and I guess that can make a difference.


I think a lot of people will enjoy this anime, I got the recommendation from people whom I didn't think liked this kind of story. I never watched any anime before this one, foolishly thinking it wouldn't be for me, and this is what got me watching, so thinking like that is no excuse either! I've watched it multiple times, so even if you've already seen it and are just scrolling through wondering what you liked about it again, just go watch it, I'll shut up now.

(This is the first time I'm submitting my review, so I don't know if I'm doing it well..) 
These anime series is not like any other anime. The story is very heart warming and the kind of "slow" development between Sawako and Kazehaya didn't annoy  me at all.. In fact, it was very adorable to see those two getting closer by baby steps. 
Story (9/10): 
The story revolves around a girl named Kuronuma Sawako (often mistaken as Sadako a.k.a. the girl from "The Ring"). At school she doesn't really have friends, since everyone thinks they'll get cursed by even sitting on the chair sheused to sit on! That all changes, though, as she made new friends: Kazehaya-kun, Chizu-chan and Yano-chin (that's how she refers to them). The whole lonely girl making friends is, of course, not really a new thing in the anime/manga world, which makes the story a kind of cliché. HOWEVER, everything besides that is not really that cliché. Okay, except from the fact that Kazehaya is a popular guy chased by many girls who even set up a "Kazehaya belongs to everyone" group. I'm rattling too much right now.. Anyways, this anime is definitely worth watching! 


Art (9/10):

It's kind of.. yeah, plain, but also very creative. The characters don't have outstanding looks, pink hair, unnatural eye colors.. They just look like average japanese students. The reason why I give the art style an 9 is because to me, that kinda looks plain. But at the same time it looks nice too, I just don't know what to say about it. There are some moments when the art kinda differs, such as when Sawako gets nervous and such. She kinda turns into a chibi character or something like that lol. That always cracks me up. When Sawako smiles, however, the art mostly turns into a beautiful colorful art (since Sawako rarely smiles). This will all make sense to you if you watch the show, honestly.. 


Sound (9/10):

The sound was pretty nice. They used the right kind of music at the right moments. I also happened to hear acoustic versions of the intro/ending song. These were really peaceful. 


Character (8/10):

As for the character.. Honestly, you can't help but feel sorry for Sawako from time to time. She's pretty dense, you know. Sometimes a little too dense, to be honest. Sometimes it's pretty funny how she struggles to understand something that's actually very easy to understand. However, it's very fun to watch her open up more and more throughout the story. 


Enjoyment (9/10): 

I've actually re-watched this anime, because I knew how cute the story was. I really loved it the first time, but the second time was even lovelier. This anime is just ADORABLE. 


Overall (8,8/10):

JUST WATCH IT ALREADY! Oh, and don't forget about season 2!

Kimi ni todoke or From me to you is my all time favorite romance anime because of the scenes, the comedy and the amount of blushing and romance in it. 
I love this anime's choice of character personalities and how accurate the voice actors are to their anime character that they are voice acting. 
The soundtrack is very ear catching and made me listen to it about everyday when I first started watching this anime because the instruments that were put together to create one of the songs/background music always made the mood in the anime absolutely amazingly accurate to what the scene is about.\n\n
In my opinion I didn't see any flaws from this anime but this is just my opinion.\n\n
Overall this anime told me that friends are always there for you and that I don't need popularity to be happy.

This is one of my favourite animes. This anime is not for everyone. If you are looking for a romantic anime, and expecting a lot of interaction with the girl and her love interest, as well as great development in their relationship, you should know that this anime has a slow pace and is't romance driven.
 One of the reason I love this anime is becasue of the main character, Sawako. I enjoyed seeing how she interacts with other people, and how she develops friendship with her classmates. Her interactions with people and reactions to various things is what makes this anime so appealing.
I enjoyedthe art in this anime. It wasn't the most beautiful, and some of the characters designs looked very simple, but I loved the use of the background, and flowes. It has some beautiful scenes in it.\n
The sound suited the anime well. It was calm.\n
Characters are the biggest strength in this anime. Sawako's friend are the best friends in an anime show I've seen so far. They didn't only provide background to the main character. I was looking forward for Sawako to interact with her friends and loved Chizu and Ayane. As well as that, Kazehaya ( main love interest) is a really nice guy but also seems human aswell with some of his flaws.\n
Overall I loved this anime.  I loved it's different outlook on love, as it seemed more pure and innocent from other animes. \n\n

"Kimi ni Todoke" is something very elusive in anime: a realistic and non exploitative look at high school life. There is nary a boob shot! This is a rarity in anime, but probably in television everywhere, but I found it be a very enjoyable show. 
Our protagonist is Sawako (not Sadako!) a shy and jarringly awkward girl who has the best intentions but ends up terrifying her classmates. She even tries to embrace her spookiness as something of a personal quirk in a last-ditch effort to make friends. However, things really don't change until she happens into two new female friends who seem different fromthe rest. 


I found her to be a very relatable character. Who didn't have awkward teenage years? The story was a pleasing portrayal the way that her anxiety and lack of social aptitude frustrated her attempts to break out of her shell, while avoiding making her wallow obnoxiously in petty problems. The real highlight for me were the realistic moments of teenage glory - hanging out with her friends for the first time and the girls scheme to get her on the phone with her crush, for example, that reminded me of what it was like to be an awkward but enthusiastic teenager in the best possible way. 


This is really the last anime to watch if you want cheap titillation, obviously. Despite that it miraculously avoids melodrama through basically realistic characters. It even avoids being too tedious by having a funny teacher who generally makes a baffoon of himself given the slightest opportunity - I can't even say it breaks the realism as I had a sports coach teacher in high school myself who was remarkably similar to him. 


The art didn't strike me as anything special until the final story arc which takes place around New Years and features some stunningly beautiful scenes in the snow. 


I've sought out many animes like this, and by comparison, it's quite good. It is more realistic than "True Tears" or especially "Rumbling Hearts", which are popular shows in this subgenre, and largely as I result I found it to be superior to them. It even seemed a notch better than what had been my favorite "serious" high school romance anime, "Myself; Yourself" as the protagonist is better drawn as a realistic teenager.


It's hard to say why this wasn't a "perfect 10" for me. I definitely liked it, and wish there were more shows like it. Sawako's love interest is perhaps a bit too perfect, as if he was custom created to be the only sort of boyfriend who could spark up a relationship with a girl with such disastrous social skills. The story does stray into a side arc involving one of her female friends which was okay but definitely seemed a notch below the main story's quality. It was ultimately just very fun to watch and reached an enjoyable conclusion, but never really took it to the next level. For this sort of a realistic drama though, that might not even have been appropriate.


So yes, this is about the opposite of your typical high school anime. For me, that's a good thing. Maybe you're the same way?

Ah yes, Kimi ni Todoke. Possibly one of the best romances in my opinion. It's cute, and it's very fulfilling in the end. But no spoilers here!
Story - 8
--------
The story could be pretty generic if you look at it normally. But in my opinion, it just seems like the anime is about a bunch of misunderstandings. But it is believable. The first episode supports it as well. Overall, the story is really good and believable.
--------
Art - 8
--------
The animation and art style stood out to me. It was very fitting with the theme of the anime and very innocent. And don't get me wrong, Kimi niTodoke is a very innocent show, well Sawako has a really pure heart, only intending to interact with people normally, but I'll save that for the character section. The chibi moments in the anime were very adorable and lighthearted as well.\n
--------\n\n
Sound - 8\n
--------\n
The soundtrack in the anime is very relaxing and peaceful, especially the OP's and the ED's. While I was listening to the soundtrack, I felt my mind at ease. Definitely something worth listening to if you want to relax.\n
--------\n\n
Character - 9\n
--------\n
I loved all of the characters in Kimi ni Todoke.You can't hate any of them. I felt more connected to the supporting characters like Yano or Chizuru. Sawako is very likable and adorable. All she wants in life are friends. She is a bit of an airhead but that adds to her cuteness. Kazehaya is also a likable character, being energetic and a perfect match for Sawako. All the characters contrast each other and are all balanced in the show.\n
--------\n\n
Enjoyment - 9\n
--------\n
I wasn't bored by Kimi ni Tdoke, but frustrated. All romance anime has some type of misunderstanding that you want to have solved. Kimi ni Todoke is no exception. But I will say that it does have its comedy together and a good amount of cute moments that I will remember for a long time. I would definitely share funny moments with a friend or two to get them interested in the same anime.\n
--------\n\n
Overall - 9\n
--------\n
Although Kimi ni Tdoke is one of the best romances, it's not the best. It has its flaws like cliches and such, but it does stand out and makes a name for itself. The anime is a bit slow but quickly picks up in the second season. It really deserves more recognition than what it has right now. It's a really great anime in the end.

I can already see this is going to be a great anime. I mean, Sawako is the girl with the highest morals. I would love to live in the world where everybody was like her. 
The story feels too convenient to give Kimi ni Todoke 10/10. With 5 episodes it has already told something other anime do with twice as many episodes. But then again, straight forward story could be something to enjoy. 
The art is something that really compliments everything. It's very easy going, often using simple shapes or still images but not in a bad way. The emotions that need facial expression areexpressed while the ones not really important to the story are left with the simple shapes. \n\n
Everything else has been top notch and I really hope it continues to be for the rest.

After watching Kimi ni Todoke I like to think of this anime as a Jane Austen style romance. The slow growing relationship between the male and female protagonists is heartwarming, old fashioned and requires time to blossom. This anime takes patience and it is well rewarded.
When checking out reviews I often quickly read small portions so I'll say the most important bit first. If you are a fan of romance, comedy, school, shoujo or josei there's a good chance that you'll enjoy Kimi ni Todoke. In my opinion you don't need to be a veteran of these genres either. I am relatively new to theworld of romance anime and I extremely enjoyed Kimi ni Todoke. This anime also has a live action adaptation which I found helped ease the, 'what am I to do with my life now' feeling after completing an awesome series. To keep from writing any spoilers about the ending I will only say that it is written extremely well though I do recommend watching season two for a proper sense of story completion.


The plot itself is nothing overly complicated. It has similarities to other stories in the shoujo/romance genre but I thought it was unique in it's own way. I found myself emotionally invested in the story. I've never had an anime make me teary eyed and then full of joy until I watched Kimi ni Todoke. 


You'll find yourself rooting for the characters. The friendships that develop are outstanding and were by far my favorite part of this anime. The majority of the main characters are extremely likable. Kuronuma is refreshing as the female lead though you may find yourself frustrated with her at times. The same goes for the male lead, Kazehaya. You come to understand just how much they have in common as the story gives you both of their perspectives. This anime does a brilliant job at conveying the emotions of the characters which in turn involves the audience.


The art was superbly done and some scenes were downright beautiful. I am a bit of a snob when it comes to the art, I like anime's that look realistic, colorful and lovely without that extreme cartoony style. Overall the music was enjoyable and the scene music fit perfectly. I especially liked the opening songs for both seasons. This is one you don't skip over the openings or endings.


All in all I'm glad I decided to watch Kimi ni Todoke. There's so much anime to choose from and this is one that should be chosen. It will give you that warm feeling in your heart and leave you a little bit happier with the world.

After watching Kimi Ni Todoke, and Kimi Ni Todoke S2, I found myself lost for words. All I could think about was the ending, and how utterly adorable some of the scenes were in this anime. When I was suppose to be sleeping, I just couldn't get it out of my head. I don't usually feel this way about most anime's, in general.
When I heard about Kimi Ni Todoke, and read the plot, I thought, "Oh, another cliche romance." And I was right, some of the situations, and moments in this anime are very cliche, but I felt that they did a great job atturning those usually normal moments into something even greater.


When a character did something, or said something cute or embarrassing, I would be on the edge of my seat, grinning from ear to ear, or covering my eyes; even though it wasn't me experiencing all this.


The art, music, and sounds are memorable, and the characters and plot are to die for. I really felt for these characters, and although I usually get annoyed by cliche characters in romances, this anime did a really good job at expressing the emotion realistically. Some moments we're a bit doubtful, and were a bit unrealistic, but c'mon, it's anime right?


Overall Kimi Ni Todoke is a heartwarming, cute, slice of life anime with a dash of Perfect romance. I can't even begin to explain the feelings I felt while watching this, and it wasn't just the plot, it was the very vibes. Even when one character blushed, or glanced at another character, I was whining with joy.


Maybe I'm crazy to feel so happy when watching this anime, but if I were to rate it, my rating would be a perfect score. 10/10.


I hope anyone who reads this will enjoy.

all in all this anime is a great succes for those who like innocent romance and friendschip

This is the best anime I've watched since lyke 2 weeks ago.
          The story line is great since its about a girl who is misunderstood because of her long black hair and her school mates all call her 'Sadako' but her real name is Sawako which means Lively Child in japenese.There one guy Kazehaya ,in her class who cannot stand it if anyone in his class do not fit in well,secretly Kazehaya has a crush on Sawako but Sawako just admires and respect him for being cheerful all the time. The story continuses with a lotof great counter with Sawako and Kazehaya.After the sports festival,Sawako finally realised that she is also in love with Kazehaya,Kazehaya asks her about how she feels about 'going out'.Sawako shyly replies that she is still young and 'Going Out' is a very mature step that she would not want to take.Kazehaya's love for Sawako gets bigger as troubles comes in his way.Will Kazehaya be able to get Sawako's heart? Im reading the manga and we're on chapter 69 and the STILL haven't kissed. 
i just find the characters a little slow to realize their feelings. i love Chizu and Ryu. They're very cute. 
Very funny anime and veeerrrryyy cute :) recommended watch if you're patient.

I had been looking for a good romance anime for a while and finally found it in this. At first the main females voice was a little annoying but then either I got used to it or it changed to show maturity. But this show has a great romance and friendship story. I really loved this and it felt so believeable that I even cried with it. (I am a 25 year old lady.... so that says a lot)
I am sure others have put everything I wanted to put in here, but I really wanted to let everyone know that this is only season oneand that there is a shorter second season that closes a lot of the loose ties. It is not as fast paced as peach girl but I really loved this anime like I did for PeachGirl and Hana Yori Dango.

In Australia, days off work are usually reserved for instances of sickness. I started watching this one at about 11pm and went old school with a 10 hour 'i'll be fine for work' marathon. Needless to say, I made the call. 
The high rank on MAL is what brought me to watch the show and I was not disappointed. The story for me was original. I've seen the movie 'The RIng' and the introduction of 'Sadako's' character had me in stitches. The early laugh made the rest of the ride easy. 
The art was really well done. I loved the intro. The colours and framesreally set the tone for what you can expect. The character designs are very pretty and real easy on the marathoning eyes. All the girls are really cute, not in a 'chibi' type way, but more of a 'legit' way.\n\n
Soundtrack is good. I acquired it immediately afterwards. Loved the intro tracks to both and the background music was very fitting for all scenes. The voicing is excellent. They all match (looks vs sound). I love a show thats really well thought out across the board.\n\n
For me, the best stories are all about the characters and their situations. This show was able to turn somebody's interesting situation into something very enjoyable. The characters are great and         you get very well acquainted as the series moves forward (yes 'forward!'). The smile I had after watching this show was well worth the day off. If you need something to smile smile about, look here.

Finally, I'm done watching Kimi Ni Todoke & I'd say that those 3 days/nights ain't half bad...
After reading the reviews for this anime, I told myself that this one could be a keeper and that I need to watch it... True enough, I'm glad I was able to get a copy of the whole season 1...
Main Characters: Sawako Kuronuma and Shouta Kazehaya
Story: 8/10 - I can say that the storyline is more realistic than the other anime romances I've seen... it seemed more heartfelt... I'm glad that the writers did not rush the story, however, there was an "arc" that I did not particularly likeand this is the Kurumi rivalry arc... that was when I kinda got uninterested and watched a different movie... good thing it was saved by the Chizuru - Ryu - Tohru arc... it was also refreshing to get the guy's point of view (speaking for both Kazehaya and Ryu)... 


Characters: 8/10 - Sawako as "Sadako" is funny esp in chibi-japanese doll-form... it took quite a while for me to get used to her voice since it's too high pitched/breathy but once I was able to equate the voice with her personality, it became easier to bear... Kazehaya is cute and funny whenever he shares an "embarassing moment" with Sawako... though I did not really feel that he was given a story of his own... hmmm... Chizu, Ayane and Ryu were good supporting characters for the couple... I am glad that they were given ample screen time since they liven up the story...


Sound: 8/10 - very nice opening and ending songs... BG music for most part were romantic as well as dramatic... fits well with the scenes...


Enjoyment: 7/10 - it would have been an 8 if only Kurumi was an interesting character... also, it seems that Sawako cries a lot and i mean a lot (may it be bcoz of joy or sadness)... but then again, her new feelings can be so overwhelming that anyone would cry...


Overall: 7/10 - it was a little slow-paced for me but like I said, it was realistic... not all courtships end in a span of 1yr... besides, the characters are only in high school (I think)...


It ended on a good and sweet note... here's hoping that the 2nd season will be much better...  :)

While the anime possessed a lot of good components, it wasn't as good as it would seem. I originally became interested in the anime after seeing an amv (Anime Music Video) with some pretty interesting and romantic scenes.
It took watching the whole season and practically the whole second season for anything to actually happen. Even then, there was no kiss, which ranks badly in my mind for romance.
I loved the interaction between Sawako and her friends, and Kazehaya was really cute.
The first season was a lot better than the beginning of the second season, that's for sure. If you want a lot of romance andnot just a few odd moments every now and then, this is not the anime for you.

This Anime makes me crazy.. the story is so cute.. 
the characters in this anime is also cool too.. the best anime i've for this MONTH :) try ot :)

Sawako Kuronuma, or people called her as Sadako  for her resemblance to the character from Ring, has always been feared and misunderstood because of her appearance. There are rumors that Sawako can see ghosts and curse people. However, despite her appearances, she is a sweet and timid girl who longs to be able to make friends with everyone and be liked by everyone else. When her idol, popular boy Kazehaya, begins talking with her, everything changes. She finds herself in a new world, trying to make friends and talking to different people and she can't thank Kazehaya enough for giving her these opportunities. Slowly,but surely, a sweet love is blossoming between the two as they will overtake any circumstance or clear obstacles in their way.
